IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: This R61/R33 proposal is based on converging evidence that suggests prior ADHD working memory training studies might have produced lackluster clinical outcomes because they focused on enhancing the wrong cognitive and neurobiological targets. The proposed studies will assess whether or not a novel executive working memory training intervention for Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder can engage frontoparietal brain network treatment targets and behavioral performance (R61), then replicate target engagement while also determining if it correlates with clinically meaningful improvements in ADHD dysfunction (R33). The project was designed so that if the R61/R33 aims are successful, the data we obtain will be adequate to support a future preliminary efficacy clinical trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal aims to characterize the neuro-computational mechanisms that drive human social learning, and their alterations in relation to trans-diagnostic symptom dimensions relevant to psychopathology. Social learning computations will be examined both in the general population and in autism, a neuro-developmental disorder known to be associated with deficits in social function. In the long run, this research has the potential to inform the development of more tailored clinical assessments and interventions to improve social function in mental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recurrent glioblastoma is associated with poor response to immunotherapy due in part to the immune- suppressive tumor microenvironment. Localized interleukin 12 (IL12) is making progress in therapy for malignant brain tumors by triggering anti-tumor immunity in patients. Our proposal will study IL12-induced anti- and pro-tumoral signaling in GB mouse models and develop a next-generation treatment whereby multi-factorial nanocarriers (extracellular vesicles) sustain IL12-triggered immunomodulating effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Approximately 17 million adults in the US are currently diagnosed with an alcohol use disorder (AUD), and about 95,000 people die from alcohol-related causes annually, making alcohol the third leading preventable cause of death in the US. Alcohol is a social drug and is believed to affect interpersonal processes in ways that might contribute to the development and maintenance of AUD. This project aims to better understand AUD risk within close social relationships by focusing on how poor relationship quality impacts the experience of alcohol intoxication in ways that reinforce drinking and increase risk to develop alcohol problems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Repetitive ozone exposures result in mucoinflammatory respiratory responses that are also associated with allergic asthma. Thus, the sustained ozone pollution during the resolution phase of allergic asthma may disrupt restoration of tissue structure and function. Using innovative approaches, supported by our novel and exciting data, we will study the effect of ozone pollution on the resolution of allergen-induced asthmatic inflammation that will also include genetic and pharmacological strategies to neutralize the proinflammatory/anti-resolution effect of ozone-mediated disruptions in the resolution of allergic respiratory disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Insomnia is prevalent sleep disorder, with highest rates among low-income adults, which is a risk factor for a host of physical and mental health conditions. This study aims to compare how well two, proven non-drug treatments treat insomnia in 350 adults of lower income and/or racial and ethnic minority groups seen in primary care. This study will inform future studies designed to test the best strategies to make these treatments more available for underserved patients with insomnia in primary care and thereby improve health.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Cryptococcus is a ubiquitous fungal pathogen which causes substantial morbidity and mortality in Veterans and other patients worldwide. Veterans have increased risk of infection due to higher rates of immunocompromising medical conditions relative to the general population (HIV and use of immune suppressive therapies). Current therapies for patients infected with Cryptococcus are lengthy, highly toxic, often ineffective, and may actually contribute to inflammatory complications. These complications are linked to pathological brain damage, mortality, and/or development of lasting disabilities in these patients. This proposal will study immune mechanisms preventing detrimental immune responses during cryptococcal CNS infection and explore immunotherapeutic potential of regulatory T cells in a relevant animal model. Our results will be also relevant to other CNS infections caused by pathogens to which Veterans are exposed to during deployment (malaria, tuberculosis meningitis and CNS viruses).

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: PTSD is 3-4 times more prevalent in Veterans than in the general population, and this gap is anticipated to increase due to ongoing conflict extensions and prolonged, repeated deployments. PTSD has been described as a “life sentence due to its association with increased risk of chronic disease, accelerated aging, and premature mortality.” Meta analyses suggest that low bone mass (osteopenia) and osteoporosis are significant comorbidities for patients with PTSD. Our preliminary data in a pre-clinical model of PTSD supports the hypothesis that PTSD-related bone loss is due to an imbalance between bone building cells (osteoblasts) and bone resorbing cells (osteoclasts) and that SHP2 mediates this osteoblast-osteoclast dysregulation. Herein, we will determine the cellular and molecular mechanisms driving PTSD-related bone loss and investigate novel methods for mitigating these negative bone effects. This proposal employs innovative approaches and has significant clinical impact for Veterans by identifying PTSD as a critical risk factor for bone morbidities.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Even though there are astrocytes in the brain, and they outnumber neurons, current circuit models of sleep-wake regulation continue to be “neuron-centric”. We will use the microendoscopy method to measure changes in fluorescence in individual astrocytes and neurons in a deep-brain region implicated in sleep. The data will describe a more complete network model of sleep regulation that will aid in strategies to treat insomnia.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The PI studies DNases, the enzymes which fragment DNA during any organ or tissue injury: chemical or drug poisoning, radiation, hypoxia, cancer or atherosclerosis. The mechanisms and role of the DNA fragmentation is not known, and, more importantly, no protection against DNases, is available. The PI’s research determines the DNase mechanisms and develop new DNase inhibitors which have a great promise to be used as universal drugs to ameliorate human diseases, including cancer and atherosclerosis, organ chemical injuries and traumas, as well as toxic side effects of drugs. These studies are highly relevant to the VA healthcare because organ injuries are common in Veterans, military personnel, and elderly. These studies may eventually save human lives, improve the health and wellbeing of Veterans, and decrease the number of disabilities among Veterans and in the general American population.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The apical sodium dependent bile acid transporter (ASBT) mediates bile acid absorption in the small intestine and controls their amount returning to the liver, which is a key regulator of cholesterol balance in the body. Blocking bile acid absorption reduces bile acid load and resortes cholesterol imbalance in the body. We recently discovered that ASBT activity can be regulated by a novel phenomenon called s-acylation, involving the attachment of different fatty acids to ASBT. The proposed studies are focused at investigating mechanisms that could effectively decrease bile acid absorption and also impact fatty acid and cholesterol metabolism to aid in the development of superior treatment for hypercholesterolemia. Diseases associated with hypercholesterolemia such as diabetes mellitus are highly prevalent among the veterans. The proposed studies are, therefore, relevant to the VA patients and the general patient population.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The potential benefits of this study are improvements in the diagnosis of precancerous polyps during colonoscopy, and enhancements in the quantification of colonoscopy quality measures. The study will focus on validating the use artificial intelligence to teach computers how to use endoscopic images to automatically classify polyps and other landmarks in the colon seen through the endoscope. One feature of our approach is that we use augmented reality to present the results from artificial intelligence predictions to endoscopists. This gives endoscopists immediate intuitive visual feedback about the polyp’s classification. Additional potential benefits of this research relating to healthcare include the following: 1. Real-time diagnosis of polyps would reduce the number of biopsies of benign tissue, significantly reducing procedure risks, costs and healthcare burden. 2. More thorough surveillance examinations could be performed to minimize missed precancerous polyps, thus decreasing cancer risk.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Spinal cord injury (SCI) is a devastating event that affects younger Veterans and is associated with long-term disability including debilitating neuropathic pain. In the acute phase of SCI, secondary tissue injury and the initiation of chronic pain occur due to a robust neuroinflammatory response triggered by immune cells in the spinal cord. Because of the poor regenerative capacity of the spinal cord, interventions need to target this inflammatory response to maximize functional outcomes. Treatment must be immediate and at the time of injury. This proposal will investigate an inhibitor of HuR, a major protein that drives the neuroinflammatory response after SCI. This molecule can be given peripherally and it quickly suppresses induction of the inflammatory response. We will determine its ability to improve functional outcomes by blocking secondary tissue injury and chronic neuropathic pain after SCI. This research proposal is therefore directly relevant to Veteran health and has the potential to improve quality of life for those who have suffered SCI.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: HARRY S. TRUMAN MEMORIAL VA HOSPITAL
PHR: Project Narrative  Cardiovascular diseases (CVD) are the major causes of morbidity and mortality in veterans. For two decades, my research focused on dissecting the molecular mechanisms underlying the initiation and progression of inflammatory CVD, has identified four potential therapeutic targets: IL-18 (Interleukin-18), TRAF3IP2 (TRAF3 Interacting Protein 2), Larp6 (La Ribonucleoprotein Domain Family Member 6), and RECK (Reversion Inducing Cysteine Rich Protein with Kazal Motifs. Increased expression of IL-18 and TRAF3IP2 play a causal role in myocardial injury, adverse cardiac remodeling, and HF development. Larp6, a RNA-bing protein, plays a role in collagen synthesis. RECK inhibits multiple mediators involved in adverse cardiac remodeling. My goal of determining if neutralizing IL-18, inhibiting TRAF3IP2 or Larp6, or inducing RECK can blunt progression of CVD is highly relevant to veterans and the mission of the Veterans Health Care System.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Many stroke survivors will develop impairments in memory, thinking, or decision-making due to the damage in the blood vessels in the brain, which is called vascular contributions to cognitive impairment and dementia (VCID); hence, there is a need to develop therapies that will improve or prevent these impairments following stroke. Insulin resistance, a common comorbidity in stroke survivors, reduces brain insulin levels, which can impact several processes important for the recovery of vessel damage due to stroke. The current proposal will investigate the benefit of improving brain insulin levels and signaling in preventing damage to blood vessels and in alleviating memory, thinking, or decision-making impairments.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Dr. Risbrough’s research program on post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and traumatic brain injury (TBI) is highly relevant to Veterans’ health in a number of ways. First, her aims to identify the molecular and genetic mechanisms of risk and symptom maintenance for post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) supports development of novel targets for interventions across the trauma-response trajectory, i.e. both early and late periods post-trauma. Second, her studies to develop fluid biomarkers of mild TBI and its associated cognitive disruption may provide a clinically feasible tool to aid diagnosis as well as prediction of long-dysfunction. Third, her work in understanding mechanisms of the gold-standard treatment for PTSD, exposure therapy, and how it can be enhanced through additional behavioral and pharmacological therapies is aimed at improving treatment outcome in Veterans with PTSD.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Sepsis strikes 750,000 Americans every year; prolonged hospitalization, secondary infections, sepsis recidivism, and hospital readmission are the most common long-term consequences in sepsis survivors. The long-term goal of Dr. Thomas Griffith’s laboratory is to define the cellular and molecular mechanisms responsible for the chronic state of sepsis-induced immunoparalysis by performing cutting-edge, biomedical research using a combination of preclinical models and clinical samples. It is by building upon such detailed understanding of sepsis pathophysiology that new, promising clinical treatments can be developed, and existing treatments improved. It is in this way that this PhD basic scientist aims to contribute to the health needs of our nation’s Veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: EDITH NOURSE  ROGERS MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSPITAL
PHR: This proposal addresses a critical need for both our older and younger populations of veterans. Head trauma may be a risk factor for both amyotrophic lateral sclerosis and Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy, a neurodegenerative disease caused by repetitive mild traumatic brain injury. Soldiers have always been at risk for head injury and this is particularly the case for OEF/OIF veterans, many of who have experienced explosive blast injury and participated in contact sports. There is a critical need to understand the mechanisms and genetic risk factors underlying this injury to facilitate prevention, diagnosis, and treatment. The aging veteran population and high rate of head injury will lead to daunting costs and responsibilities for the VA if research aimed at translating mechanisms into biomarkers and treatments is not developed.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Bladder dysfunction is highly prevalent in the aging veteran population and is the most common complication of diabetes and Parkinson’s disease. Disorders of the bladder are often ignored or overlooked in those with comorbidity, which can lead to a devastating series of pathological events. The negative impact of bladder dysfunction on the physical, mental, emotional and social health of the veteran population, as well as on the financial and healthcare delivery responsibilities of the VHA, underlie the critical need to better understand and manage problems related to the bladder. This proposal will investigate a novel signaling complex underlying bladder neurotransmission that is disrupted by diabetes and Parkinson’s disease. New insights regarding this shared bladder neuropathology will establish a foundation for design of better targeted pharmacotherapy and provide opportunities for early intervention of progressive neurogenic bladder dysfunction.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA NEW JERSEY HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Neurodegeneration in the brain and spinal cord represent significant problems for Veterans. For example, traumatic brain injury (the signature affliction of approximately 320,000 of the deployed personnel in recent combat operations overseas) is currently untreatable and has persistent effects on patients, families, and our healthcare system. Another example involves the high number, in excess of 25%, of the Veterans of Operation Desert Storm suffering a multisymptom disorder termed Gulf War Illness frequently involving neurological problems. These and other neurodegenerative conditions affecting Veterans warrant a better understanding of the molecular causes to help in the development of treatments to improve their health and quality of life. By identifying key factors influencing the course of neurodegeneration and testing treatments to reduce and reverse the losses of neuronal function the goal to improve the outcome for Veterans will be advanced.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Water-soluble vitamins are essential micronutrients for normal human health and well-being. Their deficiencies (whether systemic or tissue-specific) lead to a variety of serious clinical abnormalities. The incidences of deficiency/sub-optimal levels of water-soluble vitamins are common in our Veterans as well as in the general population, and occur due to a variety of factors/conditions and diseases. This include chronic alcohol consumption, chronic exposure to cigarette smoke, inflammation (as in inflammatory bowel diseases), infection with foodborne enteric-pathogens, diabetes mellitus, drug-nutrient interactions, and aging. Our studies aim at understand the cellular/molecular mechanisms involved in the absorption/transport of water-soluble vitamins in organs of the digestive system, and how external/internal factors and disease conditions negatively impact these processes. Our ultimate goal is to identify effective strategies to prevent vitamin malabsorption and deficiencies, and thus, improve human health and well-being.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Multiple sclerosis (MS) occurs when the immune system mistakenly attacks myelin in the brain, leading to loss of motor function. MS affects a large number of Veterans and no cure exists. Further, existing treatments are not specific and can leave patients immunocompromised. The need for life-long treatment also creates a large burden on patients and families. The goal of this project is to use nanotechnology to control signal processing in lymph nodes, tissues that regulate immune function. This ability could promote regulatory immune cells that specifically control the inflammatory cells attacking myelin. This advance would benefit Veteran’s health in three ways. First, myelin-specific tolerance that controls disease without hindering healthy immunity would improve efficacy and Veteran quality of life. Second, generating long-lasting regulatory cells would enable less frequent treatments, improving patient compliance and reducing the burden of managing disease. Lastly, since treatments might provide permanent improvements, healthcare costs for Veterans and families could be greatly reduced.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Currently no treatment is available to slow down or stop neurodegenerative processes of Alzheimer’s disease (AD). My research program has an ongoing interest of developing investigational new drugs (IND)-enabling novel therapies for AD. We have been studying a novel target to improve cognitive function, called synaptojanin 1 (synj1) and several lines of data suggest beneficial effects of synj1 reduction in AD. We have developed scaffolds of novel small molecules with synj1-lowering capabilities, and identified two lead compounds with great oral bioavailability, blood brain barrier (BBB) penetrability and long-term in vivo efficacy at improving cognitive function in multiple AD mouse models. Therefore, we propose to perform the IND-enabling studies of two lead compounds including pharmacological and toxicology studies, as well as biomarker development with the ultimate goals of transitioning into clinical studies and the commercialization of our novel AD therapies.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JOHN D DINGELL VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: The nominee’s research investigates molecular mechanisms of disorders associated with chronic inflammation such as breast and lung cancers, and reno-vascular hypertension. These diseases are known to cause significant morbidity and mortality with attendant increases in direct medical costs, loss of productivity and quality of life in our veterans of all ages. The research projects are intended to elucidate mechanisms of drug resistance in human triple-negative breast (TNBC) and non-small cell lung cancers (NSCLC), and exploit this knowledge to design, synthesize and optimize novel compounds that inhibit therapy-induced survival, and activate CARP-1 and apoptosis in naïve and drug-resistant cancer cells. CARP-1 and the novel CFM and SNI compounds were discovered by the nominee through the VA supported Merit funds. The nominee is also productively collaborating with Detroit VA clinician to investigate mechanisms of reno-vascular hypertension, and served as co-investigator on two, VA Merit proposals. Rishi - 1

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is an incurable fatal neurologic disease leading to progressive paralysis and, in many cases, cognitive decline. There is no effective treatment for ALS and its ultimate cause remains unknown. Because studies suggest that veterans are at increased risk for ALS, VA established ALS as a 100% service-connected disability. VA has made a major commitment to support research on ALS and funded the creation of the VA Biorepository Brain Bank (VABBB) as a national resource to support ALS research. Enrolled veterans with ALS across the country receive semi-annual telephone calls to collect health information. Upon a veteran’s death, the VABBB arranges for the collection of brain and spinal cord tissue for processing, storage, and distribution to qualified ALS investigators. The availability of high-quality tissue and clinical data from veterans enrolled in the VABBB is an essential resource to support research on the causes and effects of ALS and the development of effective treatments for those affected by this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Emerging evidence supports the critical role of gut microbiome in development of Veterans’ deployment related GI and liver diseases. To date, however, the role of Gulf War Illness (GWI) microbiome in diarrheal diseases in GWI has not been investigated. The proposed studies in this application, based on our exciting preliminary data from a humanized GWI mouse model established by us are aimed at investigating the mechanisms underlying the higher incidence of diarrheal diseases in GWI veterans. We propose to utilize both the humanized mice (fecal microbial transplant or FMT from GWI veterans), and conventional GWI mice (war chemical induced) to understand the causative role of GWI microbiome in increasing susceptibility to diarrheal pathogens and the mechanisms involved. We will also assess the therapeutic role of FMT from healthy donors, probiotics and bacterial metabolite butyrate in GWI. The studies may unravel new targets for better treatment of GWI Veterans utilizing novel approaches to alter microbiome.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: MICHAEL E DEBAKEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Hospital admissions are challenging for adults with dementia and for the family and friends who care for them. Following hospital discharge, adults with dementia often have increased care needs, which places new demands on their family and friends. Family and friends are critical to ensuring that Veterans with dementia can live safely in the community following discharge. Healthcare systems have an opportunity to support family and friends of adults with dementia by addressing dementia specific caregiving challenges that arise during the transition from hospital to home. However, there are no support interventions for dementia caregivers that have been developed or tested as part of hospital care. In this proposal, we will design and test a novel support intervention for the family and friends who care for hospitalized Veterans with dementia. This proposal aligns with the research priorities of the Veterans Health Administration and the National Institute on Aging to identify strategies to support the family and friends who provide care to adults with dementia across care settings.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Prostate cancer (PCa) is a major health issue among military veterans in the United States. Metal exposures experienced during deployment and post-deployment likely have significant impacts on PCa risk in veterans. Inorganic arsenic (iAs) and lead (Pb) are classified as a carcinogen and potential carcinogen, respectively, in humans. Demographic data on veterans and their occupations suggest a potential risk for veterans to be exposed to metals, such as iAs and Pb, in environmental and occupational settings. However, the underlying molecular mechanisms that link metal exposure and PCa are understudied. This application will test the hypothesis that iAs or Pb transforms prostate epithelial stem-like cells to initiate or increase PCa risk in a mouse model. Our research using a novel approach of single-cell RNA-seq will reveal this rare epithelial stem cell population in the adult prostate as the possible origin of metal-associated prostate cancer and provide novel specific biomarkers that will advance our current strategies for assessing PCa risk and treating the disease in humans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This Collaborative Merit Award application (CMA) is a synergistic, multidisciplinary project focused on the mechanistic understanding of platinum resistance (PtR) as the foremost cause of death in ovarian cancer patients. The overall strategy is to integrate ideas, resources, and expertise in advanced technologies to identify and validate novel therapeutic targets and biomarker-driven treatments for ovarian cancer patients. This application (CMA2) will study metabolic reprograming associated with emergence of PtR focusing on a shift from glycolysis to fatty acid oxidation in PtR HGSOC cells and tumors. The project will use novel single cell metabolic imaging (stimulated Raman scattering) along with lipidomic measurements to define metabolic vulnerabilities of resistant HGSOC. The deliverables of CMA2 will be a molecular imaging based prognostic test to recognize PtR and new enzymatic inhibitors as novel therapeutic approaches for PtR HGSOC.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The long-term neurological functional deficits after traumatic brain injury (TBI) are major health concerns among veterans. Currently, no therapy is available to alleviate these neurological deficits. Recent research highlights the importance of immune responses in brain recovery. Regulatory T cells (Tregs) are a specialized subpopulation of immune cells that inhibit excessive immune responses under pathological conditions. This proposal will test the hypothesis that Tregs improve brain repair and promote long-term recovery after TBI by polarizing microglia/macrophages toward a beneficial phenotype that tempers inflammation and encourages tissue healing. This study will test the therapeutic potential of a protein complex composed of interleukin 2 (IL2) and IL2 antibodies, which increases endogenous Treg numbers and prevents the destructive sequelae of TBI. The results will shed light on the communication between immune cells and the injured brain, and are expected to inform future clinical immunotherapies against the long-term deficits suffered by TBI victims.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) classified Clostridioides difficile infection (CDI) as “Threat level urgent” and called for “urgent and aggressive action” to address a significant public health crisis in 2013 and 2019. The molecular epidemiology of CDI has changed drastically over the past 10 year and the epidemic strain, restriction endonuclease analysis (REA) group BI, PCR ribotype (RT) 027 has decreased significantly. However, REA group Y, which commonly correlates to RT 014 and 020[Y(RT014/020)], has remained a prominent group strain since the 1980s. Despite the endemic nature of Y(RT014/020), a detailed molecular analysis has never been completed. We propose to determine the prevalence and risk factors associated with the endemic Y(RT014/020) and the epidemic BI/RT027 group strains and perform a rigorous genomic analysis of Y(RT014/020) and BI/RT027 obtaining critical information to assess the endemic nature of Y(RT014/020) to assess our hypothesis that Y(RT014/020) resides within an unknown community reservoir.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is becoming a globally prevalent disease, especially among US veterans. NAFLD and non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) are recognized as hepatic manifestations of metabolic syndrome. No effective therapy has been developed due to the incomplete understanding of the pathogenesis of this complex disease. BAs are important multifunctional signaling molecules. BA-mediated activation of sphingosine-1-phosphate receptor 2 (S1PR2) and sphingosine kinase 2 (SphK2) plays a critical role in hepatic lipid metabolism. Our proposed studies are aimed at elucidating the molecular mechanisms underlying BA-mediated activation of S1PR2/SphK2 in NASH disease progression. Completing this study will identify the potential novel cellular/molecular mechanisms in the initiation and progression of NAFLD/NASH and make a significant conceptual advance linking BAs and sphingolipids with metabolic diseases, which will create a fundamental base for developing novel therapies for NAFLD/NASH.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Almost 50% of women and 30% of men will suffer a fracture in their lifetimes. Fractures are a serious problem in aging Veterans and cause crippling disability requiring rehabilitation in up to 75% of individuals, loss of independence, and significant declines in quality of life. One year mortality after hip fracture in elderly veterans is 18% for women and 32% for men. Economic burden of fracture in the US is further projected to reach $25 billion/annum by 2025. As the largest integrated health care system in the US, the VA is on the front lines of fracture treatment and will have to absorb these ever-expanding medical needs and costs. In this project, we will use animal models to study two bone diseases that disproportionally affect Veterans, postmenopausal osteoporosis and bone loss cause by antiretroviral therapy against HIV. We will compare a novel therapeutic approach targeting early prevention of bone loss, to that of the current standard of care in which bone is regenerated after it has already been lost, a process that is only partly effective using currently available drugs.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: LOUIS STOKES CLEVELAND VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: The decline in immunity with age contributes to poor response to vaccines, reduced recovery from new pathogens, increased cancer and a host of other morbidities. By 2050 it is predicted that 22% of the US population will be >65 years old. At the Cleveland VA Medical Center, around 1400 patients are enrolled in the Geriatric Clinic with an average age of 83 years old. During the 2018-2019 flu season people >65 accounted for 75% of deaths. We know that elderly have lower numbers of naïve T cells and increased inflammation but how these immune parameters contribute to immune dysfunction and poor response to immunization is unclear. Many facets of the immune system are interdependent and complex. Understanding which compartments contribute to poor vaccine response in the elderly, and identifying the pre-existing and unique immunological obstacles that must be overcome in the elderly population for an effective influenza vaccine are paramount for elderly veteran health.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a significant contributor to recalcitrant multi-drug resistant infections especially in immunocompromised and hospitalized patients. Multi-drug and totally drug resistant strains of P. aeruginosa are increasing threats that contribute to high mortality in these patients. Drug resistant infections are a threat to our Veteran population. Hence there is an urgent need to develop new strategies to combat P. aeruginosa and other resistant pathogens. The pathogenic profile of P. aeruginosa is related to its ability to secrete a variety of virulence factors and promote biofilm formation. Strategies that strengthen the ability of the host to inhibit these virulence factors would enhance host defenses and improve treatment. The goal of this proposal is to define novel molecular approaches to stimulate immune response through PGC-1 alpha activators (such as Metformin) to inhibit bacterial virulence and enhance host defenses. The results from these studies can be readily translated to human clinical trials since pioglitazone is already FDA approved for treatment of diabetes.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Osteoporosis and hypertension are major health concerns that lower lifespan and hinder the ability to remain independent and active. Veterans are susceptible to both diseases, and clinical studies indicate that the progression of these two chronic conditions occur at the same time suggesting they are linked. To identify new strategies in the prevention of fragility fractures, the devastating consequence of osteoporosis, this project will investigate common pathways by which hypertension activates the bone marrow to cause bone loss and weaken bone. By using established pre-clinical models of this disease using aged animals, by collaborating with other Veteran Affairs research investigators to share ideas and unify rigorous outcome measures, and by targeting secondary causes of osteoporosis, this project is well positioned to identify a new and translatable strategy for improving bone health, namely increasing the fracture resistance of bone.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Increased incidence of lymphoma over the past decade is a major concern for our aging Veterans. While clinical advances have been made in diffuse large B cell lymphoma (DLBCL) treatment, there is still high mortality (~50%) in afflicted individuals with R-CHOP therapy due to frequent occurrence of relapsed/refractory cases and limited clinical efficacy in co-morbid patients. Clearly, there is an unmet medical need for improved, less toxic therapy for lymphoma. Our initial observations suggest that enhanced FASN activity functionally regulates the eIF4B -driven protein translational machinery in DLBCL cells. Extending our work, our preliminary data indicate that PARK2 ubiquitinates eIF4B in a FASN-dependent manner. Furthermore, we observed that eIF4B is an LKB1 substrate, positioning the protein as a key therapeutic target. Importantly, we have generated complementary mouse models that will enhance our understanding of the pathophysiological impact of eIF4B in DLBCL providing a rational basis for developing novel molecular targets.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Parkinson's disease is a growing burden for Veterans without a cure and usually without a known cause. For Veterans that have Parkinson's disease, we know the disease is usually widespread decades before diagnosis, including in the skin, and that catching the disease earlier could help us understand what causes the disease, how it spreads through the body, and how to find a cure. This project will map Parkinson's disease before diagnosis by using resources at the VA and a “big data” approach. The project will combine findings from biopsies and clinical care performed years before diagnosis with genetic studies in the Million Veteran Program. By combining these pieces of information, we hope to create a comprehensive description about how a Veteran's genetic background and symptoms relate to what's happening in his or her cells and tissues. By doing so we also hope to understand different types of Parkinson's disease. A better understanding of early Parkinson's disease should help in developing markers of disease and ultimately a cure.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Antibiotic resistant Gram-negative bacterial infections are associated with high rates of morbidity and mortality around the globe, disproportionally affecting the men and women actively serving in the armed forces, veterans, and patients in VA hospitals. Despite the health crisis associated with the rampant occurrence of antibiotic resistant bacterial isolates, only 24 new antibiotics have been approved since 1987. Most newer antibiotics are modifications or reformulations of existing drugs. None of the recently approved antibiotics have novel mechanisms of action. We have generated new chemical entities that bind to and inhibit a transcriptional factor conserved in bacteria but absent in humans. One of our novel antibiotics protects mice against a common and often life-threatening bacterial pathogen. Our proposal to synthesize improved transcriptional inhibitors with potent antimicrobial activity in animal models of infection will help with the rational design of the next generation of antibiotics.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Cardiac disease, is a common cause of death in PKD patients. Study of the mechanisms of cardiac hypertrophy, beyond hypertension, is an unmet need. Furthermore, testing of novel agents that block mTORC1/2 outputs e.g. 2nd, 3rd and 4th generation mTORC1/2 inhibitors and palmitate conjugated ASOs that vigorously penetrate heart muscle, is an unmet need in cardiac hypertrophy in general as well as PKD specifically. The proposal uses genetic and pharmacological interventions to explore unanswered questions of mTORC1/2 signaling in cardiac hypertrophy: 1) The effect of genetic knockout, ASO therapies and pharmacological inhibition of different components of the 4E-BP1/eIF4E pathway. 2) The effect of new 2nd, 3rd and 4th generation mTOR inhibitors, 3) The effect of pharmacological inhibition/activation of mTORC2 and mTORC2 outputs, Akt or PKCα. 4) The effect of mTORC1/2 inhibition on autophagic flux in the heart.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: WM S. MIDDLETON MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSP
PHR: The goal of this study is to i) determine the therapeutic efficacy of a simultaneous targeting of PLK1 and NOTCH, two biologically-informed novel melanoma targets, for the management of metastatic and drug- resistant melanoma, and ii) identify novel signaling mechanisms associated with their biological responses, using human-relevant melanoma mouse models. This pre-clinical study is expected to provide mechanistic insights and rationale for clinical testing of a new combination of drugs to obtain superior response against melanoma. Our proposed research is relevant and significant to the Veterans because melanoma is the fifth most diagnosed malignancy among Veterans, and the fact that the US military has been engaged, in missions all over the world, many US military personnel, who are deployed to high ultraviolet (UV) climates in tropical and subtropical zones are potentially at a higher risk for melanoma.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Opioid use disorder (OUD) has reached an epidemic level in the United States. After combat deployment, 15% of veterans use opioids compared to 4% of the general population. Opioid dependence is a chronic and relapsing disease and is characterized by compulsive drug seeking and use. Higher daily opioid dose use for analgesic effect may lead to opioid dependence. The proposal will examine new mechanisms of glia-neuron interaction, helping develop strategies aimed at therapeutic interventions of opioid withdrawal for both the general population and veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: WM S. MIDDLETON MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSP
PHR: Diabetes is a costly and complex chronic illness and a serious public health problem, responsible for a host of complications that significantly decrease healthy lifespan. The Veteran population has a significantly increased prevalence of diabetes as compared to the general population, making diabetes a critical problem in Veterans’ health. The underlying issue in diabetes is the failure of the pancreas cells to release enough of the hormone, insulin, into the bloodstream to properly control blood sugar levels. The aims of this proposal are to characterize emerging cellular targets to promote pancreatic cell health and proper insulin release, ultimately improving the care and treatment of diabetic Veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The proposed studies will investigate the role of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) and its ligand, HB-EGF in mediation of acute and chronic kidney injury. The studies will investigate role and mechanism of EGFR activation in renal pericytes and resident fibroblasts in response to acute kidney injury. In addition, the studies will investigate renal macrophage-fibroblasts interactions. The studies will also investigate the role of macrophage HB-EGF expression to mediate renal epithelial repair and regeneration following acute kidney injury. In addition, the studies will investigate the potential role of macrophage HB-EGF to activate the ErbB4 receptor to prevent development of subsequent tubulointerstitial fibrosis. Therefore, these studies will provide new and important insights into mechanisms of kidney injury and repair.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The mortality rate for acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) remains unacceptably high (~40%), particularly in light of the COVID-19 pandemic (ARDS is the leading cause of death among COVID patients). There are no FDA-approved treatments for ARDS. Overwhelming data demonstrate that ARDS patient outcomes are significantly worse among the elderly population, however, we do not yet understand the mechanisms that account for this age-associated predisposition. The proposed studies seek to better understand what “goes awry” in aging, and propose that specifically targeting defective mechanisms in aging may be the key to improving outcomes for elderly ARDS patients.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: End stage kidney disease is a major cause of morbidity and mortality for Veterans. One of the hallmarks of end stage kidney disease is tubulointerstitial fibrosis, characterized by abnormal accumulation of extracellular matrix along injured tubules leading to the loss of functioning kidneys. The goal of this VA Merit renewal is to understand the mechanisms that underlie the modulation of matrix turnover in injured kidneys to devise more effective therapies to prevent tubulointerstitial fibrosis and in turn loss of kidney function. We will focus on the receptor tyrosine kinase RON and its target TGF-β receptor II (TβRII). We show that: 1) RON contributes to kidney injury and fibrosis by promoting TGF-β secretion and by phosphorylating TβRII on tyrosine residues thus potentiating TβRII-mediated pro-inflammatory and pro-fibrotic signaling; and 2) inhibition of RON decreases TβRII tyrosine phosphorylation, TGF-β-mediated signaling, inflammation, and collagen production. Thus, RON-induced activation of TβRII represents a novel mechanism to selectively enhance TGF-β-mediated kidney injury.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection takes a toll on the life and health of thousands of Veterans because the currently available antiviral drugs are woefully inadequate. The Institute of Medicine estimates an annualized healthcare cost savings of $1-4 billion if CMV infection could be prevented. A CMV vaccine that effectively prevents infection is unlikely to be realized in the next decade. Thousands of Veterans already have CMV within them that has re-activated from dormancy to produce disease. This motivates a search for alternative ways of blocking CMV infection. Our research goal is to deactivate CMV before it starts replicating. By studying how CMV activates its gene expression program for replication, we aim to identify vital targets susceptible to precision-guided pharmacologic agents that effectively neutralize the virus. We will also discover previously unknown mechanisms of gene expression control that is broadly relevant to other viruses and many human diseases.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The CDC estimates more than 30 million Americans have chronic kidney disease (CKD), with a disproportionate burden on U.S. Veterans (prevalence a third higher than the general population), and we have no sustainable therapeutic strategies to prevent or reverse CKD. Acute kidney injury (AKI), despite initial renal recovery, is a major risk factor for CKD. The proximal tubule (PT) is the primary target in AKI due to its high susceptibility to ischemia and DNA-damaging nephrotoxins such as chemotherapeutic agents. Mitochondrial fatty acid b-oxidation (FAO) is the primary source of ATP production in PT cells, but in the setting of injury cells undergo metabolic reprograming, with reduced FAO and limited compensation by anerobic glycolysis. This proposal will address a current gap in the field by investigating the mechanisms mediating transcriptional regulation of FA utilization in the PT cells post-DNA damage. Therefore, the studies we propose are highly significant and clinically relevant to the Department of Veterans Affairs.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative Osteoarthritis (OA) is a leading cause of chronic pain and disability in our Veterans who develop OA at significantly younger ages and in higher numbers than non-Veterans. There are no disease modifying anti- osteoarthritis drugs (DMOAD) or treatments. This proposal will determine if vagal nerve stimulation delivered for 10 minutes a day will improve pain or prevent progression in two preclinical models of post-traumatic OA.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Several human neurodegenerative conditions are associated with abnormal protein depositions in brain neurons leading to cell death. Searching for suppressors of proteotoxicity, we have identified mitochondrial energetic metabolism and the NAD+ biosynthetic salvage pathway as excellent targets. The goal of this application is to test the unconventional hypothesis that four NAD+ biosynthetic enzymes possess additional functions as cytoprotective chaperones in the context of proteotoxic stress in human neurons. We believe the proposed studies are germane to the important mission of the VA. Understanding the fundamental mechanisms that offer protection against proteotoxicity is crucial for comprehending the etiology of age-related neurodegenerative diseases, prevalent in the Veterans and their families, and a prerequisite to devise therapeutic interventions aiming to neuroprotection, the ultimate goal of our project.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a major problem in the veteran population and no treatments have yet been proven to improve long-term recovery. The object of this application is to test our hypothesis that endothelium- targeted deletion of the miR-15a/16-1 cluster attenuates BBB disruption and subsequent pathological cascades after TBI, thereby contributing to increased BBB stabilization, reduced neuronal/white matter loss, and improved long-term neurological outcomes in traumatic brain injury. The successful implementation of this proposal will eventually lead us to develop novel microRNA-based drugs for the effective treatment of traumatic brain injury.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA NORTH TEXAS HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Melanoma is an important cause of morbidity and mortality in the U.S. and among military veterans. Immune treatments have prolonged survival of many patients with metastatic melanoma, but resistance to this modality remains high. We discovered: (1) novel pathway (DC-HIL/SD4) that suppresses T-cell immunity; (2) soluble form of DC- HIL that binds to syndecan-4 (SD4) on endothelial cells leading to angiogenesis while inhibiting extravasation of T cells; and (3) precise DC-HIL ligand in SD-4 that is a rare highly-sulfated 8-oligosaccharide (rHS), whose infusion into melanoma-bearing mice reduced tumor growth and expression of angiogenic factors within the tumor. Our proposal will: delineate consequences of DC-HIL and rHS interaction on immunosuppression vs. angiogenesis in melanoma; develop rHS-targeted treatment for melanoma; and characterize expression of rHS during melanoma progression and metastasis.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative Lung cancer is a devastating disease that disproportionally affects veterans due to chemical exposure during the war and high smoking rate. Lung squamous carcinoma (LUSC) is particularly difficult to treat as there are no personalized cancer medicines available currently. We, and others, have discovered that a complex of molecules, called mTORC2, are hyperactive in the above subtypes of lung cancer, representing a novel therapeutic target. Our overall goal of this project is (1) to gain a rigorous understanding of the contribution of mTORC2 to LUSC, and (2) to further investigate if targeting mLST8 or RICTOR, two critical components of the mTORC2, can be used to selectively inhibit mTORC2 and enhance antitumor immunity for treatment of LUSC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The human brain is composed of a remarkable diversity of cell types and classes, and at present, we have limited knowledge about the distinct contributions of each cell type and class to normal brain function. Furthermore, brain disorders are generally regarded as the consequence of cell type and circuit dysfunction, but the dearth of well-validated molecular genetic tools available to directly explore this relationship in large primate brains has constrained progress, especially for translational research. Our proposal aims to remedy this by engineering novel AAV capsids to allow enhanced neuronal transduction of primate brain, developing a suite of optimized AAV vectors for more precise cell type and cell class-selective delivery of transgenes, and testing if virus-mediated restoration of sodium channel function in forebrain inhibitory neurons can correct the devastating neurological deficits of Dravet syndrome.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: SOUTH TEXAS VETERANS HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Cancer is one of the top threats to the health of veterans. Recently developed tumor immunotherapies, including tumor vaccines have greatly improved the survival of cancer patients. However, only a small percentage of treated cancer patients experience long-lasting benefits from current tumor immunotherapies partially due to the lack of knowledge how our immune system responds to these therapies. Our project is focused on a subset of tumor-targeting immune cells, namely tumor-specific stem-like CD8 T lymphocytes. These immune cells have been established as the key to mediate the response of tumor vaccine. Based on our recent findings that these immune cells bear a unique migration pattern, we will test whether we can specifically targeting these immune cells to boost the efficacy of tumor vaccine as well as local irradiation- released endogenous tumor antigen.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer death among US Veterans despite recent advances in therapy. The National Lung Screening Trial has successfully demonstrated the efficacy of lung cancer screening in reducing lung cancer mortality. Lung cancer screening programs at VA medical centers are being implemented. We anticipate an increase in the rate of early-stage diagnoses. This research will develop a systematic approach to identify and integrate signatures from genetic, tumor microenvironment, and clinical computed tomography images to distinguish between aggressive and indolent early-stage lung cancer. The study will utilize the National Lung Screening Trial data and validate signatures from publicly available data sets. Predicting tumor behavior will improve personalized patient therapy for lung cancer.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: 8. Project Narrative The inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD) affect over 50,000 Veterans in the United States, cause significant morbidity and pose a significant financial burden to our VA healthcare system. Here, we use unique chronic mouse models of IBD and B cell function to investigate the role of beta7 integrins (targeted by FDA-approved drugs, e.g. vedolizumab) on B cell migration, localization, IgA production and control of the microbiota during experimental IBD. We believe that achieving an understanding of the cells and molecules that exert control over the microbiota might directly translate to human IBD and lead to the discovery of new ways to treat or even prevent IBD in genetically-susceptible individuals.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: SOUTH TEXAS VETERANS HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: The incidence of chronic kidney disease is increasing as our population ages and in correlation with rising obesity rates. The VA population has a higher prevalence of diabetic kidney disease than the general population, much of it as a complication of obesity. We recently found that insulin levels may contribute to tubular injury in the kidney during obesity. Our proposal seeks to understand the role of a critical protein in the kidney, AMPK, in mediating the effect of insulin and whether insulin regulates AMPK via effect on an enzyme that regulates hydrogen sulfide production. The insights gained from these studies will have a major impact on our understanding of obesity in progressive kidney disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Hospitalization for HF is the 2nd most common cause of cardiovascular hospitalization among Veterans. Patients who are hospitalized for HF often have significant deficits in strength, mobility and balance that can lead to inability to maintain functional independence. Veterans hospitalized for HF often have a high treatment workload, which leads to difficulty coping with stressors and [limits their motivation to participate in physical rehabilitation. Therefore, helping Veterans to expand their capacity to cope is important.] The COACH-HF intervention pairs Capacity Coaching with physical rehabilitation to augment Veterans’ capacity to cope with their high treatment workload - including the rehabilitation intervention. This research will [modify the proposed COACH-HF intervention] with stakeholder engagement, then evaluate feasibility, acceptability, [and improvement in rehabilitation adherence from Capacity Coaching] in a pilot study of 25 Veterans. This knowledge will be applied to a finalized COACH-HF protocol that will be tested in a larger study.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Alzheimer’s disease, the most frequent aging-associated dementia, predominantly affects individuals age 65 or older. After age 65, the likelihood of developing Alzheimer’s disease doubles every 5 years. Approximately half of American Veterans are age 65 years or older, making them vulnerable to developing Alzheimer’s disease. Further, head injuries, including traumatic brain injuries experienced by Veterans during their military service, puts individuals at elevated risk of dementia. The burden placed on American Veterans afflicted by Alzheimer’s disease is incalculable, as the disease causes progressive memory loss that erodes their independence and ultimately leads to death. Here we propose to use models to examine functional and molecular aspects of brain changes that occur in Alzheimer’s disease and to identify new neuroprotective strategies. This may lead to potential therapeutic interventions for the benefit of all those affected by Alzheimer’s disease including Veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: W G HEFNER VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative Regardless of family history, site of onset, and sequence of symptoms and progression, all Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) patients lose muscle function as central nervous system cells stop working and eventually die. This proposal will perform comprehensive analyses on 1000s of individual cells from dozens of central nervous system tissues donated by veterans with ALS. The results will provide an unprecedented depth of information on stresses experienced at the cellular level and how this stress relates to the health of the tissue. Data derived from this project will unveil numerous new directions of research to better understand ALS disease processes with the goal of developing effective therapies.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: SOUTH TEXAS VETERANS HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Project Narrative Candida-associated denture stomatitis (CADS) is one of the most common oral diseases among our aging veterans, seriously affecting their nutrition, speech, appearance, and quality of life. Previously described animal models for CADS are not well-established and do not recapitulate infections as seen in humans. This project will optimize a novel CADS rat model using computer aided design/manufacturing (CAD/CAM) technology, special UME6 overexpressing Candida strains and immunocompetent animals. We will further validate the rat CADS model to test the feasibility of treating CADS with a novel cell binding antifungal drug release system. This proposal represents a major breakthrough in CADS research and provides an easy and reproducible system for testing anticandidal drugs/devices and studying the pathogenesis of oral Candida infections.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES A. HALEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a major health issue for both military and civilian populations. Currently, there are no drugs available to treat TBI. While TBI severity ranges from mild to severe, moderate TBI is clinically most relevant, and If not treated immediately the secondary injury in these patients could spread quickly and may lead to long-term consequences including cognitive and memory loss. Hence, there is a genuine need to discover new therapeutic agents for moderate TBI. This proposal is based on the discovery of a novel target of TBI, CCL20, a chemokine protein that plays a critical role in increasing inflammation in acute TBI and memory loss. Our proposed studies focus on evaluating the long-term effects and mechanism of actions of the combinatorial anti-inflammatory and stem cell therapy for moderate TBI, which involves nanoparticle driven anti-chemokine therapy to reduce acute inflammation followed by stem cell therapy to remodel neurogenesis of parenchymal cells in the injured brain.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Pancreatic adenocarcinoma is a significant health burden with poor survival, especially among Blacks. To improve survival, we must identify individuals at high risk for further targeted screening, as universal screening is unfeasible. Current prediction tools to identify these individuals are inadequate as they were developed in mostly Whites or lack genetic data from a trans-ancestry population. This proposal will use population-level data to accurately identify cases of pancreatic adenocarcinoma, improve risk prediction by incorporating genetics with clinical factors in the Veterans Affairs electronic health record-linked biobank, and identify genetic risk factors in diverse, underrepresented populations to improve future risk prediction. This new knowledge will not only make early detection of pancreatic adenocarcinoma possible in the multiethnic population of Veterans, but also understand and ultimately bridge the disparities seen in Blacks.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Heart failure is a very common disease of the aging population with the highest incidence and prevalence in the age group above 65, which is also the largest Veteran population group. Ischemic heart disease and myocardial infarction (MI) are the primary cause or a major contributor in 2/3rds of all cases of heart failure in Veterans. Infiltration of inflammatory macrophages has been implicated in adverse remodeling of the heart muscle leading to post-MI heart failure. We and others have identified macrophage lysosome function as a key determinant of the pro-inflammatory response. In this proposal, we will explore the role of mitophagy pathways in macrophages as a determinant of cardiac myocyte homeostasis and evaluate translational approaches to stimulate mitophagy in cardiac myocytes to prevent development of post-MI cardiomyopathy.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Alcohol-related liver disease affects several million people in the United States and is the most important cause of liver cirrhosis among Veterans. Results from this innovative study will benefit Veterans health by increasing our understanding of the role that specific gut bacteria play in the progression of alcohol-related liver disease. We will also identify innovative intervention strategies to prevent or ameliorate these diseases in Veterans. Our novel findings can easily be translated into Veteran patients suffering from alcohol abuse and liver disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This VA Merit Review research will help understand how one liver cell type called hepatic stellate cell (HSC), promotes liver tumor development under alcohol drinking and Western diet consumption, the conditions which are prevalent among veteran patients. Our research has identified a lipid molecule produced by HSC as a novel driver for liver tumor development via a newly revealed tumor promotion pathway. Proposed research will pin-point a subset of HSC responsible for this pathway and test if its intervention reduces liver tumor development in a mouse model and in mice bearing human liver cancer. Findings from these studies will help develop a new therapeutic approach for liver cancer which continues to plague veteran patients.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The Department of Veteran Affairs is the single largest health care system in the world to provide comprehensive lifelong care after spinal cord injury (SCI). Most SCI patients experience bone health decline, which involves not only a decrease in the amount of bone but changes to the structure, vascularity, and chemical environment. As a result, patients are predisposed to fractures, anemia, and infections after SCI. Current bone imaging techniques, such as those that use x-rays, are limited in their capability to evaluate changes to bone health. In this project, we propose to optimize novel quantitative magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) techniques to comprehensively assess bone. We validate these techniques in an animal model to show how much bone recovery can be expected by restoring movement and loading after SCI, with and without sympathetic inhibition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The “brain-eating amoeba” Naegleria fowleri causes a deadly disease that lacks safe and reliable treatment. To identify new leads for therapeutic development, this proposal will reveal mechanisms responsible for assembling and organizing the mitotic spindle, a cellular structure essential for cell division and thus disease progression. By identifying proteins and processes that are required to assemble a functional spindle, this proposal will provide training in super-resolution microscopy and high throughput sequencing and identify new avenues to develop therapies for combating the devastating infection caused by Naegleria.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Dry eye (DE) is a complex disease that manifests with multiple symptoms and signs, affects 1 in 5 veterans, causes significant morbidity, and impacts quality of life. Given the heterogeneous nature of DE, it is necessary to understand mechanisms and contributors to the different disease sub-types in order to optimize treatments. This research focuses on the contribution of bioactive lipid mediators in meibum and tears and their relationship to ocular surface inflammation and clinical manifestations of meibomian gland dysfunction and DE.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Veterans of war are more prone to be affected by depression, chronic fatigue and anxiety. Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is common among former soldiers who have experienced traumatic battlefield combat experiences, such as witnessing suffering and death. Although there are several factors that predict the severity of symptoms and recovery, PTSD is undoubtedly a widespread condition among soldiers. Research suggests that there is a specific link between PTSD and cocaine abuse and that patient treatment should approach both disorders in order to be successful. This proposal focuses on characterizing the molecular mechanisms involved in the effects of cocaine in the cardiovascular system. This will help inform patient care and facilitate the development of novel therapeutic treatments for cocaine-induced cardiovascular toxicities for veterans in particular, among whom cocaine abuse is more prevalent.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE During development, neural circuits self-assemble to form the connectivity patterns governing all brain functions. This proposal seeks to elucidate conserved cellular strategies that underly neural circuit formation in the intact brain. Thus, this work will provide key mechanistic insight into an important neurodevelopmental process, which will be crucial for creating therapeutic strategies to regenerate circuits following ageing, disease, or injury.

PHR: Project Narrative The ability to functionally characterize all human kinases, understand potential mechanisms leading to drug resistance in cancer therapy and identify new compounds targeting them for degradation is severely hampered by technological limitations to interrogate all expressed human kinases in a single assay. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many studies now firmly support the idea that diversity makes teams and organizations stronger. Moreover, in order for taxpayer money to be equitably utilized there should be equal opportunities for individuals from every type of background to engage in research supported by taxpayer money and for their communities to benefit from such research. Here, we propose to provide educational and personal development activities to encourage individuals from diverse backgrounds to enter academia. We propose to create a new form of mentoring ecosystem to support their inclusiveness and promote their involvement and success within scientific and academic communities. The goal of this program is quite simply to train graduate students for successful careers to diversify the biomedical research workforce and to be active future leaders with skills that will enable them to further promote diversity, equity, inclusion and accessibility.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Stroke is a major cause of disability in the US and among our Veterans. High blood pressure and diabetes, which occurs in 37% and 25% of our Veterans, respectively, are two major diseases that increase the risk of having a stroke. There are NO approved treatments because we do not know the underlying mechanisms that contribute to poor brain repair and functional recovery after stroke in these diseases. Most research has been conducted in males and we do not know the disease process in females. We will use disease models that are common in stroke patients and determine the mechanisms contributing to post stroke functional and cognitive recovery in both sexes. Since a high percentage of Veterans suffer from diabetes and stroke and female Veterans are rapidly increasing, this project is highly relevant to the mission of Veterans Affairs.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA WESTERN NEW YORK HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Ischemic heart disease continues to be the leading cause of mortality and morbidly in the United States, impacting the lives of millions of Veterans each year. This project seeks to identify novel therapeutic approaches and targets to simulate heart muscle regeneration, including those that would not require the administration of stem cell populations. This would enhance the treatment of Veterans with a wide spectrum of cardiac disease including heart failure and myocardial infarction.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: We have an established research program that focuses on understanding the pathogenesis of intestinal inflammation, mucosal immunity and formulating treatment strategies for intestinal inflammatory diseases. We have made seminal observations on alterations in peptide transporters during intestinal inflammation and utilized peptide transporters to deliver anti-inflammatory molecules to treat intestinal inflammation and colitis associated cancer. Impact on Veterans Health care: Over one million adults in the US, including members of the VA population, suffer from IBD, and about 50,000 new cases are diagnosed each year (according to the Crohn’s and Colitis Foundation of America. The VA IBD patients have a much higher rate of colorectal cancer compared to the general population (2.9% vs. 0.1%; from National Center for Health Statistics data). Thus, attaining an understanding of the etiology of IBD and the relevant pathological mechanisms are major aims of research seeking to develop effective future treatments will directly benefit the veteran population.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Mutations in the most evolutionarily conserved regions of the human genome have been shown to be strong risk factors for many developmental anomalies in humans. In this proposal, I will leverage whole-genome sequencing data from an unprecedented trio cohort ascertained for intrauterine fetal death, one of the most extreme developmental disorders, to discover mutationally intolerant loci in the human genome, define functional features that are predictive of these loci, and evaluate these predictors against a continuum of severe developmental disorders. This work will establish a statistical framework for disease association capable of integrating evidence from all variation classes weighted by metrics of evolutionary constraint, and will yield new insights into the roles that mutationally intolerant loci play in the etiologies of fetal loss and other severe developmental anomalies.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: LOUIS STOKES CLEVELAND VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Infection with HCV is particularly prevalent in the veteran population. Roughly 80% of veterans are at sufficient risk as to qualify for screening, and approximately 10% are infected. Infection with HCV constitutes the most common cause of chronic hepatitis in the United States. Many infected patients develop cirrhosis, end stage liver disease, and liver cancer. Liver cancer, and geriatric age are developing issues expected to peak in 2030, though screening and treatment of liver cancer is only modestly effective. Because of these issues, and because Natural Killer (NK) cells are capable of controlling cancer, investigation of the role of NK cells in control of HCV associated hepatocellular carcinoma is needed to guide new screening, monitoring, and treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sarcopenic obesity is strongly associated with a decline in physical function and less independence in older adults. As such, there is immense value in determining strategies to mitigate sarcopenic obesity to improve the quality of life in older adults. The proposed study will pave the way for novel mechanistic insights and the discovery of new therapeutics for healthspan during aging with obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transgender and gender-diverse (TGD) youth are at higher risk of disordered eating behaviors in comparison to cisgender youth and engage in disordered eating behaviors (DEB) for unique factors related to their gender dysphoria, yet there are no specific measures tailored to this population. This Career Development Award will implement community-engaged research methods to improve recruitment of subpopulations of TGD youth who have historically been excluded from research and then develop and evaluate a culturally specific DEB measure using a high degree of TGD youth input. This proposal will advance the clinical practice for a highly stigmatized population by developing a measure that will inform interventions for specific behaviors, attitudes, and cognitions that contribute to DEB in TGD youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cytokines are powerful modulators of the immune system, but cytokine therapies have had limited clinical success due to off-target side effects. To circumvent these limitations, this research proposes to engineer a platform technology that delivers these protein drugs where they are needed in multiple different immune- mediated diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative NK cells are a type of lymphocyte with a specialized capacity to kill cancer cells through engagement of activating receptors. Memory-like NK cells develop after a brief cytokine stimulation resulting in an increased ability to kill leukemia, and when transferred into patients have an excellent safety profile; however, clinical responses in difficult-to-treat acute myeloid leukemia patients are not durable. The goal of this application is to understand how leukemia resists and evades memory-like NK cells with the goal of improving clinical outcomes to NK cell therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The pathogenic bacterium Staphylococcus aureus can evade effective clearance by host cells or antibiotics by adopting a heterogeneous mixture of states during infection that balance growth and tolerance. Since this represents a significant hurdle to curative treatment, understanding cell-to-cell heterogeneity in responses to these challenges would not only help identify the drivers of this variation, but also reveal fundamental insights into how these responses are regulated. In this proposal, I will capture the responses of individual S. aureus cells to the antibiotic vancomycin and to the complex environment within human cells to understand what determines the outcome of these interactions, helping to overcome this inherent variation and allow eradication of this resilient pathogen from infection sites.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Our lab primarily focuses on central nervous system (CNS) cell signaling that leads to neuronal death in Parkinson's disease (PD) and Alzheimer's disease (AD) and demyelination in multiple sclerosis (MS). We will try to suppress neurotoxic signaling pathways and/or boost neuroprotective signaling pathways in different animal models of neurodegenerative diseases by nontoxic drugs in order to achieve neuroprotection and functional recovery. 1

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is an age-related disease with genetic and environmental risk factors that is significantly affected by smoking. AMD has two outcomes, wet AMD or dry AMD; and while there are treatments for the former, none are available for the latter. Developing novel treatment strategies, is therefore essential to reduce the incidence and progression of AMD and improve quality of life for veterans with AMD. The goal of our research is to study mechanisms underlying AMD in cell- and animal- based experiments and develop novel diagnostic and treatment strategies to reduce the damage produced by the disease or help repair the tissues affected. Our long-term goal is to translate our treatment strategies from animal models to our veterans, which makes this research highly relevant to the VA mission.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The loss of muscle mass and function associated with obesity is known as “sarcopenic obesity”. This condition is very common in the elderly and is over-represented in the veteran population, reducing functionality and quality of life, and increasing mortality. We have generated exciting preliminary data suggesting that the hormone ghrelin and its receptor GHSR-1a may play a role in the development of “sarcopenic obesity”. This proposal will determine their effects and mechanisms of action in this setting. The results generated by these studies are expected to help us develop new treatments for this condition; thereby improving quality of life by allowing veterans to stay home longer, decreasing the need for hospitalizations and reducing the cost of healthcare.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: This research is highly relevant to the healthcare of veterans, who comprise an aging population with elevated incidence of traumatic brain injury (TBI). Both age and TBI increase the risk of AD, PD, and other neurodegenerative diseases. By seeking basic principles that govern protein aggregation across many neuropathies, we hope to gain insights and develop novel interventions (e.g., drugs) that apply to diverse neurological pathologies including “orphan diseases” that are too rare or underfunded to attract substantial research effort aimed at their prevention or cure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Life-threatening vascular toxicities reduce long-term quality of life in cancer patients after treatment and although this phenomenon has long been observed in the clinic, the mechanisms that cause this to occur remain unclear. We propose to investigate the mechanisms behind vascular toxicities by modulating the apoptotic machinery in cells within the vasculature and identify the contributions of each vascular cell type in response to various chemotherapies and radiation therapy. Our studies will ultimately lead to improved therapeutic strategies that will reduce vascular toxicity and improve health outcomes in cancer patients.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: This proposal addresses a significant healthcare issue that affects Veterans, military personnel, and their families disproportionately to the general population. Here, work from Dr. Casey’s research program is focused on the investigation of alcoholic and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (AFLD and NAFLD, respectively). Both AFLD and NAFLD represent a major clinical challenge in the VA, since there are no current, effective therapeutic interventions, and progression of liver injury can result in liver transplantation, or death. Work from our lab aims to provide a better understanding of AFLD and NAFLD progression and to increase opportunities for the development of novel treatment paradigms for the management of chronic liver diseases.
