IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: WM S. MIDDLETON MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSP
PHR: Over 29 million Americans suffer from diabetes, including 25% of Veterans seeking VA healthcare. Diabetes is defined by the failure of pancreatic β-cells to release sufficient insulin into the bloodstream to properly control blood sugar. These studies will provide new insights into the mechanisms by which β-cells depend on signals from neighboring α-cells, and explore the concept that simultaneously targeting α- and β-cells for diabetes therapy may be significantly more effective at stimulating insulin secretion than current therapies that only target β-cells. This work may lead to new therapeutic approaches to restore insulin secretion in patients with diabetes and related metabolic diseases.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bladder cancer is the fourth most prevalent cancer among Veterans. Carcinoma in situ (CIS) of the bladder is a pre-invasive lesion caused by carcinogens in tobacco smoke, occupational exposures to hazardous chemicals, and chemical/biologic warfare. CIS has a high rate of recurrence and progression to invasion and metastasis. CIS is a major diagnostic challenge and up to 40% of CIS are missed by standard cystoscopy. Current approved cystoscopy technologies have significant shortcomings, particularly high false positive rates. We aim to leverage artificial intelligence to augment enhanced cystoscopy imaging technologies to improve real-time cystoscopic detection and characterization of CIS. We propose three specific aims: 1) to develop an annotated multimodal cystoscopy imaging dataset for CIS of the bladder; 2) to develop and train deep learning algorithms for detection of CIS of the bladder; and 3) to augment detection of CIS of the bladder using deep learning algorithms in clinical settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE There are significant gaps in our understanding of TB transmission dynamics among youth living in rural areas of East Africa. This proposal will use social and spatial network analysis to identify where, and from whom, children and adolescents acquire TB in rural Uganda. These foundational data will inform novel youth-specific interventions that are needed to expand TB control beyond the home to the community.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA NORTHERN CALIFORNIA HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: My research interest focuses on molecular mechanisms on hormone regulation and function in the pathogenesis of neurodegenerative and cardiovascular disease, two major health burdens for our Veterans. We seek to determine the fundamental molecular signals of insulin and adrenergic hormones that regulate cellular function and understand the dysregulation of molecular pathways that contributes to disease development in animal models. The overall goal is to identify novel molecular targets and strategies for prevention and intervention of diseases. Specifically, our current VA merit review award is to delineate the mechanisms underlying the novel signaling induced by cardiac beta1-adrenergic receptor in development of heart failure. These investigations will provide novel molecular insights to facilitate further studies and to translate into therapeutic strategies for patient care, thus improving the Veterans' health and reduce health care cost.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to veterans’ health because, understanding the mechanism by which spermine oxidase (SMOX) causes neuronal damage and dysfunction in Multiple Sclerosis (MS), will facilitate the development of novel therapeutic strategies for preventing vision loss in MS patients. Our studies will impact field of MS research by providing new and significant information on mechanisms to preserve optic nerve integrity and visual function. Our findings will be relevant to the mission of the VA and will be broadly interesting to researchers studying molecular mechanisms of neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES J PETERS VA  MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a deadly neurodegenerative disease with higher incidence in U.S. Veterans and is considered to be a service-connected condition. Understanding the biological basis of ALS remains a major challenge. Whereas the original focus of ALS research was concentrated on the degenerating motor neurons, distinct yet overlapping pathology in different cells types have been reported in ALS patients. The proposed research will use state-of–the-art approaches to study ALS in different brain cell types from the autopsied brains of U.S. Veterans.

PHR: NARRATIVE Brain vascular disease causes and augments dementia in a very large number of Veterans, but the molecular origins of vascular pathology are unclear. PHR: Project Narrative My major research focus is to understand the fundamental mechanisms of gene regulation and function in the development of cardiovascular disease, a major health burden for our veterans. Our overarching goals are to translate the findings into identification of novel molecular targets and strategies for prevention and intervention of cardiovascular disease. With the ongoing collaboration with physician scientists and basic scientists at the Birmingham VA medical center and UAB, our ongoing investigations will not only elucidate the precise molecular and cellular mechanisms governing vascular smooth muscle cell reprograming in the pathogenesis of vascular disease and aging; but also provide novel molecular insights facilitating further studies to translate these findings into therapeutic strategies for patient care, so as to improve the veterans’ health, life span and quality of life, and reduce health care costs.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA WESTERN NEW YORK HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Eye injuries leading to compromised or lost vision are among the signature injuries sustained by our Veterans and deployed soldiers engaged in the recent conflicts in Iraq and Afghanistan (OEF, OIF). Currently, about 170,000 Veterans are legally blind, and nearly 1.5 million have some kind of visual deficit that is battle-related. Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is another signature injury of those conflicts; a significant percentage of TBI patients suffer visual deficits, nearly a third of which are blast-induced. Our goal is to understand the molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying such vision loss, and to find practical pharmacological interventions to prevent or retard the progression of those visual deficits. In addition, we’re investigating a form of Retinitis Pigmentosa (RP), about which very little is known, initially in an effort to understand the causes of the associated retinal degeneration at the molecular level and eventually to develop gene therapy approaches to ameliorate or prevent that degeneration and vision loss.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES J PETERS VA  MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative  An effective vaccine is requisite for controlling HIV infections in at-risk individuals. These include Veterans cared for in the Veterans Affairs health care system. Preventing HIV infection will save the VA countless millions of dollars otherwise needed for life-long care of HIV-infected Veterans. The proposed study will produce our lead vaccine under cGMP and optimize its delivery with the ensuing goal of a phase I vaccine trial in humans. Our vaccine is unique in that it is designed to elicit a focused antibody response against a specific site on the virus; antibodies against this domain of the virus Env protein have been shown to reduce virus infection. The strongest support for the efficacy of this approach comes from the RV144 clinical vaccine trial, the only human vaccine trial demonstrating partial but significant efficacy against HIV infection. The novel vaccine to be developed in the studies described in this application was designed to improve upon the RV144 vaccine.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The public health crisis known as “the opioid epidemic” continues to take the lives of veterans, not only due to the development of opioid use disorders and overdose but also from an enhanced risk of suicide. Improved treatments for opioid use disorders are desperately needed, but the neurophysiological adaptations that drive increased reinforcement in these individuals are not adequately understood. The proposed studies will combine electrophysiological, behavioral, molecular, and cell type-specific techniques in mice to elucidate the relationship between the modulatory peptide neurotensin, inhibitory synaptic transmission, and opioid self- administration. The mechanistic understanding gleaned from this work will help identify novel therapeutic targets to treat opioid use disorders in veterans and the general population.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The VA patient population is increasingly suffering from osteoporosis due to low bone mineral density (BMD). Current estimates indicate that 12 million people suffer from osteoporosis in the U.S., largely influenced by genetics. This project seeks to identify the gene and mechanism responsible for a locus influencing bone mineral density. Successful completion of this project will have the potential to lead to new therapies for the treatment of osteoporosis.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: NARRATIVE The human gut microbiota contributes to obesity, insulin resistance, and the subsequent development of type 2 diabetes (T2D). The primary role of the gut microbiome is to digest fiber, which results in short chain fatty acids (SCFAs). The body has a means to sense to SCFAs, via the receptors, FFA2 and FFA3. Here, we propose to investigate how SCFAs from fiber are sensed by the body, and also explore their individual roles in key tissues, in pancreatic β cells and enteroendocrine L cells. And finally, through translational studies, we will explore the applicability of these receptors to human physiology. In sum, this proposal will result in novel insight into FFA2 and FFA3 in the body, and its therapeutic value.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: More than 1.5 million veterans have diabetes and this is associated with a significant increase in complications and death. All diabetes is associated with an inability to compensate by increasing the number and function of the insulin producing β-cells in the pancreas to meet the metabolic needs. The precise molecular mechanisms regulating β-cell compensation are poorly understood. With compelling preliminary data that Tead1 regulates β-cell proliferation and function in mice, we propose to identify molecular mechanisms underlying the regulation of β-cell proliferation, differentiation and acquisition of mature function by Tead1 in human β-cells, using human iPS cell-derived β-cells, to translate the findings from mouse studies to diabetes therapy in humans. Successful completion of the proposed experiments will help close the knowledge gap in our understanding of the regulation of proliferation and differentiation in human β-cells and will help develop novel therapies that preserve and restore β-cells to cure diabetes.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: There are over 30,000 HIV-infected veterans in the VA and about 2000 at the Atlanta VA. Despite combined antiretroviral therapy (cART), approximately half of these individuals develop HIV associated neurocognitive disorders (HAND). Our screening of 41 consecutive HIV-infected veterans at the Atlanta VA indicates that 43% have HAND, which is consistent with most published data and suggests a substantial number with HAND within VHA. Fortunately, most of these veterans with HAND have mild memory impairments. However, eventually these mild deficits become severe, leading to dementia and death, even if they receive cART. So, it is vitally important to develop specific treatments for HAND and that is the purpose of the studies that are proposed. We plan to develop an animal model that will allow us to test potential treatments for HAND. If they work in the animal model they can be tested in humans with HAND.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Virus-induced diseases of the central nervous system (CNS) cause significant morbidity and mortality throughout the world. West Nile virus (WNV) is the leading cause of epidemic encephalitis in the US and probably the most common cause of all viral encephalitis during summer months in virus-targeted regions. The veteran population is highly enriched for those at most risk of WNV-induced neuroinvasive disease (90% male, 56% over age 60). This grant will determine the role of microglia in WNV-induced CNS pathogenesis and will evaluate microglia as potential therapeutic targets for WNV-induced CNS disease. Microglia are also critically important to many neurodegenerative and acquired CNS diseases (ALS, Parkinson's, Alzheimer's, traumatic brain and spinal cord injury) which have a major impact on veterans' health. In summary, this is a basic science grant, with translational components, that assesses the importance of microglia in WNV-induced CNS disease. Our findings will have direct relevance to a wide variety of neurological diseases affecting veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Mild traumatic brain injuries (mTBIs) resulting from explosive blasts are common in military personnel and can result in epilepsy and sensory dysfunction. Veterans with mTBI and a family history of epilepsy are significantly more likely to have post-mTBI seizures. We will investigate mechanisms by which mTBI and genetics interact to produce seizures, somatosensory dysfunction and thalamocortical network reorganization and we will determine if a therapeutically analogous form of neurostimulation targeted to a specific sensory network reduces symptoms.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Thrombotic microangiopathy is the most severe form of renal endothelial cell injury and occurs subsequent to a wide variety of diseases. Untreated, ongoing renal microvascular injury uniformly progresses to chronic kidney disease and end stage renal disease, of which both have increased prevalence amongst the Veteran population. The proposed project, uncovering the mechanisms of transcriptional regulation behind renal endothelial cell injury and its sensitivity to complement activation is a critical step in identifying novel targets for therapy as well as providing new insights into renal microvascular pathobiology.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: The proposed project will take an integrated genomic approach to understand how the risk and clinical severity of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is modified by the molecular machinery that regulates gene expression. The end-result will be an enhanced understanding of the novel genes, regulatory pathways and networks, and molecular mechanisms involved in the etiology and clinical severity of IPF. Given the demographics of IPF, veterans represent an at-risk population for IPF who will benefit significantly from an improved understanding of the pathogenesis of pulmonary fibrosis.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: HARRY S. TRUMAN MEMORIAL VA HOSPITAL
PHR: Healthy arteries stretch with each heart beat to receive blood pumped from the heart, then constrict to propel blood forward to target organs. With normal aging and in response to several diseases, arteries stiffen, which plays a key role in major cardiovascular diseases, including hypertension, heart failure, and stroke. Arteries contain smooth muscle cells (SMCs), which constrict and relax to regulate blood flow. It recently became recognized that SMCs themselves stiffen with aging. In addition, SMCs, like other cells throughout the body, become senescent, which leaves them unable to divide and makes them secrete proteins that promote inflammation. This proposal will examine how plasminogen activator inhibitor-1 (PAI-1), a protein that controls blood clotting and several cell functions, promotes stiffening and senescence of SMCs and arteries. The effects of drug inhibition of PAI-1 will also be examined, which we anticipate will lead to new approaches to prevent vascular stiffening and its serious adverse effects.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Available treatments for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), a very common and progressive fatal disease that afflicts many among the high proportion of VA patients who are smokers, provide no more than short-term benefits, if any. Nur77 is an orphan receptor in cell nuclei, whose incompletely known functions include anti-inflammatory actions and the ability to induce cell death by apoptosis in certain circumstances. The receptor is unusual in that it can be activated by ligand binding to either of two distinct sites. Based on our novel identification of the first known ligand for Nur77’s binding site 2 and finding that it stimulates Nur77’s anti- inflammatory activity more effectively than classic site 1 ligands while uniquely blocking Nur77-involved apoptosis, this project will determine the role of Nur77 in COPD and test the mechanisms and potential therapeutic value of novel Nur77 activation site 2 activators. Our anticipated finding will thus point toward a new avenue of effective COPD therapy.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative: The goal of this project is to validate a new, innovative treatment for neuropathic pain after spinal cord injury (SCI-NP) using a novel and highly clinically-relevant pig model. We will validate exciting findings from research in rodents which discovered a highly efficacious treatment for SCI-induced neuropathic pain in a large animal model with characteristics similar to human SCI. The new therapy is to deliver a gene construct encoding 6 copies of the NMDA antagonist serine-histrogranin and one copy of the opioid agonist endomorphin 1 (6SHG/EM1) via intraspinal delivery as reported in Jergova et al., 2017. We hypothesize that administration of 6SHG/EM1 after SCI will significantly reduce neuropathic pain. We will use quantitative sensory testing methods used in human medicine to evaluate neuropathic pain in pigs. The results of this study are a critical next step in translation of this new therapy to clinical trials, and ultimately to provide relief to Veterans who suffer from pain.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Narrative Infections with the bacterium Pseudomonas aeruginosa are a significant problem among our veterans, and they are difficult to treat due to its innate antibiotic resistance. Many VAMC patients are susceptible to opportunistic infections with P. aeruginosa due to complications with COPD, emphysema, chronic bronchitis and during treatment with respiratory ventilators. A key virulence factor of P. aeruginosa during pulmonary infection is the production of a capsule-like exopolysaccharide called alginate. A better understanding of the complex mechanisms involved in alginate biosynthesis and gene expression could lead to novel therapies. This work also includes the search for novel therapeutics to treat Pseudomonas pulmonary infections.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Tauopathies are a group of diseases in which accumulation of a brain protein called `Tau' damages brain cells. These diseases, which include Alzheimer's dementia and head injury, are collectively a major cause of chronic disability in veterans. There are currently no effective treatments for tauopathies; medications that prevent disease progression would have a significant and positive impact on veterans' health. To address this challenge, we identified chemicals that prevent deterioration of brain function in a novel animal model of tauopathy. One of these chemicals blocks a type of brain inflammation that is thought to mediate the progression of symptoms in tauopathy. In this project, we will define the precise cellular and molecular mechanisms by which this chemical prevents neurological problems the tauopathy model, and test whether this approach could be exploited to develop an anti-tauopathy medication.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: WM S. MIDDLETON MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSP
PHR: Stroke is a leading cause of death and disability in Veterans, with approximately 15,000 suffering from a stroke annually. Studying the molecular mechanisms of post-stroke brain damage and testing new drugs will help to minimize neurological dysfunction in the affected. The present project is to evaluate the functional significance of a microRNA called miR-21 in protecting post-stroke brain and providing better functional outcome. We will further test if miR-21 prevents stroke-induced gut dysbiosis and the resulting inflammation which might be a mechanism of its neuroprotective efficacy. The long-term goal is to develop miR-21 as a therapy to minimize post-stroke brain damage and improve outcomes for Veterans who have undergone a stroke.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Despite aggressive therapy, Veterans with squamous cell carcinoma of the upper aerodigestive tract (UADT) including cancer of the head and neck have a dismal prognosis. Although we have identified novel targets to treat this disease, the improvements in outcomes have been relatively modest. We propose to study how these cancers develop from pre-cancerous lesions. If we can prevent or slow the progression to cancer, we may be able to treat these patients before they develop cancer. The calcium-activated chloride channel TMEM16A/ ANO1 is frequently overexpressed in these cancers and contributes to tumor cell growth. TMEM16A appears to promote carcinogenesis by driving cellular signaling. Interestingly, we find that TMEM16A is increased in pre-cancerous lesions. This proposal outlines studies that will elucidate the fundamental biology of TMEM16A and how it promotes carcinogenesis. We will address the unmet need by implicating TMEM16A as a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of Veterans with cancer of the UADT, and head & neck in particular.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetes mellitus is a disorder of glucose homeostasis that affects nearly one in four Veterans and is a leading cause of blindness, kidney failure, and cardiovascular disease. Female veterans are at high risk for the development of diabetes, and the number of females receiving care in the VA is growing, suggesting that increased expenditures will be needed to care for this population. Pancreatic β cell dysfunction plays a central role in the pathogenesis of diabetes, yet current therapies do little to improve β cell health. The goal of this proposal is to define how impaired store operated calcium entry interacts with estrogen signaling to cause β cell de-differentiation and to test how alterations in these pathways contribute to diabetes development. The translational impact of this work will be the identification of novel pathways that can be targeted clinically as a means of preserving β cell function, survival, and identity in diabetes.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: Osteoporotic bone fractures cause dramatic morbidity and mortality that greatly impact the survival and quality of the life of our veterans along with steep socioeconomical burdens to their families and the VA Healthcare Systems. The current parathyroid hormone (PTH)-based therapies are suboptimal in rehabilitating osteoporotic skeletons due to its propensity to produce adverse side effects with higher doses. This new proposal aims to understand the molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying the skeletal actions and the adverse effects of the PTH therapy, establish the utility of a long-acting PTH analog (i.e., LAPTH) to enhance anabolic bone actions, and devise a novel regimen to build bone without unwanted side effects by concurrently targeting the PTH1R and CaSR receptors. Successful completion of this highly translational and clinically relevant project will generate an essential blueprint for designs of clinical trials using combined LAPTH and CaSR activators to more efficiently restore weakened bones in many VA patients afflicted with osteoporotic bone diseases of different etiologies.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: C. difficile infection is the most common hospital-acquired infection in the United States. Recent epidemiological data show an increasing incidence of C. difficile infection in Veterans, particularly non-hospital, community- acquired disease. This alarming trend illustrates the need for more knowledge about this potentially deadly bacterial infection. A better fundamental understanding of how C. difficile toxins target the human colon, and how the human cells and molecules respond to damage, is required for identifying new therapeutic and preventive opportunities. This proposal addresses this need by defining the molecular actions responsible for C. difficile infection. This innovative proposal will advance the science of gastrointestinal microbiology, and ultimately, the results are expected to reveal novel targets for treatments to ease the suffering of our nation’s Veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES J PETERS VA  MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Major depressive disorder (MDD) is a neuropsychiatric illness with considerable morbidity, mortality (including suicide), and personal and societal cost. Available treatments are ineffective for a large subset of MDD patients, and even among patients who respond to treatment only a fraction show long-time remission. Thus, there is the strong need to use novel approaches to advance our understanding of the biological bases of MDD in order to develop more efficacious treatments, which is an overarching goal of this application.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) encompasses both ulcerative colitis and Crohn’s disease, which are multifactorial, chronic conditions that result in numerous perturbations in the GI mucosa. The incidence of IBD has been steadily increasing, with over 1 million Americans currently affected. The economic impact of IBD was roughly $31.6 billion in 2014. Importantly, IBD represents a disease with one of the highest hospitalization rates among veterans (>100,000 hospitalizations from 1975-2006), with psychosocial conditions (PTSD, depression, anxiety) contributing to IBD severity. In addition, IBD-associated cancer is on the rise in some veteran populations. Currently, less than 50% of IBD patients respond to the current biological therapies, thus, a better understanding of IBD pathogenesis and the development of more effective therapies could significantly impact the veteran population.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: There are over 2.2 million women Veterans and 32% are enrolled to receive VA health care. Female Veterans of childbearing age are seeking care at VA facilities in record numbers. Frequent reproductive health diagnoses in VA include menstrual disorders, endometriosis and infertility, menopausal disorders, osteoporosis and ovarian cancers; conditions which rely on adequate control of steroid hormone production. This program of research will explore the role of recently discovered molecular pathways that control cell and tissue homeostasis in ovarian development, endocrine function, and pathology. This research will lead to new understanding of steroid secretion, fertility, and ultimately woman’s health. New knowledge that informs approaches to control ovarian function can translate into approaches that improve not only reproductive health, but overall health and longevity.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: Musculoskeletal disease affects millions of veterans and can result from service-related injuries as well as inflammatory disorders such as rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and postmenopausal osteoporosis. Factors produced by cells in the bone marrow play a causal role in driving bone loss (thereby increasing the risk of fracture) in these disorders, but the identify of these factors and how their production is orchestrated remain unclear. If we knew more about these factors, it would be possible to develop therapeutics that neutralize their activity and prevent bone loss. In the present study, we will test the hypothesis that a specific factor, progranulin, is an orchestrator of bone loss in RA and in estrogen deficiency-induced bone loss and is thus a potential therapeutic target. We will also investigate the mechanism by which progranulin negatively affects bone mass. Successful completion of these studies will increase our knowledge of the control of bone mass and will reveal new opportunities for treatments to prevent fractures.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: In the United States, over 300,000 cases of acute kidney injury (AKI) are diagnosed each year with high mortality and staggering medical expense. Veterans are highly susceptible to AKI as shown by the Austin Automation Center Patient Files. AKI is also a common complication among military casualties in battle-fields. Moreover, even if the AKI patients have survived the acute injury, maladaptive kidney repair after AKI may result in chronic kidney disease (CKD) that contributes significantly to cardiovascular disease and mortality in aging patients including veterans. In the general population, 15-20% of AKI cases progress to CKD within 24 months; however, AKI-CKD transition in veterans is markedly higher and faster, reaching 31.8% in 12 months (Heung et al. Am J Kidney Dis 2016, 67:742-52). By elucidating stress granules in AKI and post-AKI kidney repair, this application may lead to new strategies for the prevention and treatment of this devastating disease, contributing significantly to the improvement of veterans’ health.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The ability of the HIV to become silent and establish persistent latent reservoir is the major obstacle to cure from this virus. Because of the these latent reservoirs, discontinuation of antiretroviral treatment results in virus rebound within weeks, requiring the chronic, lifelong adherence to therapy. The number of people living with HIV infection in the United States is increasing every year, with the number of HIV-infected Veterans enrolled in VA Healthcare System reaching nearly 31,000 in 2019. The Center for Disease Control and Prevention estimates that 14% of the infected individuals are not aware of their infection, which leads to late diagnosis and increase in the size of latent reservoir. To reduce the number of Veterans living with HIV infection and the costs associated with lifelong antiviral treatment as well as therapy- related toxicities, continued research aiming at purging HIV latent reservoir is required.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Diabetic retinopathy (DR), that affects more than 40% of diabetics, is a leading cause of vision loss in middle aged adults. Although a class of new drugs (anti-vascular endothelial growth factor, VEGF) is effective in treatment of vision loss in DR patients, only 40% of patients respond well to these drugs. Thus, there is an unmet demand for the development of new drugs other than anti-VEGF drugs. The proposed research will advance our understanding of the role of specific immune cells of the retina, namely microglia and their secretion of different molecular factors that cause leakage of blood vessels and results in blindness. The studies will utilize novel genomic technology to identify these molecular mediators secreted by these cells. Perhaps, this study will lead to the development of new improved therapeutics in diabetics who respond poorly to the standard anti-VEGF drugs.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a complex neurological condition, and there are currently no FDA-approved treatments to directly treat cognitive deficits. The proposed study will delineate a mechanistic role of Neurogranin (Ng) in the pathophysiology of experimental TBI and use systemic delivery of retinoic acid and adeno-associated viral (AAV) vector-mediated overexpression to elucidate the therapeutic impact of increased Ng expression on restoring synaptic plasticity and functional outcomes after TBI. Successful completion of this study will further our understanding of molecular mechanisms of cognitive dysfunction after TBI.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Women are a vital part of the armed forces and veterans' community. The population of women veterans has risen and is projected to continue to rise. In the United States, one in seven women has or will develop breast cancer (BC). Therefore, we can anticipate that approximately 237,500 female veterans will be affected by BC in their lifetimes. The triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC), a sub-type of BC lacking estrogen, progesterone, and HER2 receptors, has a dismal prognosis. New insights into the disease and new therapeutic options thus must be developed. By revealing its mechanism of action, the proposed study aims to demonstrate CCN5 as a novel for TNBC. Our findings will directly inform the design and help interpret the results of potential clinical trials of CCN5-activation therapy in TNBC patients.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Cancer stem cells (CSCs) comprise a sub-set of cancer cells that are capable of self- regeneration, self-renewal, and de-differentiation. CSCs are felt to be responsible for the relapse of cancer patients that initially have a promising response to chemotherapy and targeted therapy. High dose acetaminophen (AAP) with delayed n-acetylcysteine (NAC) rescue has demonstrated promising evidence of anti-cancer activity in early phase clinical trials. However, the mechanism of anti-tumor activity of high dose AAP is incompletely understood. In this proposal, we outline preliminary data that high dose AAP acts as a novel anti-CSC drug and STAT3 modulator in human non-small cell lung cancer models. We outline a series of experiments to test the hypothesis that high dose AAP synergizes with chemotherapy and targeted therapy via a STAT3-dependant mechanism.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overarching mission of this project is to develop a Center entitled PRE-Clinical Interagency reSearch resourcE-Traumatic Brain Injury (PRECISE-TBI) with the mission of accelerating the development of therapies for TBI. PRECISE-TBI will achieve this mission by utilization of an enterprise approach to meet key objectives with targeted strategies and by leveraging previous collaborative efforts. The strategic missions of the Center are divided into five Cores and milestones will be achieved by activities of Core Directors and members. Leadership of PRECISE-TBI will be the Core Directors (Drs. C. Edward Dixon, Gene Gurkoff, Pamela VandeVord, Maryann Martone, Michelle LaPlaca, Neil Harris, Candace Floyd) and the Steering Committee Chair, Dr. Adam Ferguson. Leadership will interact with the Steering Committee and a Community Committee to set objectives, milestones, and deliverables.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: WM S. MIDDLETON MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSP
PHR: Anal cancer is caused mainly by sexually transmitted human papillomaviruses and has been increasing in incidence for many years—especially in adults living with HIV. In fact, people living with HIV have a 100x increased risk for anal cancer compared with HIV-negative patients. The VA cares for the largest population of patients living with HIV of any healthcare system in the United States, over 25,000 Veterans in 2019. One opportunity for preventing this deadly cancer in high-risk individuals lies in the effective treatment of precancerous lesions. The proposed research uses several novel preclinical models of anal cancer to examine the efficacy of targeted, topical therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with end-stage kidney disease (ESKD) suffer high rates of hospitalization and death. Opinion-based clinical practice guidelines recommend lowering serum phosphate in patients with ESKD, but no randomized clinical trial tested whether phosphate reduction improves or worsens outcomes. “HiLo” is a randomized pragmatic clinical trial that is testing the effects of higher versus lower serum phosphate targets on rates of mortality and hospitalization in 4000 patients with ESKD being treated with hemodialysis at >150 DaVita dialysis across the US.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: The current barrier to delivering optimal health care to patients with urinary stone disease (USD) is the lack of evidence supporting the efficacy of current guidelines for prevention of USD. This lack of evidence likely drives unwanted variability in how providers diagnose and treat USD. The proposed research has two main objectives: 1) determine which guideline recommendations are associated with better outcomes for USD in the Veterans Health Administration (VHA); and 2) identify current barriers to implementation of effective guidelines for USD in the VHA. The anticipated impact of the proposed work will be to define more clearly best practice management of USD and inform future quality improvement efforts to facilitate diffusion of best USD care practices in both the VA and civilian health care systems.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Antibiotic-resistant bacteria cause over 23,000 deaths annually in the US. The primary risk for this is antibiotic exposure. Up to half of all antibiotic use is unnecessary, much due to treating over-diagnosed urinary tract infection (UTI). Recent efforts to improve unnecessary antibiotic use focus on a highly trained physician ‘steward’ who reviews cases or restricts the use of specific antibiotics. A novel approach we defined in JAMA, diagnostic stewardship, aims to streamline test ordering, processing and reporting to make appropriate testing and interpretation easier for clinicians. Small-scale studies indicate this type of electronic medical record/laboratory intervention can significantly reduce antibiotic overuse without apparent harms and is easy to implement. This award will develop literature/expert based criteria for UTI diagnostic stewardship and tools that are acceptable to clinicians. Next, a proof-of-concept study in three VA healthcare systems will implement and measure impact on cultures and antibiotic use across acute-ambulatory-and long-term care.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: MICHAEL E DEBAKEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: ACEI/ARB therapy reduces cardiovascular events and progression to end-stage kidney disease in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) and albuminuria. We have shown that ACEI/ARB therapy is underused in veterans with CKD. This could be related to clinical inertia but could also be related to ACEI/ARB associated side effects which may not be well captured in structured VA datasets. The objectives of this proposal are to (a) identify reasons for suboptimal ACEI/ARB in CKD patients use using both structured data and provider text notes using novel informatics techniques (Aim 1) (b) understand patient and provider perspective on ACEI/ARB use in CKD and refine a communication aid targeting providers to improve ACEI/ARB use in CKD patients (Aim 2) and (c) pilot test an intervention (Aim 3) to improve ACEI/ARB use in veterans with CKD using the communication aid refined in Aim 2. Our results will identify strategies to improve ACEI/ARB use in high-risk veterans with CKD, who stand to derive the most benefit from this life saving therapy.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Every day, thousands of Veterans are treated urgently for unexpected problems. They present to acute outpatient settings such as the emergency department, urgent care clinics, and primary care offices for infectious and pain-related complaints, and in many cases, are treated with antibiotics and non-steroidal anti- inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). Unfortunately, 30% of these medications are inappropriately prescribed and may cause patient harm. Without a systematic process to give providers feedback on their prescribing, the opportunity to learn from experience and prevent future adverse events is lost. By placing the provider at the center of the design of a feedback system, this study seeks to develop a feedback system using potentially inappropriate antibiotic and NSAID prescribing as two primary opportunities to improve acute outpatient care delivery. This project will examine the performance of an automated system to enhance the quality and safety of medication prescribing for Veterans who seek acute care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neutrophils are critical first-responders of the innate immune system, yet aberrant or prolonged neutrophil activity causes tissue damage in a wide array of acute and chronic inflammatory diseases. This proposal aims to investigate the intracellular signaling pathways that guide neutrophil activation, and how these processes adapt during neutrophil development and inflammation. These studies are anticipated to identify new mechanisms to strategically modulate neutrophil function to impact disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Microglia, the innate immune cells of the brain, play a critical role in Alzheimer’s Disease pathophysiology by responding to amyloid-ß plaques through the induction of a unique transcriptional and functional phenotype. Our data suggests that the polycomb repressive complex 2 (PRC2), a known regulator of microglial transcriptional state, is required for the proper induction of this phenotype. In this proposal, I will address the mechanism through which PRC2 controls the microglial response to amyloid-ß plaques by characterizing its regulation of transcription as well as its role in microglial function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antibiotic resistant bacterial infections cause hundreds of thousands of deaths each year, while the lack of new antimicrobials poses a threat to modern medicine. The development of new drugs against Gram-negative bacteria, organisms that are responsible for most of the societal burden of resistant infections, is primarily hampered by the protective action of their cell envelope compartment. We propose to systematically investigate the interaction between resistance proteins and biochemical pathways that maintain the integrity of the cell envelope proteome, with the goal to evaluate whether targeting protein folding in the cell envelope could be exploited in future attempts to overcome antibiotic resistance.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 100,000 VA patients are diagnosed every year with carpal tunnel syndrome and 11,000 receive surgical carpal tunnel release to treat this common and disabling syndrome. Healthcare quality measures are used by policy makers, VA administrators, and other healthcare professionals to identify high and low performing facilities, measure the effects of quality improvement interventions, and for performance-based reimbursement. Currently, no feasible and valid measures of treatment quality exist for carpal tunnel syndrome. This project aims to develop and validate measures of carpal tunnel syndrome treatment quality so that all stakeholders, including Veterans, have valid measures to distinguish excellent from substandard care. With VA's increasing role as a purchaser of healthcare, as well as increasing interest in making between-system comparisons, VA needs quality measures that are rigorously evaluated for both VA-internal use and value-based purchasing of community care.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Sepsis is a common cause of hospitalization that is associated with long-term challenges in survivors, such as weakness, cognitive difficulties, and worsening of chronic medical problems. This study will help us understand why some hospitals and clinics have better long-term outcomes from sepsis. By identifying strategies used by top-performing sites, we will be able to share these “best practices” to improve survivorship from COVID-related and non-COVID- related sepsis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Despite intense and ongoing investigations, there are no established biomarkers to identify the optimal location, intensity, or parameters for emerging DBS device technologies. Here we will use a novel 16-contact directional lead in tandem with advanced stimulation and acquisition hardware to create detailed spatiotemporal maps of globus pallidus interna and subthalamic nucleus electrophysiology in patients with advanced Parkinson’s disease. Our vision is for this work to advance the design of future DBS systems that can stimulate and sense interactions between DBS and human brain circuits and inform clinical decision-making related to directional stimulation for Parkinson’s disease and other complex neurocognitive disorders.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Stroke is the leading cause of neurological disability in the veteran population and problems with arm movement are a major cause of loss of functional ability. Strokes affect a network of brain regions that control movement and restoring ability to move requires knowledge about how brain connections are changed. We propose studying the changes in connections between a few of these regions in people with and without a stroke. The goal is a method to improve movement by combining brain stimulation with practice of movement, a method that we will test, using some of the knowledge we will have gained by studying how brain connections affect movement before and after stroke.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is a major source of quality of life decline in Veterans. Sleep disruption in PTSD is very common and hyperarousal features of PTSD have a bidirectional relationship to sleep problems. Current treatment options have limited efficacy. Further, pharmacological treatments for poor sleep quality often deleteriously affect sleep architecture and may also be addictive. We will examine the efficacy of a non-invasive treatment option called transcutaneous vagal nerve stimulation (tVNS) to improve sleep architecture (aim 1), hyperarousal symptoms of PTSD (aim 2), and predictors of individual differences in response (e.g., mild TBI features) (aim 3). tVNS is promising because the vagus nerve affects brain structures that underlie core hyperarousal PTSD symptoms. Preliminary data in animals and humans suggest efficacy in reducing hyperarousal symptoms and increasing restorative sleep quality. Data gleaned from this investigation will substantially move this technology towards becoming a viable treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: In order to exert their protective effector functions during viral infections, T lymphocytes must migrate actively within the body to engage in physical contacts with their target cells. This project focuses on one major subpopulation of anti-viral T cells that are defined by high expression of a diagnostic surface molecule, CX3CR1, and were found to crawl within the lumen of small blood vessels in peripheral tissues. The goals of this project are to investigate the mechanisms of intravascular crawling of anti-viral CX3CR1-high T cells and to elucidate the immunological consequences of this unprecedented form of cellular immune surveillance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative Retention in care and viral suppression via antiretroviral therapy are critical for continuing progress toward global elimination of HIV. This proposal develops and evaluates data-driven clinical decision support tools that are designed to maximize retention and viral suppression by identifying patients who will benefit from proactive support and other interventions. The tools utilize data from electronic health records and are customized to low- and middle-income country settings; successful implementation will maximize patient engagement in care, further reduce HIV incidence, and enable continued progress toward worldwide elimination of HIV.

ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative While a great deal is known about how the transcriptional and signaling pathways that regulate the stem cell response to tissue regeneration, it is currently unknown whether stem cells integrate metabolic inputs into this process. Based on previous studies and my preliminary data, I propose that serine metabolism controls stem cell fate decisions during tissue regeneration. Successful completion of my aims will be of particular utility to promote wound repair and possibly enable dietary or metabolic interventions in the prevention and treatment of SCC in ways that do not impair normal regenerative processes.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Mild Traumatic Brain Injury (mTBI) is an important priority for the Veterans Administration which affects many veterans of the conflicts in Iraq and Afghanistan, and when it co-occurs with posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is associated with increased symptoms of post-concussion syndrome and suicidality, as well as worse health and cognitive outcomes. Currently there is no single effective treatment or rehabilitation for co-morbid mTBI and PTSD that addresses all the symptoms and the potential risk of progression of neurotrauma in these veterans. This project will look at a novel and newly available treatment for mTBI and PTSD called non-invasive Vagal Nerve Stimulation (nVNS) and how it affects brain and physiological responses to memory tasks and stress in veterans with mTBI and PTSD.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Interleukin-9 is a cytokine used by inflammatory cells to communicate with each other and target tissues during immune responses that range from allergic inflammation and inflammatory bowel disease to anti-tumor immunity. In this application, we are defining how IL-9 promotes inflammation from an allergic memory population, and examining the development of that IL-9-secreting T cell population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative: Stress exposure during pregnancy is common and disrupts neurodevelopment, increasing the risk of psychiatric disorders in the next generation. How stress is transmitted from peripheral changes in maternal microbes to the developing brain in utero is an open question, and maternal microbes are a tantalizing target for intervention. This interdisciplinary study will focus on this critical window to determine the ability of a tryptophan metabolizing microbe to prevent early inflammatory abnormalities in the developing brain which result in long term behavioral changes.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Kara Zivin, PhD, MS, MA serves as a productive Department of Veterans Affairs Health Services Researcher, consistently recognized nationally and internationally as a leader in behavioral health (BH) services research and policy. She demonstrates persistent dedication to improving care for Veterans with BH conditions. Her work aims to enhance clinical and functional outcomes through evaluation of intended and unintended consequences of policies and health system initiatives on overall access to, quality of, and costs of care for those with BH conditions, to mitigate BH provider burnout, and to address gaps and unmet needs for perinatal BH care. The proposed Research Career Scientist Award will support her continued research to promote care for Veterans, as well as an expanded role in service, mentorship, and training early career scientists in the next generation of VHA health services researchers and leaders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Elaborate strategies are used by bacteria to deliver toxic proteins into host cells to manipulate cell signaling and promote infection. Multifunctional-Autoprocessing Repeats-in-Toxins (MARTX) toxins simultaneously deliver two to five effectors into the same cell and thus have been called “cluster bombs”. This study will investigate how the multiple effectors can work in combination to promote infection by Vibrio cholerae, which causes cholera, and Vibrio vulnificus, which causes severe fatal sepsis and necrotizing fasciitis.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Nearly 25% of Veterans are estimated to be food insecure, experiencing limited access to nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecurity is associated with a wide range of poor health outcomes as well as higher healthcare costs and utilization. In 2017 the VA launched a national initiative to screen all Veterans in the VA for food insecurity and help connect them with resources. Little is known about variation in screening implementation across VA sites; how sites respond when a Veteran screens positive for food insecurity; or what VA practices following a positive screen best improve Veteran food security status, experiences of care, and health outcomes. This study will address these knowledge gaps by examining the scope of Veteran food insecurity in the VA, variation and site-level innovations in how the screener is being implemented, and Veteran experiences of screening and follow-up. Findings will help optimize screening and referral processes for connecting food insecure Veterans to relevant VA and community resources.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: EDITH NOURSE  ROGERS MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSPITAL
PHR: Community Living Centers (CLCs) provide care for over 40,000 vulnerable Veterans every year and serve as a safety net setting for many Veterans who cannot find care in non-VA nursing homes. This award will support Dr. Hartmann's research on measuring and improving the quality of CLC care, helping Veterans who live in CLCs have better outcomes. Dr. Hartmann's work to date with CLCs across the nation shows this is possible. CLCs that use techniques she developed have, for example, improved care and risen in their quality rankings. This award will expand this type of research, helping the VA system better provide high-quality Veteran care.

PHR: This career award focuses on partnered research about women Veterans’ health and health care as well as approaches to strengthening the healthcare system by supporting providers and staff. The current and planned research portfolio focuses on understanding women Veterans’ healthcare utilization and needs, and implementing flexible, patient-centered care models. Engaging stakeholders (e.g., leaders, staff, Veterans) in the care transformation process is central to the research. The career award enables continuing service to VA as well as mentoring and training early-stage and established investigators in designing, conducting, and disseminating high impact research that will result in improved quality of care for Veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Unhealthy alcohol use is common among Veterans and a significant risk factor for numerous negative health consequences, including chronic disease, injury, mortality, and suicide. It is also linked to increased financial and societal costs (e.g., higher healthcare utilization, criminal justice expenses). Due to these burdens, effective, evidence-based care for Veterans with unhealthy alcohol use was implemented in VA primary care settings. However, significant gaps in this care have been identified, indicating that a substantial proportion of Veterans in need of help are not receiving it. Improving the implementation of alcohol-related care in primary care settings has the potential to increase access to both preventive care (e.g., brief counseling interventions) and treatment (e.g., medications for alcohol use disorder), thereby significantly decreasing the harmful health and societal consequences associated with drinking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE  Drug-resistant strains of Mycobacterium tuberculosis present a critical challenge to world health, and new antibiotic targets must be identified to limit the toll of tuberculosis. This project will establish whether trans- translation can be targeted in M. tuberculosis and test the efficacy of lead compounds in vivo. New antibiotics are expected to be developed from the results of the proposed experiments.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: As an accomplished research health scientist and nurse, my research focuses on improving chronic disease management, including access to services, quality of care, and economic outcomes related to Veterans’ health and healthcare. Understanding the modifiable factors that improve health outcomes and healthcare continues to be highly relevant to the VA and to Veterans. My research contributions have positively impacted clinical practice, health care processes, and establishment of critical resources. I have contributed substantially to training the next generation of scientists. Most importantly, I have engaged patients and families in my research. A VA HSR&D Senior Research Career Scientist Award would enable me to enhance my research and scholarship, mentoring, service, and engagement contributions in addressing the potential for care coordination to improve Veterans’ health and healthcare across VA and community-based care.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Over the past 19 years, I have been conducting research in health services, epidemiology, and implementation science in VA. My primary area of research has been focused on prevention and management of infections in Veterans with spinal cord injury/disorder (SCI/D), who are at high risk for infections. Many of these infections are due to multidrug resistant organisms (MDROs); but little research had been conducted in this patient population, particularly in the VA which is the single largest source of care for persons with SCI/D in the U.S. Highlights of my research impacts include developing and disseminating a toolkit on prevention of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) colonization/infection for patients with SCI/D and educating clinicians about the modifiable risk factors of MDROs and impacts on morbidity and mortality in this population. This award will support my research in this area, collaborations, mentoring, and service activities.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Intimate partner violence (IPV) is a major public health concern with significant consequences. Veterans experience and perpetrate IPV at rates higher than their civilians counterparts. Although VHA currently recommends routine screening of IPV experiences among women Veterans, no guidelines or tools exist for IPV perpetration screening, and intervention development for IPV perpetration is in its infancy. In order to reduce rates of IPV and improve Veterans' health outcomes, effective and acceptable screening and treatment must exist. The goals of the proposed research are to validate a previously developed IPV perpetration screening instrument and to complete the necessary steps for developing an acceptable, safe, and feasible individual IPV perpetration intervention and manual for Veterans. Research proposed will provide the necessary groundwork for developing and implementing a comprehensive response to IPV and informing VHA policy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative While the rodent environmental enrichment model has been shown to be protective against various drugs of abuse, the developmental onset of this enrichment has not been elucidated nor have the effects of enrichment on cannabinoid drugs been investigated. The purpose of this study is to determine if the length of exposure to environmental enrichment during adolescence differentially alters brain density of the cannabinoid receptors (CB1R) or the rewarding effects of vaped delta-8 tetrahydrocannabinol, cannabidiol, and mixtures of these compounds. The results of the current proposal will be important in determining whether enrichment during development protects against the rewarding effects of popular vaped cannabinoids.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adeno-associated viruses (AAV) can be used as gene therapy vectors to deliver and express broadly neutralizing antibodies (bNAbs). One current setback is the host immune response to the vector and expressed bNAb that limits the protective efficacy of the bNAb. Here we use novel strategies to limit the host immune response against AAV-expressed bNAbs, allowing us to optimize expression and evaluate bNAb protective efficacy from SHIV challenges.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) signal variations linked with vigilance states, and the subcortical- cortical networks that underlie these fluctuations in vigilance, are being increasingly recognized as fMRI signals of interest both for neuroscience and in studying disease. The F99 phase of this proposal will look at characterizing the influence of vigilance in young healthy adults with an emphasis on subcortical arousal networks as well as initial application of our methods to older adults with mild cognitive impairment. Completion of the F99 phase will provide technical and professional training, in preparation for the transition to an aging focused K00 phase, where the candidate will extend her training to incorporate structural imaging to characterize the impact of structural degeneration on functional networks with respect to age-related cognitive decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to develop comprehensive, empirical, data-driven agent-based models for persons who inject drugs (PWID) using Chicago and San Francisco PWID populations, contrasting geographies for high and low hepatitis C incidence. The models would assist hepatitis C vaccine-trial sponsors in designing and evaluating clinical trials and enable policy makers to identify the most effective vaccine-based combination intervention strategies for elimination of hepatitis C that includes direct-acting antivirals and engagement in harm reduction such as medications for opioid use disorder and syringe service programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative: Due to the requirement of millions of cells for conventional proximity ligation-based methods, enhancer- promoter interaction data in sensory hair cells is not available, making it difficult to understand enhancer- mediated transcription regulation. We propose to establish a new method to interrogate enhancer-promoter interactions with a small number of cells utilizing the “cut-and-paste” transposition activity of Tn5 transposase, and then to use such method to profile enhancer-promoter interactions in sensory hair cells in the organ of Corti. The results from the proposed project will provide enriched information for us to understand the regulatory networks governing hair cell-specific gene expression and help us identify potential targets to stimulate hair cell regeneration.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Proper interaction of placental cells with the maternal immune system is required for induction of tolerance and a successful pregnancy, but this process goes awry in spontaneous preterm birth. We propose to characterize decidual natural killer (dNK) cell heterogeneity and function in both term and preterm birth. We will then apply these findings from primary dNK cells to induced pluripotent stem cells in order to establish a renewable resource for optimal study of these cells and their interactions with placental cells at the maternal-placental interface.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Messenger RNA (mRNA)-based vaccines have emerged as rapid and versatile candidates to quickly respond to virus pandemics such as coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). However, mRNA vaccines face key limitations, one of which is the inherent chemical instability of RNA. This project will facilitate the prediction and experimental validation of mRNA secondary structure and stabilities, which forms the basis for an efficient platform to design stable mRNA vaccine to fight against infectious diseases including COVID-19.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Brucella infections can cause debilitating disease with relapses of an undulating fever and lifelong complications even with antibiotic treatment; however, mechanisms underlying Brucella’s ability to cause chronic infection remain largely unknown. We have found B cells enhance susceptibility to Brucella by skewing CD4+ T cell responses, and in the proposed studies we will investigate the mechanisms by which B cells modulate CD4+ T cell responses to enhance susceptibility to Brucella infection. Collectively, our results will enhance our knowledge of the pathogenesis of chronic brucellosis and should also have implications for future rational design of Brucella vaccines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Activation of T cells by dendritic cells is essential for the initiation of adaptive immunity to pathogens. This proposal addresses a poorly understood aspect of this process, the mechanisms through which forces exerted by cytoskeletal elements coordinate signaling events at the cell-cell contact site. The knowledge gained from these studies will be important for optimizing vaccine development, and for modulating immune responses in patients with immunodeficiency and autoimmune disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungal pathogen that is the causative agent of cryptococcal meningitis, a severe HIV-associated infection of the central nervous system. In healthy individuals, C. neoformans establishes latent infections that reactivate and cause clinical symptoms upon immunosuppression. Insights gained from this study will improve our understanding of the host immune conditions required to control latent C. neoformans infection, and may lead to new therapeutic targets that prevent reactivation of latent infection and mitigate disease progression in HIV/AIDS patients with cryptococcal meningitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The lack of an objective PrEP adherence monitoring tool has led to inefficient counseling and poor supportive care. We recently developed a novel enzymatic assay that semi-quantitatively measures the concentration of TFV-DP by measuring inhibition of reverse transcriptase, which is the cellular target of oral PrEP drugs. In this proposal, we will optimize the REverSe TRanscrIptase Chain Termination (RESTRICT) assay to measure TFV- DP concentrations in PrEP clients, validate the assay to meet CLIA requirements, and conduct a feasibility and acceptability study among PrEP clients and providers.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement The burden of disease caused by trauma and injury in Lebanon and the Eastern Mediterranean Region is disproportionately high compared to other regions around the world. Yale University and the American University of Beirut seek to build upon their existing successful training and research collaborations to develop a new program to address the severe public health impact of trauma and injury by strengthening capacity at multiple levels of the trauma and injury research ecosystem. We propose a comprehensive program of theoretical and applied skill development; evidence-based policy development; and research and career development mentorship to enable a new cadre of researchers to launch successful career as independent trauma and injury investigators.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: We have discovered that: 1) Orexin peptides and receptors, typically considered to be involved with sleep-wake cycles and feeding behaviors, are also expressed in the cochlea, and 2) that ablation of the gene responsible for producing the Orexin peptides exacerbates noise-induced hearing loss. Approximately 30% of US adults report symptoms of insomnia, and while medications used to alleviate insomnia are meant to be used for a short time, many people continue taking insomnia medication for long periods. Because a relatively new insomnia medication silences the Orexin receptors, individuals using this drug long-term could be at previously unrecognized risk for cochlear dysfunction and general hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: 8. Public Health Relevance.  Social communications are critically dependent on the proper processing of social information. The social cues detected by the sensory systems can induce neuroendocrine responses that control multiple aspects of the nervous system and elicit innate behaviors. The proper function of these systems is crucial to the health and wellbeing of human beings. Malfunction of these sensory systems that result in the improper processing of sensory information can lead to deficit in cognitive function and psychiatric disorders. By investigating the neural circuitry that mediates social communications among animals, which has a direct influence on the endocrine control of reproductive and aggressive behaviors, we will be able to elucidate the functional logic of the circuit and provide insights into the brain mechanisms of processing sensory information, mediating social communications, and exerting endocrine control. This knowledge can be used for diagnostic and therapeutic applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Basement membranes are conserved, complex, and specialized extracellular matrices that underlie and surround tissues to support their structure and function. Aging tissues display changes in basement membrane structure, including thickening and collagen accumulation, that may promote the decline of tissue function over time (vision, hearing, stem cell renewal). The proposed work will develop a new animal model to rigorously determine the mechanisms and consequences of these changes, thus providing new insights into the pathology of aging tissue decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: Narrative E. chaffeensis is an obligately intracellular bacterium that replicates in mononuclear phagocytes by secreting moonlighting effectors that exploit evolutionarily conserved host cell signaling pathways for infection. This investigation will define a pathogen molecular mimicry strategy that promotes host cell survival and E. chaffeensis infection by hijacking the Notch signaling pathway. Defining the role of pathogen mimicry in host cell manipulation and the pathways involved will also provide potential new therapeutic targets for intracellular bacteria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The normal function of the immune system depends on the ability of white blood cells, or lymphocytes, to detect foreign pathogens and respond appropriately so that a pathogen is eliminated without damage to the host. This proposal is designed to expand understanding of the molecular machinery that is used by lymphocytes in this process, and uncover how the mutation or dysregulation of this machinery leads to inappropriate immune cell behavior or the growth of cancers of immune cells, including lymphomas. Our studies may reveal molecular targets for the development of new therapies designed to treat diseases that result from aberrant immune cell behavior including cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Peanut allergy is increasing in prevalence and poses a significant public health risk, as patients can develop life-threatening reactions to small exposures of peanut. Clinical trials of peanut oral immunotherapy, in which peanut allergic patients are given peanut to induce tolerance, induce lasting tolerance in only a subset of patients. Our project focuses on understanding how antibodies induced in these patients with tolerance have a unique ability to bind to the allergen to suppress allergic reactions and contribute to the development of long- lived tolerance after peanut oral immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE SWI/SNF plays critical roles in many cellular processes, from response to environmental stress, to differentiation and development. However, mis-regulation of this complex causes cancers. The goal of this proposal is to understand how environmental stress, specifically hypoxia which is present in tumors, mediates changes in compositional variation of SWI/SNF and uses different forms of SWI/SNF for gene expression during hypoxia. Given loss of SWI/SNF units result in many cancers that form solid tumors with hypoxic centers, our studies will help understand the underlying mechanisms of how SWI/SNF functions as a tumor suppressor.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS, UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF
PHR: Romantic relationship distress is a common impairment for Veterans screening positive for depression, posttraumatic stress disorder, or alcohol misuse in primary care. Relationship distress also serves as a prominent suicide risk factor. The Brief Relationship Checkup (BRC) is a three 30-minute session treatment that helps couples make concrete commitments to improve their relationships. We propose a pilot randomized controlled trial of BRC in 72 distressed couples (N=144 individuals) where at least one partner is a Veteran screening positive on a primary care mental health screen. Couples will be randomized to BRC or to three sessions of the Co-Located Collaborative Care model (CCC; the standard of care for primary care mental health). Couples will be re-assessed at post-treatment, 3-months, and 6-months. The results will provide the foundations for a larger trial by determining BRC’s efficacy in improving relationship-level and individual-level risk/protective factors for suicide. Finally, we will develop a fidelity codebook to operationalize BRC adherence and competence.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Veterans with mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI) and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) commonly experience cognitive impairments including attention and executive function deficits that interfere with their ability to engage in productive personal and social activities. Of the limited interventions available to address cognition, none rigorously train attention beyond strategy management. This study will evaluate an innovatively combined strategy training known as Goal Management Training plus computerized attention training in Veterans with mTBI/PTSD. Preliminary testing suggests an effectiveness in improving problem solving, attention and functional tasks in a small number of Veterans. Considering these promising results, cost effectiveness, and the demand for access to care from Veterans living in rural areas, a Randomized Controlled Trial will determine and compare the effects of this treatment, administered either in-person or via telehealth, on executive function, attention, other aspects of cognition and real life functional tasks.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: EDITH NOURSE  ROGERS MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSPITAL
PHR: As Veterans age, chronic health conditions increase their risk of functional limitations, or difficulty completing day-to-day activities independently. Older adults with functional limitations are more likely to be hospitalized or admitted to long-term care facilities. Maintaining independence at home and in the community is a high priority for many older Veterans. However, there are few existing interventions focused on helping older Veterans maintain their independence, and they rarely target multiple areas of functioning (e.g. physical, cognitive, and social). The goal of this CDA-2 proposal is to support the physical, cognitive, and social functioning of older Veterans by developing a program based on behavioral activation, an evidence-based brief psychosocial intervention that helps individuals increase their engagement in activities aligned with their values (i.e. what matters most to them). This project will simultaneously support the career development of the candidate into an independent VA researcher focused on promoting functional independence in older Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Mycobacterium tuberculosis is the causative agent of Tuberculosis and is responsible for approximately 1.6 million deaths annually. A key component of this disease is the bacterium’s ability to persist for long periods of time in the human host. This proposed research will characterize mechanisms involved in nutrient acquisition by the bacterium during infection. These studies will allow us to better understand lipid import and lipid utilization by M. tuberculosis while determining if these pathways have therapeutic potential.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Few suicide prevention interventions are customized for people with serious mental illnesses, and despite VA/DoD recommendations to include peers in suicide prevention, there are limited, if any, peer-delivered suicide prevention interventions. This CDA-2 proposal will refine and pilot SUicide Prevention by Peers Offering Recovery Tactics (SUPPORT), a novel peer-delivered, suicide-focused, integrated recovery program that is specifically tailored for Veterans with serious mental illnesses to enhance functional and social recovery following a suicidal crisis. The project will examine feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary efficacy of SUPPORT in improving recovery, reducing severity of suicidal ideation, and enhancing Veteran functioning. This CDA-2 is the first step toward developing a vital program of research within VHA focused on enhancing functioning, participation in society, and suicide related care for Veterans with serious mental illness.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Fatigue affects up to 92% of individuals post-stroke and contributes to decreased physical and cognitive function leading to a reduced quality of life. There are currently no effective evidence-based treatments for post-stroke fatigue partially due to the unknown pathophysiology of fatigue. While the exact mechanisms/pathophysiology of post-stroke fatigue are unknown, changes in the structure and function of the nervous system likely play prominent roles. Since post-stroke fatigue originates within the central nervous system, neuromodulatory therapies may prove to be an effective treatment option. This proposal will explore the utility of using repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation to treat post-stroke fatigue and attempt to further elucidate the biomarkers and pathophysiology of post-stroke fatigue. Fatigue is not unique to stroke and is common a common sequela of many neurological conditions. Gaining a better understanding of post-stroke fatigue may provide greater insights into fatigue in other conditions, e.g. traumatic brain injury, multiple sclerosis, and Long-COVID.
