IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: MICHAEL E DEBAKEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Obesity affects more veterans than the general population and even more so among veterans using VA health care services. Moreover, the number of obese older veterans has markedly increased because of both the increase in the aging of the veteran population and the percentage of older veterans who are obese. In older veterans, obesity aggravates the age-related decline in physical function resulting in frailty that leads to loss of independence in activities of daily living. However, lifestyle therapy resulting in weight loss in obese older adults remains controversial because of concerns about harmful effects of weight loss on muscle and bone mass in this population. Metformin, a drug widely used to treat diabetes, could slow the aging process and improve health span, the part of a person’s life during which they are in good health. It is possible that the addition of metformin to lifestyle therapy will reverse frailty and preserve muscle and bone mass in obese older veterans, thereby prevent their loss of independence and decrease need for admission to a VA nursing home care.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a highly prevalent condition that is significantly greater in Veterans and leads to significant morbidity and mortality. Natural killer cells (NKs) are innate cells that are highly cytotoxic in COPD subjects and are suspected of driving parenchymal destruction. Regulatory T cells (Tregs) are able to suppress NK cytotoxicity, but lung Tregs are decreased in COPD. This project will investigate whether targeted transfer of autologous Tregs could be used to control lung NKs in COPD. The study will use human circulating Tregs and autologous lung NKs from subjects with no airway obstruction (NAO) and subjects with COPD to determine the potential of Treg therapy in vitro. A murine model of cigarette smoke exposure will also be used to model Treg therapy in an in vivo setting. Successful completion of this study will determine whether functional regulation of NKs by Tregs in the lungs might be beneficial to prevent or treat COPD resulting from cigarette smoke.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: More than 2.7 million military personnel have been deployed to southwest Asia (Iraq, Afghanistan, and neighboring countries) since 2001. During deployment, these veterans were exposed to levels of airborne pollution that were approximately 10 times higher than pollution levels in the US. Afterwards, deployed veterans reported more chronic lung symptoms (coughing, wheezing, or shortness of breath) than were reported by non-deployed veterans. Airborne pollution is known to cause and worsen lung symptoms and lung diseases. How airborne pollution causes lung problems is not fully understood. Our results may identify a new mechanism—the human microbiota—whereby airborne pollution leads to lung disease. Discovery of a new lung disease mechanism may identify veterans at high risk of developing lung disease after deployment. Our work may also suggest new targets for treatment or prevention of lung disease in this high-risk veteran population.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Contrast-associated acute kidney injury occurs frequently after coronary angiography and percutaneous coronary intervention in patients with heart failure with reduced left ventricular ejection fraction. Although, periprocedural administration of intravenous fluid, has been the standard intervention to prevent contrast- associated acute kidney injury, patients with congestive heart failure may not tolerate intravenous fluid. Unfortunately, there is no alternative therapy to prevent contrast-associated acute kidney injury in patients with congestive heart failure. This project will determine the effect of remote ischemic preconditioning on contrast-associated acute kidney injury in Veterans with congestive heart failure with reduced left ventricular ejection fraction who cannot tolerate intravenous fluid. It will characterize the effect of remote ischemic preconditioning on functional capacity and major adverse kidney events in Veterans with congestive heart failure with reduced left ventricular ejection fraction undergoing coronary angiography.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research is relevant to women veterans and public health because it focuses on developing novel and alternative strategies to treat or prevent metabolic dysfunction and associated comorbidities in postmenopausal women with prediabetes and early diabetes. Once such strategies have been established, there is the potential for momentous progress in prevention or treatment of estrogen deficiency-induced metabolic dysfunction, ultimately decreasing cardiovascular disease risk factors. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the VA's Research mission that refers to improving Veterans' health and well-being by reducing disease and disability.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative Parkinson disease (PD) is a progressive neurological disorder strongly linked to advancing age that ultimately results in decline in mobility and thinking. Approximately 100,000 veterans with PD receive care from the Department of Veterans Affairs, and this number is expected to grow in the coming decades. Inflammation in the brain may play an important role in the progression of these impairments, but we lack easily accessible tools to identify and measure inflammation in the brain. The main goal of this project is to use a novel brain imaging test, diffusion basis spectrum imaging (DBSI), to examine brain inflammation in veterans with PD. We will compare DBSI to other measures of inflammation and use it to predict clinical progression in PD. This will help us understand the role of inflammation in PD and lead to development of a readily-available, noninvasive brain imaging measure of inflammation, which will be useful in clinical trials of agents that target the immune system.

PHR: The goal of this study is to validate a 3D Short TR Adiabatic Inversion Recovery UTE (STAIR-UTE) sequence for myelin imaging, and a 3D UTE quantitative susceptibility mapping (3D UTE-QSM) technique for iron imaging, then characterize longitudinal changes in demyelination and iron accumulation in brains of mice subjected to open-field low-intensity blast (LIB), and finally apply the 3D STAIR-UTE and UTE-QSM techniques to evaluate cross-sectional changes in demyelination and iron accumulation in two groups of Veterans, one group with history of mTBI and the other group with no history of mTBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Mutations in the pfcrt gene has been linked to resistance to antimalarial drugs, and at least 61 PfCRT protein isoforms have been found across the globe. This project quantitatively compares the function of novel PfCRT isoforms associated with a new form of drug resistance (“MDRdcp”), using yeast and malarial parasite model systems, and will solve structures of these proteins via cryoEM and synthetically evolved nanobody (SEN) methods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nearly every stage of T cell development critically depend on Tcf-1, a multifunctional protein, expressed in distinct isoforms, that regulates of the chromatin landscape, conformation and gene expression. The proposed studies will address the hypothesis that Tcf-1 participates in distinct regulatory protein complexes and cooperates with Lef-1 and HEB to dynamically modulate chromatin conformation and expression profiles that guide thymocyte development. Determining how these regulators co-ordinate to establish epigenetic and chromatin conformation states will provide a novel and comprehensive molecular model of how DP thymocyte programs are modulated.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Peripheral nerve damage can result from traumatic injury to the limbs or as a secondary outcome following cervical spinal cord injury. Functional recovery from nerve damage is often poor, resulting in impaired motor function, sensory loss, and pain; the prognosis for recovery further deteriorates with time. We propose novel quantitative ultrasound (US)- and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)-based strategies to provide a quantitative, high-resolution assessment of nerve quality that will guide and improve a surgeon’s diagnosis of the extent of nerve damage, his/her decision on what type of surgery to perform, and his/her ability to predict and monitor the success of the nerve repair.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Neuropsychological and neurobehavioral outcomes following traumatic brain injury (TBI) are considerably heterogeneous, and despite there being an “expected” recovery, there are many individual factors that can influence post-injury outcome. While extensive effort has been placed on delineating the impact of various environmental contributions on TBI outcome, the literature pertaining to neurobiological underpinnings of poor clinical outcome in the aftermath of TBI is comparatively limited. The proposed study seeks to use data from the Million Veteran Program—a very large genetic and clinical database—to examine the influence of genetic factors and neuroendocrine abnormalities on cognitive and psychiatric outcomes in Veterans with TBI histories. Determining the extent to which underlying neurobiological factors contribute to post-injury outcome would offer critical information to healthcare providers and patients, and findings could have profound relevance to treatments that are currently being developed and optimized using a personalized approach to medicine.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: WM S. MIDDLETON MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSP
PHR: Smoking is a common and treatable addictive disorder that remains the leading preventable cause of death and disease. Veterans smoke at a higher rate than the US population, and therefore suffer disproportionately from smoking–related illness. The VA offers evidence-based cessation treatments for smokers who are willing to quit. However, at any point in time, the great majority of smokers are not willing to make a quit attempt. Thus, most Veterans who smoke leave VA healthcare visits without treatment for their tobacco dependence. This project will generate new knowledge about the effectiveness of an intervention designed to enhance smoking treatment use and long-term abstinence in smokers initially unwilling to quit. Results from this project will offer the VA a blueprint for motivating more smokers to use evidence-based treatment and quit successfully, thereby decreasing smoking-related death and disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The proposed research will help us to enhance and tailor our treatments for women Veterans with alcohol misuse, with and without co-occurring PTSD. The importance of understanding, and identifying strategies to reduce, stress-induced drinking among women Veterans is critical because (1) stressful events and acute trauma create a more influential pathway to alcohol misuse among women compared to men, and (2) women experience serious health and interpersonal consequences due to alcohol misuse, over a shorter period of time, compared to men (a phenomenon referred to as “telescoping”). Given that the rates of problem drinking are quickly rising among women, research that informs the enhancement and personalization care for this population is needed. Ultimately, interventions for women’s alcohol misuse and other behavioral health conditions may be personalized by directly teaching emotion regulation and directly targeting fluctuations in, or low levels of, progesterone.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD) and insomnia are more prevalent in Veterans than in the general community. Furthermore, insomnia is comorbid in 36-91% of individuals with AUD and jeopardizes recovery by increasing their risk for relapse and complicating their clinical profile. The VA/DoD guidelines recommend four medications for the treatment of AUD. Among them, topiramate (TOP) has demonstrated promise in improving abstinence and decreasing heavy drinking but without any clinical improvement in sleep continuity. The recommended treatment for insomnia is Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I), and it has shown efficacy in improving insomnia but with minimal benefit in improving abstinence. The proposed study will evaluate whether augmenting TOP with CBT-I bolsters recovery in AUD, by improving abstinence and decreasing insomnia. If this strategy shows good clinical results and the findings are replicated in a multi-center trial then the combination of TOP with CBT-I should be considered a standard component of the initial management of AUD with insomnia.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Patients with advanced cirrhosis with high portal vein pressure frequently develop complications such as internal bleeding and retention of fluid in the abdomen. Development of these complications marks a change in a patient’s status from “compensated” (no symptoms) cirrhosis to “decompensated” (symptomatic) cirrhosis, and is associated with a high risk of death. Several retrospective studies suggesting that statins, a class of medications usually used to lower cholesterol and reduce heart disease, may also reduce death in patients with cirrhosis. However, many primary care providers will not use these medications in patients with liver disease due to fears of liver toxicity. This study will prospectively test in a randomized, placebo-controlled trial whether or not simvastatin, a commonly used and inexpensive statin drug, lowers the risk of cirrhosis complications and death, and is safe to use, in patients with compensated cirrhosis.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: The overall goal of this project is to recruit and characterize a VA-based cohort of veterans with post-9/11 southwest Asia, Afghanistan, and Djibouti (SWAAD) deployment with and without deployment-related lung disease (DLD) and to identify deployment and clinical characteristics associated with DLD, to find cellular markers of activation and inflammation in those with DLD, and to monitor longitudinal respiratory health outcomes in those with and without post-9/11 SWAAD DLD. Southwest Asia, Afghanistan, and Djibouti deployment is associated with exposure to burn pits and desert dust that have been linked to post-9/11 deployment-related asthma and small airways lung diseases (e.g. bronchiolitis). Deployment and clinical characteristics that predict DLD, and long-term prognosis of DLD is unknown. Given the influx of post-9/11 deployers leaving the military and enrolling in VA healthcare, VA-based clinical/translational research programs are needed to identify clinical biomarkers of DLD and to monitor long-term lung function and health outcomes.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is the 4th most common diagnosis amongst US veterans costing VHS, $18 billion annually. Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the single largest killer for these patients. At present time we do not have an effective strategy capable of reducing the exceedingly high CVD mortality in those with CKD. We propose a novel therapy for this deadly disease and plan to conduct the first human proof-of-efficacy study to examine whether it can impact the parameters of CVD in Veterans with CKD. Based on multiple in vivo, in vitro, and population-based data, as well as our recently concluded validatory animal and human feasibility studies, we believe that [hydroxychloroquine (HCQ)], a traditional, safe, and cheap anti-inflammatory drug will have significant benefits relevant to CVD in CKD. The outcome of this study has the potential to provide an entirely new line of therapy for the treatment of CVD, not only in CKD, but in general population as well, and in the process, may establish a new field of research to attack CVD.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: MICHAEL E DEBAKEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Opioid use disorder (OUD) is a major problem, including high death risk, in returning Veterans. Although therapies are available (methadone and buprenorphine), often these don’t work especially because patients discontinue treatment. Our understanding of the brain mechanisms of OUD and OUD treatment success is lacking, which precludes the development of improved therapies. We propose to use brain imaging and limited genetics to understand the brain circuitry behind OUD and treatment outcomes, and to create a machine learning algorithm to predict which patients entering the clinic are most and less likely to succeed. This knowledge would allow for improved personalized therapy and for optimal resource allocation.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Veterans returned from the 1990-1991 Persian Gulf War (GW1) often suffer from headaches, muscle and joint pain, depression and other debilitating physical symptoms. These multi-symptom illnesses are described as Gulf War Veterans’ Illness (GWVI). However, the current pharmacological treatment options for GWVI related chronic headaches, and body muscle and joint pain conditions (GWVI-HAP), and depression are quite limited. Repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) offers an effective non-invasive treatment option for pain, headache and depression. The treatment, which usually is non-painful and requires no anesthesia, utilizes a coil to non-invasively create a small current in a specific brain region for pain relief. Our preliminary studies indicate the treatment can be potentially beneficial for both GWVI-HAP and depression. This multi-center clinical trial study aims to further: 1) valid the long-term efficacy of the treatment for GWVI-HAP and depression; and 2) assess site specificity of the treatment in patients with or without severe form of depression. !

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Among veterans both the rate of incidence and the rate of mortality due to lung cancer are twice higher than the entire population, making this an urgent unmet clinical problem in veterans. This is partly due to higher smoking rates among veterans that can result in higher incidence of NSCLC in this population. Immune checkpoint blockade strategy has emerged as an effective therapy for lung cancer with long lasting clinical benefits. However, only 20% of patients respond to these agents and currently available only to patients whose tumors express checkpoint ligand, PDL1. Therefore, there is an urgent need of alternatives for a large fraction of patients including those that are PDL1 negative. We recently identified a protein called CADM1, expressed on lung tumor cells and render them susceptible to natural killer (NK) cells of the host immune system. This project will investigate the role of this protein in lung tumor immune surveillance, its mechanism of action and will develop a novel NK cell based immune therapy for lung cancer.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Approximately 30 million adults have diabetes (DM) in the United States and DM confers a risk for cardiovascular disease (CVD). Between 2013-2017 multiple clinical trials of newer agents (SGLT2 or GLP1RA) were conducted versus placebo that demonstrated cardiovascular or renal benefit with a pronounced effect among those with pre-existing CVD. There is less data available among those without CVD. Evidence on the advantages and risks of these newer agents relative to other commonly used medications remains unknown because data from real world cohorts is methodologically limited for many reasons. We propose to conduct a large longitudinal national study using administrative, clinical and laboratory data to quantify the relative risks and benefits of newer antidiabetic agents among Veterans. We will include cardiovascular and renal outcomes and risks of amputations and fractures in 2 distinct cohorts, those with and without CVD. This study would be the largest methodologically rigorous evaluation of newer antidiabetic medications in Veterans to date.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Nearly a quarter of Veterans have diabetes, which costs the VA $1.5 billion annually. Diabetes is a risk factor for cognitive impairment and dementia, and in turn, cognitive impairment is a risk factor for poorer medication adherence and hypoglycemic events. Current diagnostic approaches to identify Veterans at risk for future cognitive decline are often invasive, expensive, or not sensitive enough to capture early cognitive changes prior to objective impairment. The proposed study will use innovative neuropsychological methods (process scores) to detect subtle cognitive changes and inefficiencies in Veterans with diabetes to improve prediction of future cognitive decline. Furthermore, this work will identify a potential biomarker (cerebral blood flow) for cognitive inefficiency in diabetes. Early identification of Veterans at risk for future cognitive impairment, including Alzheimer’s disease, will provide opportunities for earlier behavioral, lifestyle, and pharmaceutical interventions as well as improved clinical decision-making. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Varicella-zoster virus (VZV), a human alphaherpesvirus, establishes lifelong latent neuronal infection in the ganglia of the majority of humans worldwide, reactivating in one-third to cause shingles, debilitating pain and stroke. Recently, we identified a novel, protein-coding spliced viral transcript, VZV Latency Transcript (VLT), which together with VZV gene 63 (ORF63) are the sole virus transcripts present in latently VZV-infected human ganglia. Our application will determine the role of both viral genes in the establishment, maintenance and egress from VZV latency in human neurons ex vivo, in situ and in vitro.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to Veteran health because it focuses on innovative ways to electronically measure frailty and multimorbidity in older Veterans with multiple myeloma using data from the integrated national VA health system. This work will lead to tools for VA oncologists to identify age-related vulnerabilities that can inform decision making regarding intensity and type of initial treatment for myeloma. Moreover, these electronic measures will allow VA investigators to study the safety and effectiveness of current and future myeloma treatment regimens as they are applied to older Veterans with frailty and multimorbidity. The proposed research seeks to combine geriatric measures with cancer-specific measures toward better individualizing care for older Veterans, intersecting the missions of the VA Geriatrics Research Education and Clinical Centers (GRECC) and the National VA Precision Oncology Program.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: MICHAEL E DEBAKEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Low testosterone and diabetes mellitus are each associated with increased risk for fractures. Men with diabetes mellitus are commonly found to have low testosterone as well. Testosterone has been shown to improve the bone health of patients with low testosterone but has not been tested in patients who also have diabetes mellitus in addition to low testosterone. To date, there is no treatment that is specifically recommended for bone disease among patients with diabetes. This study will evaluate the effect of testosterone on the bone health of male veterans who have both diabetes and low testosterone, both of which are highly prevalent in this subset of the population.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: The novel coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 infection, (COVID), continues to rage throughout the world with 115,000,000 confirmed cases and over 2,500,000 deaths (as of Mar 3, 2021). This translates to millions of people surviving COVID19 infection. While the lungs are ground zero, COVID19 tears through organ systems from brain to blood vessels. We are now beginning to see people recover but complain of ongoing problems, including lingering cognitive problems, depression, and anxiety. We have brought together 2 laboratories with complementary techniques including psychological testing and neuroimaging methods together with markers in the blood that may signal damage in the brain. A close look at these problems is timely and imperative if we are to understand the pathophysiology of “COVID brain” and prepare for downstream problems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Our ability to communicate with each other and to navigate through acoustically rich environments depends on the detection and exquisite analysis of sounds by the inner ear. Numerous genetic studies have shown that the tectorial membrane plays a key role in shaping this analysis, but the important mechanisms are not well understood. The proposed research to clarify these underlying mechanisms will improve our understanding of both normal and impaired hearing, and will be important for the design of speech-processing devices such as cochlear implants, hearing aids, and speech-communication and speech-recognition systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NARRATIVE Diversity in the ion channel composition of auditory and vestibular neurons is important for how they convey sensory information. The properties of ion channels are not fixed but can modulated by inputs from other cells to protect the neurons from damage. By understanding how this modulation works, our research will aid future therapies aimed at protecting the vulnerable neurons in the hearing and balance systems.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative Severe chronic pain and opioid use disorder (OUD) occur at significantly higher rates in Veterans compared to the general population. Chronic pain often persists despite engagement in opioid agonist treatment (OAT), the first line treatment for OUD. Recent VA guidelines strongly recommend non-pharmacologic treatment for chronic pain, but individuals with OUD are frequently excluded from pain treatment studies. There is a need for evidence-based pain treatments that compliment OAT for Veterans with chronic pain and OUD. In this study, we will determine feasibility and acceptability for a behaviorally focused pain treatment that includes pain education and a pedometer assisted adaptive walking program for Veterans receiving OAT for OUD. Treatment outcomes will be assessed using ecological momentary assessment (EMA), where behavior is repeatedly assessed using a mobile device, and study-provided pedometers. By offering pain treatment within OAT clinical care, we hope to decrease stigma and increase access for Veterans with chronic pain and OUD.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE        Over 40,000 Veterans who served in the 1991 Gulf War have chronic multisymptom illness that defines Gulf War Veterans Illness (GWVI). There are no proven treatments to provide relief to these sufferers, so it is critical to find efficacious and acceptable treatments for GWVI. Our goal is to develop a safe and effective mind-body treatment to reduce pain and enhance wellness in Veterans with GWVI without the side-effects of drug treatments. Tai Chi is a traditional Chinese mind-body therapy that has been practiced for centuries. Our team has demonstrated that Tai Chi can improve physical health and psychological well-being for individuals with a variety of chronic conditions. Providing GW Veterans even moderate relief from chronic and debilitating symptoms of GWVI could have a profound impact on improving their overall sense of well-being and quality of life, the ultimate measure of treatment efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Studies proposed in this renewal application for the GM031530 grant will address several new regulatory aspects of the Arg/N-degron pathway of protein degradation, a universally present and important proteolytic system. Specific proposed studies address a coupling between a C-degron and stability of a protein’s mRNA, the new phenomenon of superchanneling, and a functional (as well as mechanistic) link between human caspases and the Arg/N-degron pathway. Our studies of this proteolytic system will contribute to advances in fundamental biology and may also lead to therapies for specific human diseases.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Post 9/11 Veterans who enroll in VA health care frequently present with suicidal ideation and/or recent suicidal behavior. Most of these Veterans are not screened that day, and their risk goes undetected. Studies show that screening for suicide risk, and associated mental health factors, can lead to early detection and referral to effective treatment thereby decreasing suicide risk. Many studies also show that technology can improve screening efforts. Building off 7 years of prior work, in this trial we will evaluate an innovative VHA technology, eScreening, to improve rate and speed of suicide risk screening and referral to mental health care compared to current screening methods used by transition care managers. This study will also evaluate a strategy designed to help programs implement eScreening in new sites. The results of the study could help identify best practices for screening in suicide prevention for Post-9/11Veterans enrolling in VHA and provide information on how best to implement technology-based screening into clinical care programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on measuring the cellular effects of dihydroxyacetone (DHA) exposure in pulmonary and cardiovascular models to better understand the inhalation exposure effects of DHA. DHA generated by e-cigarettes is inhaled by vapers, enters cells, and is incorporated into metabolic pathways causing metabolic changes and mitochondrial damage. This work will establish critical links between DHA exposure and disease for e-cigarette users by understanding DHA’s ability to alter cell homeostasis, cause severe declines in cellular function, and induce cell death. .

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The neural plate border is the site of specification for diverse cell types including neural crest and ectodermal placode cells, and cells of the central nervous system (CNS). Despite the involvement of neural plate border cells and their derivatives in human health and disease—craniofacial and cardiovascular defects, cancers including melanoma and neuroblastoma, and congenital deafness can all result from their dysfunction—a detailed understanding of their early specification and lineage commitment is lacking. The goal of this proposal is to investigate the epigenetic regulation of miRNAs during specification of neural plate border cells in order to understand how this diverse pool of progenitors becomes differentially primed for the acquisition of distinct fates.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: VA has mandated that all Veterans be screened for PTSD annually for the first five years after military separation and every five years thereafter to identify Veterans with undiagnosed posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and provide them with evidence-based interventions. Despite these efforts, nearly half of Veterans who receive a new positive PTSD screen in primary care receive no follow-up VA-based mental health care. To improve access to care for these Veterans, information is needed regarding who is being lost to follow-up, where in the process they are being lost, and why these Veterans are not receiving VA care. The immediate goals of this HSR&D IIR project are to map the pathways Veterans follow after screening positive for PTSD that may eventually lead to VA mental health care, and to understand the factors that may facilitate or hinder this process. Our findings will directly inform the development of policy guidance and the implementation of targeted access interventions, thereby improving access to VA mental health care for all Veterans with PTSD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative There is continued concern about the negative impact of environmental exposures on human health and a shortage of qualified young scientists entering the field of environmental health sciences (EHS) who seek to elucidate the environmental causes of injuries and illnesses. Recruiting talented, energetic undergraduates to the field of environmental health sciences and encouraging them to seek advanced degrees in EHS or related fields is critical to advancing public health as it pertains to protecting the public from the negative impact of environmental exposures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: A better understanding of what causes autism and other neurodevelopmental disabilities can lead to better treatment and ultimately prevention of onset or disabilities. Although we know genes and prenatal and early life environments play a role, we do not yet understand the specific factors and need rigorous studies that follow pregnancies and early childhood factors as they occur, prior to symptom onset. The EARLI study is designed in this way, with many types of data about environments, medical conditions, early child development, and biological samples like blood, urine, hair, semen and placenta that can contribute to the child environmental health research community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Decades of investigations have established chronic dietary exposures to fungal toxins (aflatoxins) and chronic inflammation from hepatitis B viral infection as known risk factors for developing liver cancer. We have recently discovered an additional risk factor - deficiencies in a DNA base excision repair gene. Since at-risk portions of the human population carry deleterious mutations in this repair gene, this application will investigate deficiencies in this pathway as a driver of liver carcinogenesis using biochemical, cell, and murine models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Invasive melanoma is a potentially deadly medical condition, with an incidence of 100,000 new cases in 2021 alone. Melanoma research has mainly focused on melanocyte dysregulation to understand the disease; yet, the epidermis is an important microenvironment for healthy melanocytes, which adhere to and communicate with keratinocytes to maintain homeostasis. In this project, we will test hypothesis that melanocytes and epidermal cells form specialized adhesions important for melanocyte migration and retention within the epidermis, thereby contributing to the suppression of melanoma metastasis.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: With advancing age there is a higher incidence of mobility related falls, leading to devastating consequences. One component of mobility often overlooked but commonly performed is turning, which can lead to injury when performed poorly. As such, there is a need for effective rehabilitation interventions to improve turning function for older adults. Transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) is a promising and clinically-feasible approach that might enhance the effects of rehabilitation. tDCS is a non-invasive form of electrical stimulation delivered to the brain via electrodes placed on the scalp. When active tDCS is delivered during walking and turning rehabilitation sessions, it might help to strengthen neural circuits and promote better outcomes as opposed to sham tDCS. The goal of this study is to assess whether combining active tDCS with practice of challenging walking tasks, including turning, improves turning performance in older adults. This outcome would provide supporting data to pursue a larger clinical trial assessing the use of tDCS for rehabilitation specific to turning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Double-negative T cells are a rare population of T cells that lack CD4 and CD8 expression and abnormally expand in lupus patients. While current studies demonstrate that DN T cells play an important pathogenic role in autoimmune disease development, the mechanisms that regulate DN T cell homeostasis are completely unknown and there are no therapies to selectively deplete DN T cells in vivo. In this proposal, we will define the cellular and molecular mechanisms that control DN T cell development and function, and we will develop a novel mechanism-based immunotherapy to deplete DN T cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: This study will provide new and much needed information on the magnitude, sources, and impacts of exposure to commonly encountered chemicals, both individually and in combination, among pregnant women, and innovative methods for identifying relevant biological pathways and assessing health impacts from exposure to mixtures. These findings will have a significant impact on public health given widespread exposure to the target chemicals in the population, the growing need to identify environmental agents that adversely impact pregnancy, and the need to discover contributors to the high rates of preterm birth in the U.S. and beyond that could be prevented. Our study will also provide new information on the role of oxidative stress in adverse pregnancy outcomes which may inform future therapeutic or preventative interventions, and contribute new statistical and machine learning methods for investigating mixtures, mediation, and birth outcomes.

PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health, because a sustainable technology will be developed for the passive bioremediation of complex mixtures of groundwater contaminants, including chlorinated solvents and 1,4-dioxane via aerobic cometabolism. The co-encapsulation of pure cultures of bacteria along with slow release compounds in hydrogels beads has the potential to lower costs and achieve high treatment efficiencies. The beads can be used to treat a broad range of contaminants and in many different platforms, including permeable reactive barriers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antifungal drug resistant Candida species are a serious antimicrobial threat worldwide. The goal of this project is to determine the rate and dynamics in which drug resistant mutations are acquired in controlled evolution experiments and elucidate novel mechanisms of acquired resistance both in vitro and in vivo. Our approaches include experimental evolution, flow cytometry, mathematical modeling, comparative genomics, and molecular engineering.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative Atherosclerotic vascular disease remains the leading cause of death in the United States with the majority of mortality due to coronary artery disease and myocardial infarction. Likewise, the Veteran population is not immune to this where a significant portion of VA medical care is focused on ischemic heart disease and its complications. Macrophages are primary cells that specialize in removing the excess lipids and other debris present in the atherosclerotic plaque. We have found that macrophages have the ability to augment their degradation machinery and when this response is stimulated genetically in mice, they have reduced atherosclerosis. Furthermore, we have discovered a key regulatory pathway in macrophages that can stimulate this degradation machinery. We propose to dissect the mechanisms involved in this regulation both in vitro and in vivo with the goal of developing a completely novel strategy of treating atherosclerosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research will delineate how chronic manganese exposure can impact neuropathological and cognitive changes in Alzheimer’s disease. This work is directly relevant to NIEHS’s mission to understand how the environment can directly impact public health and specific disease burden. Understanding the role of manganese in mechanisms of neurodegeneration will provide opportunities to delay disease onset or progression in order to extend the healthy, active years of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nutritional status may influence the qualities of immunity, including perhaps the effectiveness of defense against microbes. There are hints that this major factor in human health may involve the levels of key amino acids in the bloodstream, but a major technical obstacle has been that scientists cannot visualize relative levels of these nutrients or metabolites that can come from them in the micro-anatomy of organs where immune responses are generated and effected. The work we propose here will test how manipulations of supply or utilization of nutrients such as glutamine impact antibody responses after modeling vaccination, and use a novel approach to rigorously validate how these manipulations change the micro-environment in immune organs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Pediatric and Reproductive Environmental Health Scholars-Southeastern Environmental Exposures and Disparities (PREHS-SEED) mentored K12 career development scholars program will provide junior clinical faculty with comprehensive training in pediatric and reproductive environmental health research. Faculty scholars will collaborate with local community partners and the Region 4 Southeast Pediatric Environmental Health Specialty Unit (PEHSU)— a region burdened by systemic racism and climate-related environmental threats that intensify health disparities. Faculty scholars will conduct research to assess environmental health exposures and disparities in order to improve health equity and safeguard the health of at-risk women and children in the Southeastern United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Age-related hearing loss (ARHL) or presbycusis, which is becoming increasingly common as the population ages, and the genetic basis of ARHL is not well-defined, however, Genome-wide Association studies (GWAS) are rapidly identifying new variants and candidate genes. To understand their role in ARHL, we will generate knockouts of candidate disease genes associated with ARHL in zebrafish to determine the functional consequence of such mutations in ARHL. Identifying the functional consequences of causal variants involving ARHL will be crucial in understanding the molecular basis of the disease that will ultimately be required for the development of therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infections during pregnancy produce inflammatory cytokines (such as type I interferon) which can lead to miscarriage or birth defects; unfortunately, there are no interventions capable of protecting the fetus from this inflammation. We have identified a previously uncharacterized signaling pathway, induced by the G protein- coupled estrogen receptor 1 (GPER1), that functions to prevent type I interferons produced during a maternal respiratory infection from compromising fetal development. The major goal of this application is to define how the basal activities of GPER1 normally protect fetal health so that this knowledge can eventually be leveraged to prevent poor pregnancy outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The mission of the Woods Hole Center for Oceans and Human Health is to protect the public health by: a) expanding our understanding of how climate and oceanic processes affect the population dynamics of key Harmful Algal Bloom (HAB) species, b) applying this information to predict how climate variability influences HABs and human exposure to toxins, and c) determining the scope and consequences of newly identified effects in the brain from exposure to potent HAB neurotoxins during development. Studies will focus on Alexandrium catenella and Pseudo-nitzschia spp. that produce the potent neurotoxins saxitoxin and domoic acid, respectively. Findings will be communicated, involving resource managers, stakeholders, students, health care providers and the public, to enhance understanding and disease diagnosis and improve public health.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Relevance Prostate cancer is the leading cause of cancer related death in veterans. Although significant progress has been made in treatment, “exceptional responses” are rare and there is currently no way to personalize care for the majority of men with this disease. This study will test the effectiveness of high dose testosterone, a drug with early evidence for responses across a range of genes involved in DNA repair and with excellent tolerance in patients with ATM or CDK12 inactivating alterations in their prostate cancers. If successful, this study could provide a means of predicting which veterans could benefit from more effective and less toxic therapy for metastatic, resistant prostate cancer.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The goals of this proposal are to identify genes responsible for neurologic disorders that affect movement, including ataxias, parkinsonian disorders, hereditary spastic paraplegias, choreas and dystonias, and decifer the steps that lead from the altered genes to disease. Genetic diseases of the nervous system are relatively common in the Veteran population and the diseases studied in this research project are directly relevant to Veterans’ health. These disorders, and especially parkinsonian disorders and ataxia, disproportionately affect the aging Veteran population. By itself Parkinson's disease affects approximately one million individuals in the United States at an estimated annual cost of $52 billion. Knowledge gained from studies on the biologic causes of the inherited forms of diseases will also increase understanding of more common neurologic disorders and accelerate improvement in diagnosis, management, and treatment of these and related conditions. Therefore, a better understanding of genetic diseases is pertinent to the long-term VHA mission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Rising negative affect is a well-established momentary maintenance factor for binge eating, yet limitations inherent to ecological momentary assessment hinder the field’s capacity to detect risk for binge eating in response to negative affectivity. This study will use passive psychophysiological sensors to evaluate the momentary association between negative affect and binge eating with the goals of 1) improving upon EMA to accurately predict binge eating in real time and 2) quantitatively and qualitatively evaluating the feasibility and acceptability of wearable psychophysiological sensors among individuals with binge eating. The project will set the stage for future research to develop more effective just-in-time adaptive interventions for binge eating and improve treatment outcomes and access in this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Healthy people exposed to environmental mutagens accumulate somatic mutations in most cells of the exposed tissues. In this project, we propose to develop an innovative computational approach that will allow noninvasive monitoring of mutational processes from environmental exposures in easily accessible normal tissues of healthy individuals. The proposed approach will open a plethora of opportunities for personalized cancer prevention by timely detection of mutagenic exposures allowing targeted interventions for reducing or eliminating these environmental exposures.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: WHITE RIVER JUNCTION VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Depression is very common, costly and disabling, especially within the VA. Although there are potentially effective treatments for depression, many patients do not respond adequately to these. Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) is a novel intervention for depression that is available in the VA through a Clinical TMS Pilot Program. Many patients with treatment-resistant depression respond well to TMS, but many do not. TMS likely works by altering how certain regions of the brain communicate with each other. Electroencephalography (EEG) can provide a measure of how various brain regions are functioning and communicating with one another. By enrolling patients receiving treatment in the TMS Pilot Program, this study will test EEG-based markers of brain function that predict response to TMS for depression. Additionally, this study will create a large, multi-site research infrastructure that will allow identification and testing of EEG markers of treatment response in a large Veteran group receiving TMS for depression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative: The studies proposed here are relevant to public health for three reasons. First, they will allow us to identify individual and organic toxicant mixtures associated with ASD prior to the onset of clinical signs, as possible causal agents. Second, they will allow the discovery of exogenous and endogenous metabolites, and biological responses associated with ASD prior to the onset of clinical signs, so that we can objectively identify potential causal pathways and markers that can serve as the foundation for treatment strategies. Third, the temporal resolution afforded by the novel tooth biomarker technology allows us to identify the sensitive life stages for metabolic perturbations and toxicant exposures in fetal and neonatal development most strongly associated with ASD risk.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emerging evidence suggests that early-life environmental exposures are contributing to the increasing prevalence of allergic diseases including food allergy. In this proposal, we will investigate how exposures to environmental agents within the home, such as microbial products and air pollutants, influence peanut allergy development. This research will elucidate the role of the indoor exposome in food allergy development and help guide environmental remediation strategies aimed at reducing food allergy risk in children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of our studies is to learn how aging effects our immune cells and responses to influenza vaccination so that we can reverse the declines with aging and restore a youthful vaccine response. We will compare the seasonal influenza vaccine responses in a group of around 100 each young (40yrs) and older (65yrs) adults by analyzing their blood to determine how their immune cells change with age and how these changes affect our vaccine responses. We will use the knowledge gained from these studies to perform laboratory experiments in which we treat older immune cells with immune modulators and small molecules to see if we can restore immunologic and metabolic function to overcome age-related defects in vaccine responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The utero-placental circulations are specifically designed to regulate the flow of blood and transport of essential nutrients to the fetus; this coordinated exchange is highly susceptible to disruption from environmental exposure, which can result in miscarriage and intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR). Unfortunately, the vascular and endothelial-dependent mechanisms by which utero-placental blood flow is reduced in IUGR are unknown, resulting in few treatment options beyond preterm delivery. We will use our model of environmentally-inducible IUGR to reveal novel mechanisms of altered hemodynamic molecular signaling that contribute to the development of IUGR as well as test nutritional interventions to mitigate IUGR severity.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFASs) are highly stable and toxic chemicals that can cause adverse human health effects (e.g. increased risk of Type 2 diabetes and liver cancer). The goal of this proposal is to develop a treatment system that combines nanotechnology with microbial degradation to achieve complete destruction of PFASs without the production of toxic byproducts. The fundamental knowledge obtained from this study will provide critical information needed in developing efficient strategies to eliminate deleterious effects of PFAS in the environment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative The research aims to address the significant challenges of persistent organic pollutants (POPs) remediation using Nanomaterial-Fungus Framework (NFF) through material design and mechanism study. The NFF contains a scaffold that absorbs trace level POPs rapidly, supports fungal growth, and stimulates the expression of oxidative enzymes for efficient bioremediation. The study will elucidate fundamental mechanisms for fungal bioremediation and offer an innovative stimulating material to enhance efficiency, enabling broad applications for remediation of diverse POPs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Both chlorinated volatile organic compounds (CVOCs) and 1,4-dioxane are potential or known human carcinogens. 1,4-dioxane, an emerging contaminant above the health-based reference level in 6.9% of the U.S. public water supplies, is commonly found to co-occur with CVOCs in contaminated groundwater including Superfund sites. This project aims at enhancing the remediation of 1,4-dioxane or its mixture with CVOCs by combining novel macrocyclic materials for contaminant adsorption with bioremediation, and investigates the interactions among the adsorbents, microbes, and contaminants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Relevance Excessive type 3 cytokine response is responsible for psoriasis and eczema, a skin disorder involving impaired skin barrier integrity. Obesity, often driven by intake of high fat western diet, is one of the non-genetic factors associated with morbidity and severity of these two chronic inflammatory skin diseases. Despite major progress in understanding the immunological effect of dietary lipids, little is known about the molecular mechanism linking high fat diet to tissue inflammatory diseases. We have discovered that dietary cholesterol and its metabolites oxysterols shapes innate T lymphocytes resident in the skin that are equipped with sensors of altered oxysterol homeostasis. We will test the hypothesis that the fine specificity of skin positioning of these dermal T cells guided by oxysterols produced in a specialized skin niche is obligatory for proper immune reactions. Skin-homing innate T cells are imprinted to sense cholesterol byproducts during their development in the thymus and we will seek to decipher the molecular features controlling T cell-thymic niche crosstalk. This project will establish the functional importance of tissue cholesterol metabolism to achieve mucosal tissue immune homeostasis and provide new intervention strategies to treat inflammatory disorders in the skin, lung and gut.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have learned that capsule serotype influences the translocation rate of Streptococcus pneumoniae across vascular endothelial cells (VEC) and into organs during bacteremia. Herein we will examine how capsule impacts attachment, receptor mediated endocytosis, resistance to intracellular killing, and S. pneumoniae trafficking to the basolateral surface of VEC for organ invasion. Our results will directly impact risk assessment strategies for escape from serotype-based vaccine design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Daily adherence to food allergen avoidance and emergency preparedness is challenging particularly during early adolescence. The Food Allergy Mastery (FAM) Program is a novel behavioral intervention that is developed to equip youth with food allergy knowledge and self-management skills, bolster their food allergy-related problem- solving, social skills, and social support, and attenuate food allergy anxiety. We expect this program will increase the likelihood that youth will engage in appropriate food allergy self-management, improve quality of life, and ultimately, reduce risk for anaphylaxis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NARRATIVE There is a rapidly growing population of adult and pediatric cochlear implant (CI) recipients with acoustic hearing preservation in the implanted ear(s) allowing for combined Electric and binaural Acoustic Stimulation (EAS). Despite the rapid technological and surgical advancements that have led to this increased prevalence, there is limited research on EAS outcomes—particularly for pediatric EAS listeners—including the expected trajectory of benefit following EAS fitting and underlying mechanisms driving benefit in EAS users of all ages. The purpose of this project is to provide a comprehensive description of behavioral and electrophysiologic measures of binaural hearing in adults and children both with normal hearing and EAS users.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Replication stress is a fundamental step and an early driver of tumorigenesis and has been associated with many activated oncogenes. The goal of this study is to define the molecular events that govern the early changes to DNA replication initiation and termination across the genome during oncogene activation. Deciphering the mechanisms that contribute to oncogene-induced replication stress may provide new avenues for targeted cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Radiation therapy is one of the most common treatments for cancer. Upon conclusion, we will translate a new in vivo dosimeter prototype into a workable tool for radiation therapy dose monitoring based on an academic-Industrial partnership between University of Oklahoma (OU) and PhotoSound Technologies Inc. The technological advances in using dual modal X-ray-induced Acoustic Computed tomography (XACT) and ultrasound imaging for in vivo dosimetry will decrease radiation treatment toxicity and improve clinical outcomes for cancer patients.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: OVERALL The Great Lakes Center for Fresh Waters and Human Health at the University of Michigan (UM) is building on five years of successful interdisciplinary collaboration and community engagement to better understand the increasing risks that cyanobacterial harmful algal blooms (cHAB) pose to freshwater ecosystems and human health. This Center, led by a multi-institutional team of biomedical scientists, limnologists and community engagement experts, seeks to advance their work in Lake Erie by characterizing how climate change affects cHAB growth, production and transport of toxins through water and the atmosphere, and impacts public health outcomes, especially for vulnerable populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Spinal cord stimulation (SCS) is a promising nonpharmacological intervention for the treatment of chronic pain. Current technology for SCS is based on time-invariant pulses (TIP) which can constrain the location and quality of paresthesia coverage, and contribute to the development of tolerance to the therapy. To overcome these challenges, we propose to develop and clinically test a device capable of delivering novel stimulation time variant pulse (TVPs) patterns, in which a stimulation parameter changes according to a modulatory time- varying function, a strategy which may lead to improved long-term pain outcomes with SCS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions): Bacterial viruses called phage play a major role in controlling the transmission of Vibrio cholerae, the  infectious agent of the lethal disease cholera. The proposed studies seek to define the mechanism of  bacterial systems that defend against phages because many of these have been shown to have  counterparts in human cells that defend against viruses including Covid-19.Thus, discoveries made through  our work may lead to new strategies to control or eradicate human viruses that impact public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: OVERALL NARRATIVE The Lake Ontario Center for Microplastics and Human Health in a Changing Environment aims to prevent negative health impacts of microplastics in the context of climate change in the Great Lakes region. Our multidisciplinary systems research integrates assessment of sources, transport, fate, and impact of anthropogenic debris into Lake Ontario, with experimental investigation of biological activity of real-world mixtures of microplastics, associated biofilms, and other chemical contaminants utilizing novel nanomembrane technology. Multidirectional engagement with diverse partners will support community science, environmental health literacy, and capacity to promote multilevel solutions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Core A – Administration – Project Narrative The inherent complexity of microplastics (MP) and human health requires coordination, evaluation, adaptation, and facilitation of multidirectional communication both internally and externally. The Administrative Team will support these efforts through: 1) administrative, fiscal and scientific oversight; 2) communication about the Center to maximize its research, engagement, and translation impacts; 3) evaluation activities that provide ongoing feedback on Center goals, including the Plan to Enhance Diverse Perspectives. Our intentionally collaborative administrative structures will support convergent multidisciplinary, engaged, systems science that informs effective solutions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The Materials and Metrology Core (MMC) will serve as a resource for the center that: 1) maintains and distributes standard materials; 2) develops, documents and teaches consensus protocols; 3) facilitates access to instruments and other resources useful in microplastic research. The MMC will also facilitate public access to the products of the Center.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project 3 – Project Narrative Although increasing exposure to plastic debris such as microplastics have become a major concern for human health, little is still known about their specific long-term biological impacts and how climate changes affect these effects. The goal of this project is to leverage a sensitive and reliable experimental platform in the amphibian Xenopus laevis to rigorously assess the biodistribution of microplastics and resulting impacts on development, fitness, immune homeostasis and antimicrobial immunity, under varied conditions of temperature. Given the high degree of evolutionary conservation of vertebrate physiology, the outcomes from this study are relevant to human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Neurodegenerative diseases are imposing an increasing health and financial burden given the rapid increase of the aging segment of the population. Currently, no therapeutics exist that significantly modify sporadic amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). This grant will use proven methods for developing a potent antisense oligonucleotide therapeutic that normalizes pathologically high STAU1 expression. Because other neurodegenerative diseases are also characterized by STAU1 overabundance, this therapeutic may be effective for other neurological diseases as well.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are multiple evidence-based strategies (EBS) for increasing HPV vaccination among target adolescent populations, but few of these programs are routinely used in practice, including in safety-net clinics serving communities at higher risk for HPV-associated cancers. This R37 extension project aims to evaluate longer-term sustainability, maintenance, and equity requirements for use of EBS and identify factors that impact broader system-level adoption and scale-up within health care settings for underserved populations to inform practice change for HPV vaccine improvement relevant to real-world clinical settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cachexia is a debilitating metabolic disorder characterized by an involuntary loss of lean body mass, systemic inflammation, and negative protein and energy balance. It is the primary cause of death for up to 30% of cancer patients and there are currently no effective therapies to manage cachexia. The proposed project will provide novel nanomedicine-based therapeutic strategies that stimulate appetite and attenuate cachexia-associated muscle wasting and systemic inflammation in cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  Over 50 inherited neuromuscular disorders including myopathies, muscular dystrophies, and metabolic muscle disorders have been identified with a monogenic underpinning. These neuromuscular disorders are characterized by progressive weakness and degeneration of muscle tissue. In this Fast-track SBIR proposal miRecule will develop a muscle-specific platform (Muscle- NAVTM) for the delivery of therapeutic oligonucleotide to treat inherited muscle disorders. Facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy (FSHD) is the third most common form of MD with roughly 20,000 patients presenting with symptoms in the US. FSHD results in progressive weakness in the muscles of the face, shoulders, arms, abdomen, and legs. To validate our Muscle-NAV platform we propose to deliver our (ASO) targeting DUX4 (miRecule candidate MC- DX4) for the treatment of FSHD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative (Public Health Relevance Statement) Reversible oxidation and reduction of protein methionines is an emerging mechanism for maintaining cellular homeostasis, contributing to regulation of protein function, cell signaling, and antioxidant defense. Indeed, increased oxidative stress and/or decreased capacity for reduction of methionine sulfoxide to methionine is linked to life-span regulation, neurodegeneration, vascular diseases and thrombosis, and cancer cell proliferation. We are developing new chemical tools to probe methionine with high specificity in protein and proteome settings to identify, biochemically characterize, and provide new imaging reagents for redox- responsive methionine sites important to physiology and disease, particularly in metabolic and oncogenic proteins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Project Narrative  Environmental exposure to carcinogenic metal (metalloid) arsenic, especially the trivalent form, As3+(iAs), has long been a major public health concern. The research proposed in this application is aimed at increasing our understanding of mechanisms by which iAs induces generation of the cancer stem-like cells (CSCs). Main efforts will be on the role of iAs-induced Nrf2-HIF1a signaling linked to glycolysis and the formation of CSCs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Nickel (Ni) compounds are environmental toxicants, prevalent in the atmosphere due to their widespread use in several industrial processes, as well as extensive consumption of Ni containing products. Although Ni- compounds have been conclusively shown to be associated with a multitude of human health risks including allergic contact dermatitis, bronchitis, pulmonary fibrosis, pulmonary edema and lung and nasal cancers, the molecular basis of Ni-induced diseases remain poorly understood. This study will investigate the mechanisms underlying Ni-induced diseases by examining the long-term changes to the transcriptome and epigenome that occur due to Ni exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Appalachian Kentuckians in Martin and Letcher Counties are grappling with a health-threatening drinking water crisis arising from exposures to disinfection by-products (DBPs). DBPs include compounds that have been associated with a variety of adverse health effects, including increased risk of bladder cancer and cardiovascular birth defects. This study, which builds on findings from two community-engaged NIEHS P30-funded pilot studies and one P30-funded community grant, uses a multi-method approach, stakeholder-engaged approach to reduce DBP exposures and improve public health in target counties.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Knowing the structure, dynamics and ligand binding specificity of proteins and nucleic acids is essential to understanding the mechanisms of human disease and to the optimal design of molecules that can intervene therapeutically in disease processes. Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) Spectroscopy is one of the most versatile techniques for obtaining this molecular information. This research will further develop and extend an integrated, software application for processing, analyzing, and using NMR data, and thereby make the use of these techniques faster and more accessible to a wider population of researchers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Hearing loss typically involves difficulty understanding sounds, especially in backgrounds of noise. We are developing and testing a new framework for describing the way that sounds are represented in the responses of neurons. Knowledge of how the healthy brain copes with difficult listening environments will provide new and important insights for aiding listeners with hearing loss. The Public Health Relevance of this project is to develop a better understanding of the difficulties in noisy situations for listeners with hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The cellular degradative process of autophagy is a major host defense pathway. Thus, gene variants and pharmacological interventions that affect autophagy are predicted to modulate susceptibility to bacterial pathogens. In this proposal, we will investigate the physiological mechanisms by which autophagy alters defense against two significant bacterial pathogens, Salmonella enterica Typhimurium and Staphylococcus aureus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Many nematode (roundworm) species are parasites of humans, livestock, and crops, infecting one-third of humans world-wide and causing billions of dollars in agricultural losses. An understanding of the chemical signals used by nematodes to control their development will provide new strategies and chemical treatments to interfere with the life cycles of parasitic species and reduce their survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative All genetic processes are ultimately controlled by protein-DNA interactions. Incorrect processing of DNA in humans lead to a wide range of genetic disorders, while induction of changes in DNA processing provides a strategy to control pathogenic organisms. The proposed project seeks to obtain mechanistic understanding of proteins that interact with DNA and thereby to advance our ability to control genetic processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exposure to phthalates, a class of chemicals that humans are unavoidably exposed to on a daily basis, is increasingly being recognized as contributing to the prevalence of infertility, in which defects in ovulation are the leading cause of infertility in women. The proposed research will address this public health concern by providing a more complete understanding of how phthalates inhibit prostaglandins and angiogenesis, which are essential for ovulation and fertility in women. Because infertility in women seeking to conceive leads to impairments in their physical and mental health, the overarching goal of this proposal is to establish novel rescue approaches to alleviate phthalate-induced reproductive dysfunction and infertility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hearing loss is a major health problem that significantly affects the life quality of affected individuals. Many forms or hearing loss are caused by defects in auditory hair cells and the neurons that innervate them. We propose here to study the mechanisms that regulate the connectivity of spiral ganglion neurons that innervate hair cells, and how they are affected in a genetic form of hearing loss with the anticipation that our studies will ultimately lead to a better treatment of the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Human health and disease are shaped by a range of life-long exposures, and our biological response to them, underscoring the need for a systematic plan to integrate environmental health/exposomics into precision medicine initiatives. Clinician-scientists are a critical bridge for translating basic and clinical research into new paradigms of clinical care. The Mount Sinai K12 program will develop healthcare professionals poised to integrate environmental science with evolving precision medicine and clinical care efforts and catalyze the development of the next generation of versatile children's environmental health leaders to address emerging complexities of pediatric and reproductive environmental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cytoskeletal proteins play fundamental roles in many biological processes in all eukaryotes. Given their essentiality, they are traditionally thought to be highly conserved. However, many cytoskeletal proteins, especially those that are expressed in the male germline, are subject to accelerated diversification in the form of gene duplications and rapid evolution in multiple animal lineages. This proposal investigates how cytoskeletal proteins undergo adaptation for novel functions during spermatogenesis and impact male reproductive fitness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Using combined genetic, biochemical, spectroscopic and structural approaches, we propose to investigate how M-cluster, the unique metallocofactor of molybdenum nitrogenase, is assembled into a functional unit. Through our proposed studies, we expect to refine the biosynthetic mechanism of this catalytically important and chemically unprecedented metallocluster, which will provide crucial insights into the structural-functional relationship of nitrogenase and reveal some general principles of the assembly of complex metalloclusters in biological systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Hematologic malignancies that carry an activating mutation in the tyrosine phosphatase PTPN11 continue to carry a poor prognosis. Targeting this pathway to improve treatment of these diseases has remained difficult. We have recently shown that PTPN11 activity is dependent on activation by a tyrosine kinase, TNK2 that can be readily chemically targeted. Interrogation of these findings will lead to a better understanding of the activation and dependence of this pathway to improve treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Older adults have reduced immune responses to vaccination that leave them more vulnerable to infectious diseases, such as influenza. The overall hypothesis in this proposal is that the age-associated accumulation of senescent cells and the senescence associated secretory phenotype (SASP) are the main drivers of diminished vaccine responses with aging. To assess this we will 1) pharmacologically eliminate senescent cells in mice via senolytic drugs prior to influenza vaccination and determine immunomodulatory effects on cell- mediated and humoral responses to vaccination and influenza infection challenge; and 2) determine translational impact via in vitro analyses of human T and B cell responses when exposed to senescent media.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer death in the country, surpassing deaths caused by colorectal, prostate and breast cancers combined. Veterans are at higher risk of lung cancer due to the higher rate of smoking and environmental toxin exposures. The lack of effective therapy provides the impetus to search for alternative, safe, and efficacious anticancer agents to improve treatment strategy against lung cancer, enhance the probability of a cure and reduce recurrence. Based on encouraging preclinical and clinical findings in a lung cancer chemoprevention pilot study, the purpose of this new CSR&D Merit Review proposal is to evaluate the feasibility of a standardized grape seed procyanidin extract with enhanced bioavailabilities, leucoselect phytosome, for neoadjuvant treatment of resectable stage I and II lung cancer in a phase IIa clinical trial, to establish safety, feasibility, define and validate mechanisms of action, identify suitable surrogate endpoint biomarkers and set the stage for larger, confirmatory trials in the near future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Small cell lung cancer (SCLC) accounts for >30,000 American lives each year and portends five-year survival rates of just ~7%. Detection of SCLC at early stage drastically improves these survival metrics. We propose to leverage molecular features unique to SCLC, such as the development of autoantibody-antigen complexes, to validate a plasma biomarker panel capable of SCLC early detection to allow for early initiation of potentially curative chemotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative While silencers (cis-regulatory elements) are known to be highly cell type specific, their contribution to CD4 T cell homeostasis is unknown. This proposal seeks to identify functional silencer elements in CD4 cells, and provide a mechanism for silencer activation through PRC2 binding and H3K27me3 formation. This proposal aims to provide a catalogue of T cell specific silencer elements, the defining histone marks, and transcription factor regulation of silencers in T cells.
