IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Streptococcus pneumoniae remains a leading cause of bacterial pneumonia and death due to infectious diseases worldwide despite the use of two approved vaccines targeting the serotypically diverse capsular polysaccharide. The infection rate remains high, especially in older adults, primarily due to infection with serotypes not included in current vaccines, and treatment options can be limited as there has been a rise in antibiotic resistance among non-vaccine serotypes. The research described in this R01 proposal will determine the protective efficacy and underlying structural and mechanistic correlates of protection of human monoclonal antibodies to highly conserved pneumococcal surface proteins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: STATEMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH SIGNIFICANCE Enteric infectious diseases are among the most common illnesses in the world and the bacterium Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium is both a NIAID category B priority pathogen and a leading cause of morbidity and mortality from diarrhea globally. Colonization of cockroaches by S. Typhimurium not only enhances the potential for vector-borne transmission relative to mechanical mechanisms, but also creates an interphase for the evolution of antibiotic resistance and virulence traits that could influence the severity of cockroach-borne human infections. By illuminating the active role of cockroaches as vectors, our work will improve appreciation of cockroach control among the scientific and public health fields, which may lead to more concerted efforts to use existing cockroach control tools or develop novel tools for infection prevention in high-risk areas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions): Our proposed studies will further elucidate the mechanism of chromatin loop extrusion-mediated lgH CSR, test the role of loop extrusion in SHM and also address the function of recurrent BCR clonotypes expressed in chronic intestinal Peyer's Patch germinal cente rs. To address these questions, we are applying a host of powerful new technologies developed by our lab. The proposed work should advance our understanding of key antibody maturation mechanisms and may provide insights into potential roles of Peyer's Patch germinal center antibodies with respect to involvement in normal physiology or disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance Statement While outcomes have substantially improved for many types of cancer, endometrial cancer incidence and deaths are on the rise, due in large part to inadequate sensitivity to hormonal therapy. Our study is anticipated to revitalize hormonal therapy for endometrial cancer by determining the mechanisms underlying loss of progesterone receptor, which dictates response to hormonal therapy, and successfully combining agents that overcome this hormone receptor suppression. Our research plan, which incorporates valuable clinical specimens from patients and a human-in-mouse tumor xenograft mouse model, is anticipated to have a positive impact by developing molecularly enhanced hormonal therapy to improve outcomes for patients with endometrial cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: While recent successes of cancer immunotherapy have generated considerable excitement, this form of treatment has been largely ineffective in patients with pancreatic cancer. A major barrier for immunotherapeutic approaches is immune suppression instigated by pancreatic tumor and stromal cells. We have identified IL35- producing B cells as important regulators of anti-tumor immune responses in pancreatic cancer, and our proposed research will shed light on the mechanisms by which these cells elicit pancreatic tumor growth and will provide us with novel therapeutic targets that could be used to synergize with existing immunotherapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Ovarian cancer (OC) survival has improved over the past several decades as new, frontline treatment strategies have been developed; however, the benefits of improved treatment have not been shared equitably. Given the immense complexity of cancer treatment and the importance of access to quality care, an improved understanding of factors underlying access to care – and an understanding of how those factors differ across population sub-groups – is urgently needed. Our proposed extension will comprehensively evaluate the impact of structural racism on healthcare access, quality treatment and survival among diverse OC patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) treatment is insufficient even with the latest novel therapeutics, and the overall prognosis is still poor. The JMJD1C protein has been shown to be a potential therapeutic target in AML. The proposed work aims to study the effectiveness of combining JMJD1C modulation and inhibitors against RAS protein pathway, which are commonly mutated in AML, in eliminating leukemia cells in AML with RAS activating mutation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Humans critically rely on a tiny region of the retina, the foveola, to inspect objects of interest. By examining how foveal processing is jointly shaped by anatomy, eye movements and fine control of attention, this research will advance understanding of the mechanisms responsible for visual acuity in humans and it may lay the basis for new treatment approaches for impairments in foveal functions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – OVERALL The mission of North Carolina Center for Coastal Algae, People, and Environment (NC C-CAPE) is to deliver novel insight and understanding of emergent and future, climate-driven human health risks related to cyanobacterial algal blooms and microcystins in shallow, estuarine environments. The integration of three research projects and a community engagement core will facilitate 1) the characterization of algal composition, microcystin concentrations, and microcystin congener mixtures in water and seafood (oysters and blue crabs) in relation to environmental conditions including toxin transport across the freshwater-to-marine continuum, 2) the examination of the effects of cyanotoxin mixtures on hepatic toxicity, fatty liver diseases, and liver cancers using a combination of a rodent model and a nested case-control study on human populations, 3) the development of predictive models for cyanotoxin risk assessment in the context of climate change, based on diverse algal bloom metrics and environmental covariates, and 4) effective data sharing to prevent bloom exposure of NC coastal communities, activate community science projects that fill data gaps, and improve translation of research findings on oceans and human health to community stakeholders. NC C-CAPE will be a nexus of climate and ocean science, human health, and stakeholder engagement to advance our understanding of harmful algal blooms, and to develop innovative approaches to assess, mitigate and predict their impacts on human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: The goal of the Scripps Center for Oceans and Human Health (SCOHH) is to advance the science of marine contaminants and seafood security. This multidisciplinary project involving ocean and human health scientists will examine the sources, fates, and toxicology of anthropogenic and natural chemicals in the ocean, and to probe their environmental distribution and movement through the seafood chain in a changing climate. Importantly, SCOHH will bridge science discovery, environmental health literacy, and community engagement to build capacity for public health risk prevention while highlighting the health benefits of consuming fish.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative – No change from original submission Many oral anti-cancer medications have proven effective in preventing cancer recurrence and mortality, however, treatment adherence to these oral medications, some of which are taken for years, can be challenging for cancer patients due to a variety of factors, including side effects and high costs. Since medication discontinuation can lead to lower survival rates, increased risk of recurrence, and higher healthcare costs, society will benefit from gaining a deeper understanding of the causes of medication discontinuation and knowing who are at a high risk of medication discontinuation. In this project, we will analyze the online communications between patients and healthcare providers in a patient portal and apply them as well as structured electronic medical records to predict medication discontinuation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Pancreatic cancer is characterized by KRAS mutation and extreme compression of cells in the highly mechanically perturbed tumor microenvironment. We have developed devices to apply precise compressive stresses and probes that enable the rapid determination of the physical properties of cells, and discovered that KRAS and compression lead to extremely high rates of mitotic error, thereby accelerating cancer genome evolution. We will now determine how evolved cancer cells survive and proliferate far more effectively in compressive environments.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and stroke are two common neurological diseases that often occur in the same aging individuals including veterans, but little research has been focused on the comorbidity of these diseases. Memantine (MEM) is a NMDA receptor antagonist used for moderate to severe AD patients. The investigation will test the hypothesis that chronic MEM treatment in AD mice of mild and moderate stages can ameliorate AD progression as well as precondition the AD brain for neuroprotection against ischemic stroke that attacks <50% of AD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Interneuron dysfunction is strongly associated with autism, schizophrenia and childhood epilepsy. Increasing experimental evidence points towards imbalances between the excitatory and inhibitory circuits in the brain as a prominent component in the etiology of these illnesses. This project is aimed at further our understanding on how electrical activity affects early brain maturation during critical periods of development with an emphasis on inhibitory neurons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Endothelial cells are known to aid in stem cell maintenance and regeneration in many tissues, but little is known about the role of endothelial cells, particularly lymphatic endothelial cells in the intestinal niche. Additionally, how lymphatic endothelial cells in the small intestine change in chemotherapy induced mucositis and how these changes relate to epithelial repair, remains unknown. My proposed work aims to understand how lymphatic endothelial cells, in part through the expression of the WNT modulators RSPO3 and WLS, contribute to ISC regeneration after cytotoxic injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The goal of this applications is to characterize in detail the mechanism by which three proteins that we discovered to bind to the HIV genome regulate up or down HIV expression. Drugs that can manipulate HIV expression from infected cells have immense potential in functional cure approaches. The more knowledge we gain on the how these host proteins interact with viral proteins and regulate HIV, the more we can leverage host regulators as antiviral targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tumor cells display nuclear pore and chromosomal defects, however, their specific mechanistic contribution to cancer progression is ill-defined. To enable the dissection of these intricate biological processes and their contribution to the aggressiveness of prostate cancer, our laboratory interrogates in vitro and in vivo patient- derived experimental models via transcriptomic, high-resolution live imaging microscopy, biochemistry and genetic approaches combined with publicly available patient datasets evaluation and patient tumor tissue validation. Our studies aim to identify novel actionable nuclear pore-regulated mechanisms in lethal prostate cancer that may benefit the clinical management of therapy refractory disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Narrative/Relevance  Castration-resistant prostate cancer is the lethal form of prostate cancer and the second leading cause of cancer death for men in the United States. This proposal will elucidate metabolic mechanisms that enable resistance to potent androgen receptor antagonist therapies. We anticipate that the insights gained from this proposal will directly lead to the identification of new drug targets and the development of improved treatment strategies for more effective clinical therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: De novo tissue morphogenesis is a fundamental process that contributes to building and maintaining organs, as well as orchestrating overall embryogenesis. This project will determine the mechanisms behind lumen formation and the role of cytokinesis/abscission in this process. Specifically, we will determine whether the site of abscission provides a landmark to initiate polarity and cilia formation through directed vesicle transport.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This pilot clinical trial leverages novel, scalable, and sustainable mobile technology, applied as an adjunct to behavioral treatment, to enhance real time skills utilization and promote sustained improvement for adolescents with Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD). This research will provide valuable data toward understanding how technology can optimize skills engagement, promote adherence, and improve treatment response in adolescents, which has the potential to critically inform treatment research with wide- reaching applications for other skills-based and behavioral treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Bacteria and fungi have evolved intricate mechanisms to detect their environment and transduce signals across biological membranes, inducing responses in organismal behaviors like growth, survival, and pathogenicity. Despite the prevalence of these transmembrane receptors, our understanding of the discrete mechanisms by which signals are propagated is still evolving. Through protein design and structural biology, we will elucidate the biophysical mechanisms of transmembrane signal transduction, establishing structure-function relationships that help us to better understand how biological systems have evolved to sense the world around them and leave us poised to more effectively target and engineer these signaling mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Narrative Gram-negative ‘superbugs’ have been classified as an urgent threat to public health globally. Recently, strains of Escherichia coli and Klebsiella pneumoniae that are resistant to all antibiotics have emerged and spread worldwide. This highlights the significance of the current project, which aims to devise innovative strategies for combinations of available antibiotics to successfully combat these highly resistant, deadly pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Hepatitis B virus (HBV) chronically infects >250 million people world-wide and kills ~900,000 annually by inducing liver failure or liver cancer, but current therapies are not curative and only partially suppress disease progression. HBV replicates by coordinate action of the viral reverse transcriptase and ribonuclease H (RNaseH) activities, but no anti-HBV RNaseH drugs exist despite the RNaseH being an attractive drug target. Here, we will conduct lead optimization and hit-to-lead medicinal chemistry campaigns to advance development of two related chemotypes of HBV RNaseH inhibitors as novel drug leads for treating chronic HBV infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH

PHR: Project Narrative  Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is a neuropsychiatric condition that causes enormous human suffering and is thought to result from a complex interplay of genetic and the environmental factors. Our goal in this study is to learn more about what precise genetic factors influence an individuals risk for OCD. We propose to do this by resequencing the protein coding portion of the genome in a large number of OCD subjects and matched controls.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: An important goal of modern mental health research is finding the neural circuit components and activity patterns that cause psychiatric symptom; a remarkable convergence of new technologies is occurring that may allow a fundamental leap forward in such circuit-level understanding of anhedonia (the loss of reward from experience), a defining symptom in, among other conditions, the disease of major depressive disorder. These technologies include mechanisms for collecting cellular-resolution dynamical information from deep within the brains of freely-moving mammals—and technologies that will allow us to test the causation of anhedonic states. Insight into the circuit dynamics of anhedonia may not only guide development of new, potent, and specific therapies, but will also contribute to our basic understanding of how neural circuit activity patterns give rise to behavior, with potential relevance to many neuropsychiatric diseases such as depression and schizophrenia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE) have become important causes of hospital-acquired infections and now represent serious threats to public health. The proposed experiments seek to elucidate the molecular mechanism that allows VRE to detect and respond to vancomycin. This information will prove invaluable in rationally developing new antibiotics and antibiotic adjuvants to combat this emerging crisis.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Pain is a very common and disabling symptom in Parkinson’s disease, yet it is often untreated. This study will assess the impact of home-based physical and cognitive exercise interventions to reduce pain in this disease. This approach would offer an easily implemented and affordable way to encourage and maintain use of these interventions by patients virtually indefinitely through our remote access technology. The study findings may help VA clinicians provide optimal care for the many veterans with Parkinson’s disease and chronic pain.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is an urgent need to understand mechanisms that lead to T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (T-ALL) relapse. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: The engineering of living cells and microbes is a transformative approach to cancer therapy, as cells can be genetically programmed to intelligently sense and respond to environments potentially leading to improved safety and efficacy of therapies. However, the vast number of rapidly engineered therapies far outpaces the throughput of animal-based testing regimes, thus creating a major bottleneck for clinical translation. Leveraging synthetic biology tools and a high-throughput bacteria-spheroid platform, the objective of this proposal is to rapidly optimize tumor-homing S. tyhpimurium to express therapeutics locally and specifically in tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating and fatal neurodegenerative condition, and environmental exposures are hypothesized to play a role in disease pathogenesis and progression. Our goal is to identify environmental pollutant exposures that contribute to ALS disease risk and survival when accounting for genetic susceptibility to understand how these exposures play a role in ALS pathogenesis. This work will have wide-ranging implications on ALS disease prevention and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative This project seeks to clarify the etiology of key internalizing psychiatric disorders and closely associated functional medical disorders by applying a range of methods from epidemiology, genetic epidemiology and molecular genetics to the large informative population-based cohort in the Netherlands called Lifelines. We will attempt to understand the origins of the comorbidity between these disorders and how genes and environment contribute to their development. To meet these goals, we will apply advanced statistical methods to a unique set of epidemiological and molecular genetic resources.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Suicidal ideation and suicidal behavior are increasingly serious public health concerns in the United States. We propose the development of a sleep-based, integrated, multi-method model of proximal suicide risk emphasizing near-term and proximal measures of risk and derived from a combination of intensive ecological momentary assessment, digital phenotyping, laboratory-based behavioral assessments, peripheral psychophysiological biomarkers, and cross-sectional measures including clinical interviews and self-report measures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Insects are the primary vectors for many pathogens causing human disease and consequently contribute to the death of millions of people annually. Blood-feeding insects locate their human hosts through their exquisitely sensitive olfactory system, but the molecular mechanisms underlying insect odor detection are poorly understood. This project will elucidate the structural basis for modulation of the conserved insect odorant receptor, Orco, providing an inroad to rationally design novel classes of potent repellent chemicals that ward off biting insects and prevent the transmission of insect-borne disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: In Specific Aim 1 of this grant, we will leverage the power of whole genome sequencing and structured bioinformatic analysis to identify novel deafness-associated genes in carefully selected patient cohorts. In Specific Aim 2, we will resolve hidden heritability in known deafness-associated genes by targeted analysis of non-coding regions and select missense and synonymous variants. The completion of these two specific aims will improve the clinical care of persons with hearing loss and provide a foundation for gene therapies that target specific types of genetic deafness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Learning impairments and memory confusion are symptoms of many connected neurological disorders (major depression, anxiety and post-traumatic stress disorders, schizophrenia, autism, Alzheimer’s disease or temporal lobe epilepsy) that also show disorganization of a brain center critical for memory specificity: the dentate gyrus. The goal of the proposed research is to determine how the dentate gyrus normally works to limit confusion by measuring the activity of its input and output neurons in mice forming and recalling memories of similar experiences. Uncovering the brain computations underlying normal memory storage and retrieval will offer new avenues and targets to treat memory impairments in numerous conditions.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Depression is a leading cause of disability worldwide and is more commonly seen in individual’s post-spinal cord injury (SCI) than in the general population. Depression post-SCI impacts an individuals’ quality of life and recovery. It has been reported that among Veterans with an SCI, those without depression live longer than those with depression. Thus, depression must be treated appropriately. Repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) is an FDA-approved treatment for depression, but dosing is based on a motor response in the thumb. Over half of individuals with SCI have some degree of arm or hand impairment, so these individuals might not be eligible for rTMS, or they may receive the wrong dose. [This study proposes secondary data analysis of a completed trial and a clinical trial in individuals with depression post-SCI to assess the anti-depressant effect of a novel technique to dose rTMS that does not require a motor response.] By gaining a better understanding of the application of rTMS for depression post-SCI, we aim to advance the rehabilitative care of Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative  Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is a neuropsychiatric condition that causes enormous human suffering and is thought to result from a complex interplay of genetic and the environmental factors. Our goal in this study is to learn more about what precise genetic factors influence an individuals risk for OCD. We propose to do this by resequencing the protein coding portion of the genome in a large number of OCD subjects and matched controls.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Kaposi’s sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) is an AIDS-associated pathogen and the most common cause of cancer in untreated AIDS patients. This proposal investigates the impact of the RNA- sensing cell intrinsic immune system on KSHV infection. Defining mechanisms by which KSHV is recognized by the immune system, as well as how KSHV combats its recognition, will provide fundamental knowledge regarding how KSHV interacts with the host cell.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Current lung cancer screening eligibility guidelines use only age and smoking history, were developed in a civilian population and miss the majority of Veterans who develop lung cancer. Veterans suffer from lung cancer at higher rates than the rest of the United States population and have unique exposures due to their military service. This proposal will define Veteran-specific lung cancer risk factors, develop a screening eligibility model for Veterans and compare that model to current eligibility risk models and criteria. We will use linked Department of Defense and VA Electronic Health Records to discover novel phenotypes associated with lung cancer risk. We will then build a Veteran-specific lung cancer screening model using standard, machine and deep learning methods and compare it to existing screening models. With nationally recognized leaders in machine learning, Veteran’s health data, lung cancer screening modeling, and health services research, we are uniquely positioned to use artificial intelligence to improve lung cancer screening for Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Narrative  Ototoxicity is one of the major side effects of cisplatin, a widely used anti-cancer drug. Cisplatin- induced nitration and downregulation of LMO4, a molecular adaptor protein, appears to mediate its ototoxic effects. The characterization of the regulatory role of LMO4 nitration in cisplatin-mediated ototoxicity is expected to reveal the biological significance of this novel molecular mechanism and facilitate the development of effective therapeutic approaches to prevent the ototoxic effects of cisplatin.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD) is a common and chronically disabling disorder in youth, and there is a pressing need for studies that shed light on its functional neurobiology. Our proposed combination of innovative multi-modal functional imaging applications (¹H fMRS and fMRI) will identify dysfunction related to brain glutamate modulation and network dynamics facilitating a better understanding of specifics of this dysfunctional neurobiology. The resultant advances in mechanistic understanding are expected to motivate more effective and precise treatments for this severe form of childhood psychopathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV-1 remains a substantial public health burden: antiretroviral therapy (ART) is capable of suppressing virus, but not curing infected individuals. Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T-cell gene therapies have induced long term remission in cancer patients, but must address inherent challenges to enable long-term ART-free remission in people living with HIV (PLWH). Our goal in this project is to increase the potency, durability, and feasibility of CAR-T cell therapies for HIV-1 in the nonhuman primate model, in support of future clinical studies in PLWH.

Here we propose to study a new mechanism which allows immune cells at the initial site of a pathogen infection to warn and prepare far away tissues for a possible attack.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Events in early life involving the gut microbiota can have an important impact on immune development altering the risk of immune related disorders. For example, it has been reported that the route of delivery, feeding, hygiene, and antibiotics, in early life can modify the risk of inflammatory bowel disease and allergic outcomes later in life. This proposal seeks greater understanding of the gut commensal bacteria that impact immune development and address whether the extent of this interaction dictates durable immune homeostasis and resistance from pathologic immune outcomes in later life. These data on physiologic immune development may inform on risk of developing inflammatory bowel disease or other immune conditions in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Blood clotting that occurs in large arteries causes heart attacks and stroke, while clotting in small vessels can cause organ failure in the setting of infection. Current therapies to treat these thrombotic diseases are complicated by bleeding and recurrent clotting. We have identified a new layer of control of blood clotting mediated by thiol isomerases and will study the role of these enzymes in thrombus formation to identify better diagnostic and therapeutic approaches for the management of common, life-threatening clotting events.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will lead to improved insight into the genetic basis of hematologic traits and red blood cell disorders. Finding the risk factors and causes of these disorders or traits will lead to new insights into why they occur, and, potentially, how they can be treated. Our project will create a renewable resource for the scientific community for research into human red blood cell production and how this goes awry in disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type 1 diabetes (T1D) is a chronic autoimmune disorder that affects more than 1% of population worldwide. Insulin as a standard treatment has major long-term complications; therefore, the development of novel approaches to prevent and treat T1D is a significant therapeutic goal. The primary objective of this proposal is to develop an immunomodulatory protocol that prevents the rejection of pancreatic allogeneic islets for the treatment of T1D. If effective, this approach will have immediate and important implications for the use of allogeneic islets for the treatment of T1D in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Immunotherapy activates a patient's immune system to detect and kill cancer cells by recognizing the mutated proteins they express, called neoantigens. In this proposal, we investigate what these neoantigen look like to our immune system and how this information can be used to improve neoantigen-targeted cancer vaccines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sluggish cognitive tempo (SCT) symptoms, characterized by excessive daydreaming, slowed thinking, and mental confusion and fogginess, are distinct from other psychopathologies and associated with functional impairment. SCT symptoms are also strongly associated with internalizing symptoms and suicide risk, yet the absence of rigorous longitudinal research makes the directionality, mechanisms, and vulnerabilities of this association unknown. Findings from this study will advance theoretical models of SCT, position SCT within broader models of psychopathology, and provide avenues for targeted clinical assessment and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE All cell types use changes in Ca2+ concentration to control their physiology, and regulated activation of intracellular Ca2+ channels plays a key role in cellular Ca2+ homeostasis. One important family of intracellular Ca2+-permeable channels - two-pore channels (TPCs) - reside within endosomes and lysosomes where they mediate Ca2+ release in response to the second messenger nicotinic acid adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NAADP). Here, our team has identified a long sought, key component in NAADP activation of TPCs, and we will define how activation of the TPC complex is physiologically regulated.

PHR: NARRATIVE Increasing evidence supports the role of arsenic exposure in diabetes development. This study can provide insight into novel pathways of arsenic related diabetes, identify prevention interventions, and inform recommendations for arsenic levels in water and food.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Serious mental illness, including schizophrenia and bipolar disorder are common, complex and debilitating psychiatric disorders that carry considerable morbidity, mortality, and personal and societal cost. The overarching goal of our proposal is to leverage multiscale genomics and other functional omics (gene expression and epigenome regulation) data and perform fine mapping to detect and validate causal variants, transcripts and regulatory sequences in serious mental illness. The proposed work will bridge the gap in understanding the link among the effects of risk variants on enhancer activity and transcript expression at the gene- and isoform-level, thus illuminating at least some of the molecular mechanisms that underlie serious mental illness and providing new targets for future therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Improved malaria surveillance techniques that offer higher resolution information about local and regional malaria epidemiology will be necessary to more efficiently target malaria control interventions as we work toward malaria elimination. Parasite DNA and host antibodies present in biological samples collected as part of routine surveillance activities can offer useful information about malaria burden that is not captured by routine surveillance metrics – however, there is limited data on how to best apply molecular data to improve malaria surveillance. This project hopes to fill that gap by providing an understanding of which markers are most useful to enhance routine surveillance data at the community level by appropriately risk stratifying sub-national regions over space and time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Changes in physiologic pH, particularly acidotic signals, accompany a variety of biological processes and clinical pathologies. The goal of our proposed research program is to pursue an in-depth understanding of how these pH signals regulate the biology and pharmacology of G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs), the largest and most therapeutically targeted class of transmembrane receptors in the human genome. The three program areas of this proposal will identify pH-selective agonists, inhibitors, modulators, drugs, and conformationally-selective nanobody probes for regulating and studying numerous human GPCRs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE This research project will advance human health by identifying risk genes and biological mechanisms that could affect individuals’ genetic vulnerability to a wide array of psychiatric disorders. Understanding of this shared genetic basis is central to decipher the etiologic and nosologic relationships of psychiatric disorders. The clinical and pharmaceutical impact of this study is also particularly high and will lead to the prioritization of genetic targets that could yield most broad and profound impact transcending traditional diagnostic boundaries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposal seeks to investigate the role of the influenza-induced pathogenic IL-17 response in the nasopharynx, leading to the transition of colonizing Streptococcus pneumoniae (Spn) into a pathogen. We hypothesize that the nasopharyngeal IL-17 response contributes to influenza-mediated hyper-inflammation and dysregulated barrier integrity in the nasopharynx, which allows colonizing Spn to outgrow and disseminate/invade to sterile tissues, establishing disease. The proposed research plan will lead to the development of an IL-17-based, novel interventional approach to mitigate inflammation and Spn pathogenesis during a co-infection with influenza virus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antibiotics are one of the most common interventions for critically ill patients; however, antibiotic resistance is on the rise and few new medications are currently in development. Immediate innovative solutions are needed to preserve and improve the effectiveness of existing drugs. We propose a series of studies to develop more accurate, individualized-dosing models for anti-pseudomonal beta-lactam antibiotics, designed to improve the treatment of infections and limit the development of bacterial resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE C. difficile infections (CDI) and inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) are on the rise in children and commonly co- exist. This proposal seeks to better understand the determinants and sequelae of CDI and C. difficile colonization in children with IBD. Knowledge of these factors and their interactions can then be used in clinical settings to improve the treatment and outcomes associated with C. difficile in pediatric IBD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative. This study will examine short-term or proximal biological risk profiles for suicidal behavior in stress response and inflammatory pathways, peripherally and in the brain, and examine familial and nonfamilial biological mechanisms underlying suicidal behavior in young adults at acute risk. This study will improve our understanding of familial and nonfamilial biological mechanisms for suicidal behavior to better separate long- term and short-term risk biological phenotypes, which will help guide risk detection and novel just-in-time approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This career development award is focused on developing the necessary skills, through mentored training, to independently investigate sex specific effects of air pollutants on respiratory health. This project will significantly enhance understanding of sex specific regulation of respiratory immune function in response to wood smoke exposure using in vivo and translational models with immediate human relevance. Increasing our understanding of differential respiratory immune responses in males and females to air pollutants will potentially identify new targets for preventative measure development or treatments against adverse responses and will decrease the burden on public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The immune system maintains a careful balance between protecting the body from infectious pathogens and the collateral damage that may arise as a result of too much inflammation, particularly autoimmunity. Interleukin (IL)-17 is an important mediator of immune inflammation and protects against various microorganisms. However, an overabundance of IL-17 signaling contributes to the pathogenesis of autoimmunity. Antibodies that block IL-17 are now approved for psoriasis, but this treatment may put patients at risk for developing infections. Although we know quite a bit about which cells make IL-17, the molecular process of IL-17 signaling through its receptor is poorly defined. This proposal focuses on how the regulation of IL-17-driven mRNA expression occurs at a molecular level and how this serves to control autoimmune pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Antibiotic-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) persistently colonize humans, which represents the key risk factor for community- and hospital-acquired infections with poor clinical outcomes. Capitalizing on new insights into S. aureus immune evasion, this proposal combines the skills of three investigators to generate human monoclonal antibodies that neutralize staphylococcal protein A (SpA), resist bacterial interference with antibody effector functions and promote opsonophagocytic killing of MRSA. Preclinical testing will identify antibodies with product profiles of 1) promoting broad spectrum antibody responses against MRSA, 2) clearing S. aureus from colonized individuals, 3) inducing persistent immunity to colonization and invasive disease, and 4) improving the outcome of MRSA bloodstream infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Statistical methods used in agreement studies contain fundamental flaws that hinder the complete development and understanding of biomarkers and diagnostic tests. As we have entered into an era where neuroimaging biomarkers are warranted for use in the diagnostic strategy of Alzheimer’s disease, these statistical methods have never been more important. This project develops a novel statistical methodology for evaluating inter- and intra-rater agreement upon which diagnostic tests and biomarkers are evaluated, and, in doing so, will identify clinical, provider and neuroimaging features important for obtaining an Alzheimer’s disease diagnosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Osteoarthritis (OA) is the most common joint disorder in the United States, but the mechanisms leading to OA are still unclear. To better understand the influence of genetic and environmental factors on OA pathogenesis, this research will use a large panel of differentiated human chondrocytes to identify inter-individual variation in gene expression and epigenetic responses to biomechanical strain treatments that induce OA phenotypes. This work will yield insight into the genetic basis of how biomechanical stress contributes to human OA and may inform efforts to screen for and treat this disorder.

PHR: Aging and obesity are the most significant risk factors for the development of type 2 diabetes and metabolic disease. In this proposal, we test the hypothesis that age-dependent changes in a key regulator of glucose metabolism leads to changes in adipocyte function that increase the risk of disease. Completion of this work will enhance our understanding of how adipocyte biology changes over the lifespan.

ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Myocarditis is a rare but important adverse event in some individuals following vaccination against COVID-19. Recently published work by the Principal Investigator demonstrates that high-impact, putatively damaging variants in cardiomyocyte genes increase risk for viral and idiopathic myocarditis. The present proposal will investigate Mendelian human genetic variation and immune profiles in patients with vaccine-associated myocarditis, to determine susceptibility and pathophysiologic processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Pyroptosis is a type of regulated lytic cell death that is mediated by members of the gasdermin family that assemble membrane pores upon cleavage by proteases. Gasdermin E (GSDME)-mediated pyroptosis and cytokine release play crucial roles in host defense against viral or bacterial infections as well as in autoimmune disorders and tissue injury. This proposal aims to investigate the mechanisms of GSDME autoinhibition and recognition by apoptotic caspases, which may facilitate the development of specific inhibitors targeting pyroptosis and apoptosis pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because of the rapidly increasing aging population, and with it the significant increase in age-related malignancies worldwide. We propose that 15-PGDH is a novel therapeutic target to enhance hematopoietic function during aging both at steady state and during regeneration, which has significant implications for the treatment of various hematologic diseases including myelofibrosis and myelodysplastic syndromes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Remote nomadic groups in northwestern Kenya near the border to Plasmodium vivax-endemic Ethiopia are particularly at risk of contracting P. vivax, but remain largely outside of public health surveillance or programming. We will leverage samples and data from a recent study of malaria in nomadic pastoralists to try to understand the potential for emerging P. vivax in this population and the region, and determine whether this group represents an important sentinel surveillance population for P. vivax emergence and control. Findings from this study will generate evidence to guide Kenya’s National Malaria Control Programme and similar regions of Sub-Saharan Africa as they confront the possibility of growing endemic P. vivax transmission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The present study focuses on a novel concept of the function of aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AhR) and its repressor (AhRR) as environmental sensors modifying the immune response. This study investigates the interference of the AhR and AhRR with key regulators of cellular processes (Toll-like receptors and NFκB) in immune cells. The current study is critical in understanding the biological and pathological functions of the AhR and AhRR in the immune system and its role in immunological disorders like allergy, autoimmune and infectious diseases. This work will help to understand the mechanism how environmental toxicants disturb critical functions of the immune system and have an effect on human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Radial chromosome formation involves the fusion of two unrelated chromosomes and most likely results in the death, transformation or aberrant aging of the cell in which radials occur. How radial chromosomes form in human cells, however, is not clear and has been the subject of many conflicting studies. Here, we demonstrate that the alternative non-homologous end joining pathway of DNA double-strand break repair is required for human radial formation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Right hemisphere strokes result in language production changes that are different than those found in left hemisphere strokes. Yet, language production after a right hemisphere stroke is less frequently the focus of scientific inquiry. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will advance knowledge concerning the relationship between locus of lesion and discourse production characteristics needed for the development of measurement, evaluation, and treatment methods for language production deficits after a right hemisphere brain damage (RHD).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: NARRATIVE Harnessing Age-Associated B Cells for a Universal Influenza Vaccine for the Aged. Recently we found that a unique age-associated B cell (ABC) population that includes naïve IgD+ B cells and generates a unique extrafollicular effector B cell response to influenza infection, is, in the aged, the predominant response producing Ab-secreting cells and Ab to new infections. We will determine the extent to which ABC generate lung and nasal tissue-resident Ab-secreting effectors that give rise to resting memory B cells and long-lived Ab-secreting cells and will determine if vaccines can elicit these responses and if these unique memory cells provide protective immunity. This will inform strategies to make a Universal influenza vaccine that is protective in the aged.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) are especially vulnerable to optic nerve damage. Our new study shows that silencing lincRNAs in RGCs promotes strong neuroprotection after optic nerve injury. We will use viral strategies to examine the extent to which distinct lincRNAs regulate RGC survival in mouse models of optic neuropathy, and investigate the underlying molecular mechanisms.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: NARRATIVE Preeclampsia is a major clinical condition in Women’s Reproductive Health and this proposal seeks to introduce cutting-edge research on this devastating pregnancy complication with long term maternal and fetal heath consequences. Preeclampsia needs an effective treatment as delivery is the only therapy currently available clinically. The Principal Investigator and his collaborators have proposed a novel and focused research proposal to understand mechanistic heterogeneity of preeclampsia and to introduce an inexpensive, readily available intervention to improve pregnancy outcomes and maternal-child health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative Cell migration is a critical process involved in diseases and cell-based therapies. Unfortunately, methods that can track this migration non-invasively in living subjects are inaccurate, limiting their use for pre-clinical and clinical research. This project proposes a new approach that can follow the migration of individual cells, dynamically, in real time, in 3D, anywhere within the body.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Early life stress (ELS) causes abnormal connections in circuits that regulate anxiety in mice and humans. Exactly how ELS alters these connections and how these changes contribute to elevated anxiety are questions that are difficult to study in humans. In this application we present preliminary data showing that circuits that regulate anxiety are refined during development by cells called microglia and that exposure to ELS interferes with this process leading to elevated levels of anxiety in mice exposed to ELS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Project Narrative-Relevance to Public Health The threats by bacteria against antimicrobial agents is a challenging issue in treating infectious diseases. We propose to innovate novel macromolecular compositions that possess local facial amphiphilicity attached from a flexible macromolecular chain, which overcomes the limits of existing host-defense peptides and antimicrobial polymers. The proposed research will have a significant impact on advancing the development of novel antimicrobial agents for the success of multidrug-resistant bacteria-associated infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative A-to-I RNA editing is a very prevalent type of RNA modification in human cells. An increasing number of A-to-I editing sites is being identified in various organisms, but mostly having unknown functional roles or regulatory mechanisms. The proposed research aims to develop and apply bioinformatic and experimental approaches to study the function and regulation of RNA editing in human brain, providing a basis for future studies on how RNA editing may contribute to human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative  Pseudomonas aeruginosa is an important opportunistic pathogen that is the principal cause of morbidity and mortality in cystic fibrosis patients and one of the most common causes of ventilator-associated and hospital-acquired pneumonia. Our studies are expected to reveal how two post-transcriptional regulators that are essential for the virulence of this organism control the expression of target genes. This work has the potential to reveal novel therapeutic targets for the prevention and treatment of P. aeruginosa infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Mitochondrial dysfunction has been associated with aging and with virtually all age-related diseases (e.g., neurodegenerative disease, cardiovascular disease), however it remains unclear how this dysfunction arises and if it truly causes these conditions. This objective of this project is to use state-of-the-art human genetics approaches to understand (1) the association landscape linking mitochondrial dysfunction and age-related disease, (2) if this dysfunction is causal for the disease, and (3) the genetic architecture underlying the dysfunction itself. This proposal has the potential to provide clarity on the mechanisms underlying aging, age- related disease and mitochondrial dysfunction, potentially nominating new therapeutic targets and strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Cortical visual prosthetics (CVPs) aim to restore some degree of sight or a functional analogue for people who are blind, potentially offering life-altering benefits via a distinctive, brain-based approach. CVP research raises complex questions about potential impacts on identity, autonomy, quality of life, and other dimensions of non- clinical risk and benefit, as well as important considerations of access, avoidance of group harms to the blind community, and how to conceptualize and measure research success. This project will identify and address ethics and policy dimensions of next-generation CVP systems informed by the perspectives of key stakeholders (researchers and research participants), helping to maximize individual and social benefits of CVP research while minimizing its risks and providing values-based guidance for development of neurotechnologies aiming to restore vision and other physiological functions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: This project seeks to understand the role of EWSR1 to participate in the activity of a fusion protein, EWS-FLI1, and drive Ewing sarcoma development by involving a process known as phase separation, creating a semi-stable molecular scaffold. Our working model is that these molecular scaffolds localize the machinery for transcription to active genes and aberrant molecular scaffolds introduced by the EWS-FLI1 fusion can titrate away EWSR1 activity. This proposal uses a proteomics, genomics, and biochemical approaches to investigate the ability of EWS-FLI1 to redirect EWSR1 activity in the cell.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Years of research have shown that disease frequently accompanies changes in the glycome. We hypothesize that this stems from a previously unrecognized pathway of dynamic and targeted regulation of protein glycosylation which serves to modulate form and function to meet the immediate biological need. Our proposal is centered on a key enzyme responsible for the addition of sialic acids on glycoproteins, whose action appears to fall well outside of the canonical secretory pathway to modulate sialylation of B cell-secreted IgG antibodies. The action of this enzyme, the cellular microenvironment necessary to support its function, and its role in inflammatory disease will be investigated as an exemplar of a novel glycosylation pathway for glycoproteins outside of the originating cell. We believe that this will pave the way towards the manipulation of the glycome to influence disease progression and susceptibility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Alterations in neuronal and glia activity during ageing have been associated with cognitive decline, seizures, neurodegeneration, and other age-related neuropathology. We found that microglia, the resident macrophages of the brain, play a critical role in protecting the brain from aberrant neuronal activation via a novel adenosine- dependent mechanism that appears to be attenuated in the aging brain. In this proposal we will address the mechanism of microglia-controlled neuronal activity regulation and its potential contribution to age-dependent alterations by integrating highly specific genetic and molecular approaches with assessment of mouse behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project will be the first study to evaluate changes in subclinical measures of atherosclerosis over time from childhood to adulthood and assess the impact of lifetime air pollution exposure on early phases of atherosclerosis progression. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative A significant obstacle to the successful treatment for cancer is identifying and eradicating treatment-resistant tumor cells, the so-called tumor-initiating cells (TICs). Our incomplete understanding of the complexity of the TIC niche microenvironment and the plasticity of TICs is an outstanding barrier to improving therapeutic efficacy, and thus without rational treatment strategies, drug resistance will likely remain a life-threatening problem for cancer patients. Here we will investigate the cellular interactions between TICs and their supporting cells to find novel avenues to destabilize TIC functions and improve treatment efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will determine how the immune cells of the brain, known as microglia, change the synaptic connections between nerve cells in the brain. We will test the hypothesis that microglia engulf and remodel a lattice-like structure between cells known as the extracellular matrix. This novel mechanism could help explain how immune signals can impact the formation of long-term memories.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer cells that are deficient in homologous recombination (HR) rely on an alternative pathway, Alt-EJ, to repair DNA breaks induced by replication. As a consequence, inhibition of Alt-EJ is lethal in these cancers, and could be used as a therapeutic approach to eliminate HR-deficient cancers. We have identified the nuclease APE2 as an uncharacterized central player of Alt-EJ, and we will determine its molecular function and its potential as a novel therapeutic target.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) symptoms are often elicited by environmental stimuli that were not directly present during trauma; therefore, understanding how fear spreads to non-trauma associated stimuli is paramount to PTSD treatment. Recently, we found that memories are temporally linked by overlapping neural ensembles and that this temporal linking permits the spread of fear to neutral stimuli occurring days prior to an aversive event. The experiments in this proposal will leverage the most cutting-edge in vivo imaging with Miniscopes, in vivo tagging and in vivo chemogenetic techniques to dissect the circuit mechanisms underlying the temporal linking of aversive events in an effort to advance novel treatments for PTSD.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative The Forum on Drug Discovery, Development, and Translation (the Forum) of the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine (the National Academies) was created in 2005 by the National Academies Board on Health Sciences Policy to provide a unique platform for dialogue and collaboration among thought leaders and stakeholders in government, academia, industry, foundations, and patient advocacy with an interest in improving the system of drug discovery, development, and translation. The Forum brings together leaders from private-sector sponsors of biomedical and clinical research, federal agencies sponsoring and regulating biomedical and clinical research, the academic community, and patients, and in doing so serves to educate the policy community about issues where science and policy intersect.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Kingella kingae has emerged as a leading cause of septic arthritis, osteomyelitis, sepsis, and other invasive diseases in young children between 6 months and 4 years of age and is associated with significant short-term and long-term morbidity. Reports that an increasing percentage of K. kingae isolates are resistant to β-lactams and other antibiotics raise concern about approaches to treatment in the future and underscore the need for an effective approach to disease prevention. The overarching objective of this proposal is to understand the biosynthesis, surface anchoring, pathogenic properties, immunogenicity, and vaccine potential of the K. kingae exopolysaccharide, which is critical for full K. kingae virulence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Urinary tract infections (UTIs) are among the most common bacterial infections both in the hospital and community setting, and complicated UTIs are severe, life-threatening, and typically caused by multidrug resistant Enterobacteriaceae, including carbapenem-resistant Enterobacteriaceae. The extensive spread of CRE has prompted the CDC to designate it as an Urgent Threat pathogen. This project seeks to develop a mechanistically novel IV and PO administered therapeutic to treat uncomplicated UTIs and complicated UTIs caused by antibiotic susceptible and multidrug-resistant Enterobacteriaceae, including extended spectrum beta-lactamase (ESBL) producers and carbapenem-resistant Enterobacteriaceae (CRE).

PHR: Candida glabrata is the second major cause of candidemias owing in part to its ability to develop high level resistance to azole antifungal drugs. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Emerging infections caused by antibiotic resistant Acinetobacter baumannii pose important public health problems. Of particular concern are ventilator-associated pneumonia and blood stream infections that may lead to sepsis. This proposal seeks to understand the mechanism by which some A. baumannii strains inhibit the growth of other Acinetobacter isolates and with this knowledge identify new ways to treat A. baumannii drug resistant infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This project will compile the most comprehensive set of records on drinking water quality in the US and link to individual-level administrative Medicare data to study how drinking water pollution shapes health outcomes, including hospitalizations, emergency department admissions, and mortality, among older Americans. The findings will provide insight on whether the health benefits of drinking water investments exceed their costs and whether policies to improve drinking water quality benefit groups unequally. The project will yield a public-use national dataset with information on drinking water system service territories and water quality to catalyze research on drinking water and health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Malaria is one of the most burdensome diseases in human history and continues to exert enormous suffering on a global scale. Elimination efforts have made great progress, but it is becoming apparent that these efforts will need an infection-blocking vaccine to truly extinguish the disease. In this proposal, we explore a newly identified phenomenon of intracellularly targeted anti-malaria antibodies which will not only define new mechanisms of immunity, but create a path to an entirely new avenue of malaria vaccine development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: In this study, my lab will reveal the mechanism of action of second-generation daptomycin antibiotics that will circumvent bacterial resistance. This study will help face one of the biggest threats to global health and reduce mortalities that result from bacterial resistance against current antibiotics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sneathia vaginalis is very difficult to culture and detect; however, contemporary culture-independent techniques have recently elucidated it as an invasive pathogen capable of causing amnionitis and sepsis in mothers and neonates and it is strongly associated with preterm birth. Through this project, we will break ground in the study of the pathogenesis of a pore-forming toxin produced by this uncharacterized bacterial species through the measurement of antibodies against the toxin in mothers and neonates, characterization of the role of the toxin in fetal membrane damage, and development of a murine model of uterine invasion during pregnancy. This addresses the NIH Healthy People 2020 Objective “Reduce the Rate of Fetal and Infant Deaths”.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Bacterial persisters are cells that exhibit multidrug tolerance and are likely responsible for clinical recurrence of infections. Persisters are challenging to study as they are difficult to identify in bacterial populations despite occurring in almost all major pathogens. In this work, innovative biophysical approaches will be developed to isolate persisters and study how persistence emerges, which is expected to help combat antibiotic resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Apicomplexan parasites are the causative agents of a number of important human diseases including malaria, cryptosporidiosis, and toxoplasmosis. These parasites divide through an unusual paradigm in which daughter cells are fully assembled inside the mother cell and remain coupled to one another through a poorly understood organelle called the residual body. Our goal is to use a recently identified ubiquitin ligase as a tool to understand how the Toxoplasma residual body sequesters turnover of essential complexes to prevent destruction of growing daughter cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: HIV-1 spreads mainly through mucosal exposures. Dominant in mucosal secretions, IgA has long been the class of antibodies desired at the portal of entrance to block infection; however, anti-HIV-1 IgA antibodies have been understudied. We therefore propose to identify and functionally characterize anti-HIV-1 IgA bNAbs and ADCP that are highly relevant to HIV-1 prevention and therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV is a top cause of death in sub-Saharan Africa, but rates of new infections are declining, so that HIV prevention services avert fewer infections per client served, and HIV testing services lead to fewer new HIV- positive diagnoses per test conducted. To increase the efficiency of these services, a rapid point-of-care test for recent HIV infection has been developed and is being used in over two-thirds of people newly diagnosed with HIV in Zambia in order to identify other people at risk or living with undiagnosed HIV in their social networks. We will use mathematical modeling to determine whether recency testing can help Zambia achieve epidemic goals, is a good use of limited resources, and can be improved upon using “big data” methods for greater precision, ease-of-use, and avoidance of potentially stigmatizing data elements.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Antibiotic resistant infections pose a public health crisis requiring new approaches to antibiotic development. In this proposal we will develop and apply genome scale screens to identify virulence factors that can serve as novel antibiotic targets in the human and animal pathogen Listeria monocytogenes. Upon completion of these aims we will have a high value target list for novel antibiotic discovery, will have defined novel virulence factor functions in immune evasion and will have identified potential synergies between antibiotic therapies and protective immune responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Non-human primates are excellent models of the human immune system, and previous pre-clinical studies in adult rhesus macaques have directly informed the choice of vaccine route, schedule and/or adjuvant for clinical assessment of malaria vaccine candidates. However, despite infants and children being the target population for malaria vaccines, no infant non-human primate malaria challenge model currently exists for vaccine evaluation. This project will develop a novel infant rhesus malaria challenge model and use this model to define how age at immunization and features of the developing infant immune system shape the response to malaria vaccination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Coxiella burnetii is an obligate intracellular pathogen that causes human Q fever. We propose to elucidate Coxiella’s strategies to manipulate host lipid metabolism by regulating inter-organelle interactions in the host cell. Completion of this study will greatly advance our understanding on Coxiella subverts host cell processes, which could reveal potential therapeutic targets for Q fever treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Postpartum depression is prevalent and associated with profound negative effects on mothers and their offspring, making the need to better understand risk processes and inform prevention efforts urgent. We will conduct multimethod intensive longitudinal assessments across the peripartum period to examine trajectories of positive valence systems (PVS) function, examine whether PVS influence mother–infant interactions, and explore neurobiological and psychosocial PVS processes shaping risk for postpartum depression. This study will have relevance for understanding the dynamic interplay of factors shaping positive valence systems and depression risk, with implications for determining when and how to intervene to prevent postpartum depression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative This project seeks to clarify the mechanisms by which alcohol use disorder is related to risk of suicidal behavior, namely through psychiatric illness, medical comorbidity, and aggregate genetic liability. We will apply a range of novel and sophisticated methodological approaches using data from Swedish national registries. Given close parallels between alcohol use disorder and suicidal behavior across Sweden and the US, these findings have the potential to improve risk assessment, prevention, and intervention.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE More than 2.7 million military service members have deployed to Iraq or Afghanistan since 2001. Compared to non-deployed personnel, Veterans of these conflicts have a higher prevalence of exertional dyspnea and other respiratory symptoms which may relate to exposure to inhalational irritants during deployment. While many such Veterans are ultimately diagnosed with common respiratory diseases, constrictive bronchiolitis (CB) has been reported in up 78% of Veterans with unexplained dyspnea who undergo surgical lung biopsy. In this study, we will determine long-term outcomes in Veterans with deployment-related constrictive bronchiolitis (DR-CB), investigate specific metals which drive ongoing activation of the immune system and lung damage, and rigorously assess cutting-edge diagnostic modalities which may improve our ability to diagnose DR-CB non-invasively.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative for HOPE study: Women with cardiovascular disease (CVD) have the highest risk of adverse maternal and neonatal outcomes and in the US, which has the worst maternal outcomes and greatest racial disparities in the industrial world, there is a lack of evidence estimating patients’ risks or how best to structure Cardio-Obstetrics (COB) care. The HOPE study has coalesced the nation’s top COB experts to prospectively enroll 1000 pregnant women with CVD to identify patient risk factors for adverse clinical and quality of life outcomes, and to rigorously test what structures and processes of care best optimize outcomes. Through our dissemination partners and engagement with professional organizations and patient-advocacy groups, we will develop novel strategies to elevate the care of pregnant people with CVD and reduce disparities by defining the optimal structures of COB care, guiding the development of performance measures for quality, and by supporting the creation of novel risk prediction models to support the creation of risk-based protocols to optimize outcomes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: THE FRAGILE FAMILIES AND CHILD WELLBEING STUDY – YOUNG ADULTHOOD Project Narrative The Fragile Families and Child Wellbeing Study is the US’s longest-running contemporary national birth cohort study and, with age 27 data, will allow researchers to examine how experiences and exposures across childhood, adolescence, and early adulthood influence health and wellbeing in young adulthood. The sample is very diverse, allowing researchers to examine racial, ethnic, and socioeconomic disparities in health and wellbeing. Further, the multigenerational nature of the study will allow researchers to examine intergenerational mobility and persistence of a wide range of health and wellbeing outcomes.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: There are 650,000 invasive non-surgical interventional cardiology, interventional radiology and gastrointestinal endoscopy procedures performed annually resulting in 22,000 emergency department visits and 25,500 admissions. Adverse events may cause up half of this post-procedure utilization and are poorly understood; presently, there is no patient safety surveillance in the VA for invasive procedures. This IIR proposal addresses the VA's urgent need for targeted surveillance tools to detect adverse events and inform quality improvement initiatives at the facility and specialty levels. The proposed work will test two hypothesized opportunities to update care guidelines or design quality initiatives to mitigate patient harm using surveillance data: whether the patient received inappropriate antibiotics and whether an anesthesiologist was involved in the procedure. We will also examine disparities in care processes in each specialty. Surveillance data will inform policy directives by operational partners from each specialty as well as Pharmacy Benefits Management.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Surgical site infections are common and morbid; however, they are preventable with administration of evidence- based antimicrobial prophylaxis. In 2005, in the setting of high rates of non-compliance with antimicrobial prophylaxis guidelines, the VA implemented the Surgical Care Improvement Project (SCIP). SCIP included public reporting of evidenced-based antimicrobial guideline compliance metrics in high-risk surgeries and led to high rates of adoption of evidence-based practices (>95%). The program was retired in 2015, as the manual measurement and reporting process was costly with limited expected additional benefit. This IIR will use novel electronic algorithms to measure compliance with SCIP metrics over time, and stakeholder feedback to identify intervention strategies to sustain compliance. The aims are guided by the Dynamic Sustainability Framework and will address 1) the sustainability and spread of practice changes achieved by SCIP, 2) factors influencing sustainability, and 3) implementation strategies to test in a future Hybrid III trial to improve compliance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Early developmental exposure to antidepressants such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) has been associated with an increased incidence of ASDs in offspring. Determining how serotonin signals in the developing brain is a key first step to understanding how SSRIs alter serotonin system and may cause ASDs. A better understanding about the central roles of serotonin signaling in brain function will be significant and has the potential to direct new therapeutic strategies for neurodevelopmental disorders involving serotonin dysregulation, such as ASDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project narrative This grant proposes an innovative contrast agent - TaOx nanoparticles – and an X-ray computed tomography method for imaging implantable biomaterials, in vivo. Our goals here are to determine 1) the in vitro and in vivo biological effects of these new contrast agent and 2) the effectiveness of the imaging methodology to measure in vivo biodegradation of implantable biomaterials. Successful demonstrations will rationalize continuing translational studies towards in vivo CT evaluation of TaOx- embedded TES in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Epidemiological studies and clinical data correlate decreased estrogen signaling and loss of estrogen receptor beta (ERβ) expression to increased melanoma risk and disease progression. This proposal will determine how estrogen signaling through ERβ regulates melanocyte biology, impacts immune recognition of the tumor, and protects against melanoma. As an integral part of these studies, we propose to evaluate the potential of ERβ- specific agonists in enhancing current melanoma therapies.
