IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal seeks to validate caveolin-1 as a complementary biomarker of HER2 and to determine sensitivity or resistance of the tumor-targeting anti-HER2 antibody trastuzumab when administrated in combination with the common cholesterol-depleting drug lovastatin in the treatment of esophagogastric cancer. Retrospective clinical and preclinical analyses will be performed using patient HER2+ tumor samples and patient-derived EG xenografts treated with statin alone, trastuzumab alone, or the combination of the two. The long-term goal will be to inform future therapeutic strategies that can prevent or delay the emergence of trastuzumab resistance.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Among HAIs, Clostridioides difficile infection (CDI) is responsible for approximately 500,000 infections per year, of which 66% are healthcare-associated, and undiagnosed patients who are colonized with C. difficile are increasingly recognized as a potential source of infection in the hospital setting. The overall objective of this proposal is to prospectively deploy our validated machine learning risk model for hospital-acquired CDI to gain an increased understanding of 1) how the risk of CDI relates to colonization status and 2) its utility in guiding management and improving outcomes. This can lead to a paradigm shift in how CDI is prevented in hospitals and serve as a model to combat other infections.

PROJECT_TITLE: Data-Driven Interventions for Reducing C. difficile Incidence

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK STATE PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE DBA RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR MENTAL HYGIENE, INC
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adapting mental health treatments to address modifiable interpersonal problems has the potential to improve and sustain outcomes in low-resource settings where treatment gaps persist. This K23 Award will prepare the candidate to become an independent investigator with high-impact public health research and expertise in couple-based interventions that address interrelated mental health problems and intimate partner violence in couples by gaining expertise in engagement and treatment of men, adapting an evidence-based treatment for common mental disorders to address IPV in couples, designing and conducting randomized controlled trials with couples, and professional skills development. This work has applicability for low-resource low-income countries and US populations that experience couple-based violence and the mental health treatment gap. With its focus on intimate partners, the intervention also has the potential to benefit health and wellbeing of children.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A protective HIV-1 vaccine is needed to halt the spread of the pandemic. This Program will move into manufacturing a rapid vaccine platform that presents multiple copies of neutralizing antibody targets to the immune system. This vaccine platform will hasten progress towards finding a protective HIV-1 vaccine.

ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The majority of emerging viral diseases result from the zoonotic transmission of pathogen from animals to humans. While the innate immune system plays a critical role in limiting cross-species transmissions, cellular determinants mediating this effect have yet to be fully described. This study aims to identify and characterize novel cellular factors responsible for limiting viral replication in human cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative HIV-1 reverse transcriptase (RT) is a central target for antiviral treatment of AIDS and detailed knowledge of its structure and function has important clinical and biological consequences. Reverse transcriptase inhibitors figure prominently in almost all HIV/AIDS treatment regimens, including combination therapies that are used in highly-active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) and pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) as well. The proposed studies will enhance opportunities for targeting known and new sites on RT, both as the mature enzyme and during morphogenetic stages in which RT forms part of long precursor polyproteins.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immune cells in a mother’s uterus help the embryo receive the blood and nutrients it needs to grow. When a fetus fails to grow in the womb, both mother and fetus are in danger of death or major disability. This project will provide important information about how specialized immune cells called macrophages help the uterus to nurture the fetus throughout pregnancy, keeping mother and fetus safe from harm.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: Project Narrative The fact that a small subset of HIV infected individuals develop broadly neutralizing antibodies (bnAbs) capable of neutralizing 98% of HIV viruses gives substantial promise that an HIV vaccine is possible. However, there has been a lack of understanding of the biophysical constraints of the germinal center microenvironment (GCME), which is the arena in which B cells compete to develop into bnAb producing B cells. We aim to uncover the composition of the extracellular space within the GCME, with the goal of identifying novel biophysical constraints and metabolic pathways that may be recruited during vaccination to elicit generation of bnAb producing B cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Using random germline mutagenesis and tumor growth screening in mice, we have identified several mutations that confer cancer resistance. We now focus on understanding mechanisms of resistance in mice with two of these mutations, advancing our work to the point of translational application. We will also extend mutagenesis and screening to identify still more cancer resistance mutations, and mechanistically analyze those that operate by effects on the immune system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Psychiatric disorders in youth are very difficult to predict and prevent but addressing the drivers of mental illness during the developmental phase of the life course offers a critically important opportunity to reduce the global burden of mental disorders in youth people and over the life course. In this project we will investigate social drivers, pathways and mechanisms through which a large cash transfer program is associated with better mental health outcomes among youth, thus attempting to reveal avenues for prevention, using an unprecedent cohort of over 100 million in Brazil. Results from this innovative project are expected to inform policymakers in ways of addressing the burden of mental illness through social protection programs for youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Non-typhoidal Salmonella serotypes are a common cause diarrheal disease in the United States, with a cost of $0.5 to $2.3 billion per year due to lost productivity and the cost of medical care. This application will support studies on how Salmonella colonizes the mammalian intestinal tract and causes disease symptoms. A better understanding of the molecular mechanisms that influence bacterial colonization is expected to aid in the development of new intervention strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: Inappropriately activated Ras lies at the center of more than a third of all tumors and the RASopathy spectrum of birth defects, yet Ras itself is relatively undruggable, with key partners and the contexts in which they are used poorly understood. This proposal seeks to understand the mechanisms of Ras effector switching and the role served by its neglected partners in diverse biological functions, using the invertebrate experimental animal C. elegans as a simple model to delineate molecular and cellular mechanisms. The long-term goal of this work is to define biomarkers and druggable targets for therapeutic interventions into birth defects and tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Apramycin is an unusual aminoglycoside antibiotic with minimal oto- and nephrotoxicity and minimal susceptibility to common mechanisms of aminoglycoside resistance. As such it is currently in clinical trials in Europe and the USA under development for the treatment of multidrug-resistant bacterial infections. Nevertheless, resistance to apramycin is expected to eventually surface because of its susceptibility to a single isoform of an aminoglycoside modifying enzyme, the aminoacetyltransferase AAC(3)-IV. This proposal, through a combination of design, chemical synthesis, and antibacterial and antiribosomal screening, test the hypothesis that improved analogs of apramycin based on the streptamine core (as opposed to the existing 2-deoxystreptamine core) can be designed and prepared that overcome the inherent susceptibility to AAC(3)-IV without loss of the broad-spectrum activity or minimal toxicity of the parent.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: SMARCB1 (SNF5), a subunit of SWI/SNF chromatin remodeling complexes, is specifically mutated in nearly all cases of malignant rhabdoid tumor, a highly lethal cancer of early childhood. Recent studies have revealed that genes encoding SWI/SNF complex subunits are mutated in nearly 25% of all human cancers, demonstrating that investigations of SMARCB1 function have broad cancer relevance. The proposed studies are designed to determine the normal function of SMARCB1, to define the mechanisms by which SMARCB1 mutations cause cancer, and to explore novel approaches for circumventing therapeutic resistance in these aggressive cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The precise patterning of cells that make up most complex organisms relies on an ancient cellular communication strategy called the Hedgehog signaling pathway. This pathway is absolutely critical to the development of organisms as diverse as sea squirts to humans, and disruption in normal signaling causes many cancers. This research program will uncover the fundamental mechanism that enables cells to sense the Hedgehog signal, laying the foundation for the discovery of drugs for regenerative medicine and various cancers.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative SARS-CoV2 is an ongoing global pandemic that targets the most vulnerable members of our society with persistent, overwhelming inflammation of the lungs that can eventually cause respiratory failure and death. However, the specific factors that act locally in the lungs to determine disease severity remain unknown. These studies will contribute powerful new tools to obtain clinically relevant information about macrophages, the predominant immune cells in SARS-CoV2 infection, including whether they prevent repair of lung damage during infection, and whether they may be potential drug targets to reduce disease severity and death in humans infected with SARS-CoV2.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative  Ferroptosis is an iron-dependent form of nonapoptotic cell death that is induced by excessive lipid peroxidation. The objectives of this application are to determine the mechanisms by which ferroptosis inactivation contributes to radioresistance in KEAP1-mutant lung cancer cells and to assess the combination of radiotherapy and ferroptosis inducers in treating KEAP-mutant lung cancers. Our proposed studies will have a significant impact on both our understanding of the fundamental mechanisms of ferroptosis and radiation biology and our ability to target ferroptosis-related radioresistance in cancer treatment.

PHR: Project Narrative Over 2 million people in the United States abuse opioids, and overdose deaths involving synthetic opioids are on the rise. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  We have recently shown that HIV-1 integrase (IN) enzyme binds to the viral RNA genome during virion maturation and ensures its proper encapsidation inside viral capsid lattice. Here we propose to unveil the molecular details of IN-RNA interactions, how IN binding to the viral genome ensures accurate placement of the genome within the capsid lattice and how infected cells sense and respond to viruses generated upon inhibition of IN-RNA interactions. This project will provide new knowledge about the key non-catalytic function of HIV-1 IN in virion maturation and help in the development of therapeutics that can complement integrase strand-transfer inhibitors that target the catalytic function of IN.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Stress alters reward processing and decision-making, increasing the risk of developing neuropsychiatric disorders. The fundamental mechanisms of stress-induced alterations remain poorly understood, but likely involve a disruption of dopamine system, which underlies many neuropsychiatric disorders. This study will provide mechanistic insights into stress-induced dysregulation of dopamine signaling and reward processing to speed the transition from basic research to more translational models of chronic stress and the development of novel treatments for stress-related disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Chronic rhinosinusitis affects up to 16% of the population in the United States and is among the most common reasons people seek medical attention. Solitary chemosensory cells (SCCs), akin to type II taste cells in the tongue (responsible for taste transduction) and tuft cells in the mouse gut (responsible for local inflammation) are enriched in the sinus epithelium in those with chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps, however, little is known about their role in human mucosal inflammatory diseases. This proposal will characterize and identify taste and inflammatory pathways related to SCC differentiation and expansion in chronic rhinosinusitis and explore how SCC signaling through epithelial ion channels affects mucosal immune function, which may reveal novel therapeutic targets for the treatment of chronic rhinosinusitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The rise of antibiotic tolerance is one of the most critical global public health threats of the 21st century. Bacterial persisters, which are reversible drug tolerant cells that have been observed in every bacterial species studied so far, contribute to this problem significantly. The eradication of persister cells could aid in curing recurrent and chronic infections; therefore, the main theme of this proposed study is to therapeutically challenge persister cells by exploring a global, self-digestion-mediated persister formation mechanism in bacterial species.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Candida auris has emerged as a global threat causing serious invasive infections worldwide with mortality approaching nearly 60 percent. Because C. auris colonizes the skin and acts as a nidus of infection, developing therapies that can concurrently target skin and exhibit systemic efficacy will be highly innovative and desirable. Recently, a new class of antifungals termed fungerps have been developed, and a second-generation fungerp-SCY-247 is under development as a potential systemic therapeutic option for Candida infection; we propose to investigate whether SCY-247 will exhibit differentiating fungicidal properties including the ability to cross the BBB and work systemically, and as an effective cutaneous treatment for C. auris.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Cognitive decline is a growing global health concern due to unprecedented increases in the aging population. This proposal will test whether certain neural “hubs” may play unique roles in cognitive functions and treatment outcomes in Parkinson’s disease, a major risk factor for dementia. Studying the effects of Parkinson’s disease on white matter integrity related to cognition will generate clinically useful insights into the subtype, prognosis, and pathophysiology of cognitive decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: GHESKIO is a Haitian organization dedicated to research, service, and training in HIV/AIDS with a 37 year track record of NIH-funded clinical research. The GHESKIO Clinical Trials Unit has two clinical research sites in Port au Prince and will conduct research in two NIAID networks: The adult HIV/AIDS therapeutic clinical trials group and the maternal-adolescent-pediatric HIV/AIDS trials group. The goal is to improve the treatment of HIV, tuberculosis, and HIV complications across the lifespan in pregnant women, adolescents, children, and adults of all ages in Haiti and around the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal investigates how the bacterium that causes tuberculosis (TB) in humans, Mycobacterium tuberculosis, has the unique ability to evade being killed by our immune system and is able to persist for long periods of time in its host as a latent infection. Latent infections can be reactivated—especially in the immune compromised—to the highly contagious, active form of TB and accelerate spread of the disease. Therefore, it is important to understand how latent tuberculosis develops and how it becomes reactivated because globally the number of deaths caused by M. tuberculosis now exceeds those caused by the HIV/AIDS virus.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA SALT LAKE CITY HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Diabetes Mellitus (DM) is a global epidemic and heart failure (HF) is the leading cause of death in diabetics. The prevalence of DM in US veterans is higher than their civilian counterparts. Cardiac metabolism is central in the pathophysiology of both DM and HF but our understanding of the metabolic adaptations when they coexist is very limited. HF patients with DM undergoing therapy with left ventricular assist devices (LVAD) present a unique opportunity, as human cardiac tissue and serum become available, both before and after intervention. These samples become extremely more informative when we prospectively associate cardiac recovery with molecular/metabolic changes while on LVAD support. Using the novel and powerful method of non-radioactive 13C metabolic flux studies we will interrogate the dynamic cardiac metabolism and associated mechanisms implicated in myocardial recovery in human HF with DM.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: It is estimated that up to 20% of young veterans have had a traumatic brain injury (TBI), yet little is known about the impact of TBI over the long term. This project aims to utilize medical information obtained through VA medical centers to investigate the long-term effects of TBI. We have assembled a database of nearly 2 million veterans (including all veterans with a TBI), and plan to expand and use this resource to study various TBI outcomes such as neurodegenerative disease and mental health diagnoses. We also plan to develop models that will guide clinicians toward better care and prevention of TBI associated outcomes. This line of investigation is vital not only to anticipate and plan for individual, VA, and U.S. public health burden from military-service related problems, but also to inform VA and other healthcare systems about how to best use resources and target interventions to improve the care of veterans and to reduce the risk of long-term consequences.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES J PETERS VA  MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE Dr. Haghighi's genomics research focuses on how environmental signals or insults are interpreted by the genome through epigenetics. Epigenetics is the bridge connecting the environment and genetics, regulating gene expression and cellular response to environmental cues throughout our lifespan. Specifically, she is interested in how physical and/or psychosocial stress throughout the lifespan can induce epigenetic abnormalities leading to neuropathological and psychiatric symptoms. Traumatic brain injury represents a physical stress, and psychosocial stressors often precipitate depression and heightened suicide risk. Using both animal and human studies, she investigates the role of such stressors using genomics approaches to identify the underlying molecular mechanisms in such disorders. Her successes in building productive collaborations within the VA Health System and the Department of Defense to support our TBI and suicide genomics research programs demonstrates Dr. Haghighi's continued leadership capabilities in building a strong suicide clinical and research program at the VA.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Prostate cancer is the most common cancer of Veterans and will take the lives of 1 in 41 men. Each of these tumors is driven by a unique combination of mutations of inherited as well as non-inherited origin. Precision oncology identifies these drivers in order to exactly target the most effective therapy available. The drivers are diverse and can also reveal cancer risks in the family, often unanticipated. Inherited drivers occur more often among men with a family history of prostate cancer and men with metastatic prostate cancer. Although prostate cancer has greater heritable risk than any other common cancer, its broad diversity has also proven to be a formidable obstacle for traditional family-based study to reveal its inherited causes. The knowledge base for decision-making in precision care of prostate cancer remains very limiting. This study uses a novel design to investigate men with familial prostate cancer in order to further build this knowledge base for the care of Veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: WM S. MIDDLETON MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSP
PHR: Arterial stiffness is linked to hypertension, poor BP control, and cardiovascular disease (CVD) events. Many older Veterans have suboptimally controlled blood pressure, in part because of inconsistent guideline recommendations for BP treatment goals and fear of side-effects from pharmacotherapy. Exercise and administration of sublingual nitroglycerin acutely alter arterial stiffness. We hypothesize that arterial reserve, determined by change in arterial stiffness measures following acute exercise or administration of sublingual nitroglycerin, will be greater in those with controlled blood pressure than in those with poorly controlled blood pressure or those without high blood pressure. A non-invasive arterial stress test that evaluates dynamic arterial stiffness in older hypertensive Veterans could determine who will better tolerate more aggressive BP goals, minimizing CVD events with fewer adverse side-effects.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Wildland fire smoke inhalation has been linked to disease of the cardiopulmonary system, but the contribution of exposure frequency and duration, as well as smoke composition remain unknown. With the occurrence and severity of wildland fires on the rise, there is an urgent need to understand the negative health consequences of smoke inhalation, in order to properly inform and protect at risk populations. In this proposal, we evaluate changes in the cardiopulmonary function of adult mice after prolonged fire smoke inhalation, modeling conditions at wildland urban interface regions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative  Both large and middle envelope proteins of hepatitis B virus contain the preS2 domain, and late stage of chronic infection often selects for deletions to remove part of the preS2 domain. We will perform transfection and infection experiments in cell culture to critically test our hypothesis that such deletions escape neutralizing antibodies, which block viral infection by binding to either large or middle envelope protein. If proven, immune escape could explain the selection of such deletion mutants and their close association with liver cancer development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Beginning at birth, the activity of eight different tongue muscles must be precisely coordinated for the successful performance of diverse tasks such as breathing, suckling, and swallowing but how this is accomplished is unknown. Tongue muscles are innervated by motor neurons in the hypoglossal motor nucleus of the brainstem, which is a bilateral collection of seven motor neuron pools, with motor neurons in each pool innervating a different tongue muscle. The proposed basic science studies will reveal unique physiologic and genetic properties of the motoneurons that supply a given muscle, which can then be targeted to activate or inhibit specific tongue muscles.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: WHITE RIVER JUNCTION VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: The proposed research is highly relevant to Veterans’ health because it will test a [novel intervention that addresses two key contributors to suicide risk after psychiatric hospitalization: poor social connectedness and engagement in care.] There is overwhelming evidence that one of the highest risk periods for suicide in Veterans is the three months following psychiatric hospitalization. The proposed suicide prevention strategy, [Prevention of suicide: Education, Awareness, Connection, and Engagement (PEACE), directly addresses this high-risk phase of care by coupling a mobile health intervention targeting social connectedness with a manual- based approach to support engagement in care after discharge.] This proposed research has the potential [to be highly scalable] and could have a large, positive impact on the health and well-being of Veterans by preventing suicide in Veterans who are at high risk for suicide. The proposed research is also highly relevant to the VA’s top clinical priority, namely suicide prevention in Veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: Major Depressive Disorder is the leading cause of disability in the United States for ages 15-44, with associated substantial healthcare system costs. Estimates among the Veteran population for major depressive disorder prevalence are about 11%. This study will provide insights into whether reward processing measures of brain functioning and behavior are useful for improving aspects of treatment planning, suicide risk assessment, and cognitive-behavioral therapy response prediction. Mental healthcare practitioners need treatment predictors that account for the full extent of depressed individuals seen in the clinic in order to realize the goal of personalized healthcare. Studies like the one proposed here are vital to this larger effort in that they are poised to discover biomarkers to account for neurobiological variation presumably underlying distinct individual clinical responses. A refined depression taxonomy, informed by clinical neuroscience, could then be harnessed to improve diagnosis, increase treatment precision, or enhance prediction of suicide risk.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Heart failure is a chronic cardiovascular condition with periods of stability interrupted by episodes of acute decompensation that frequently result in hospitalization. Approximately 350,000 Veterans are living with chronic heart failure, while there are almost 90,000 hospitalizations for acute heart failure in the VA system annually. During a hospitalization for acute heart failure, one third of patients will have a rise in creatinine that reflects worsening kidney function. Currently, this change in kidney function could be a benign hemodynamic effect from treatments given for acute heart failure or true kidney injury; there are currently no tools available to distinguish these two situations. This proposal will apply novel kidney biomarkers found in urine to discriminate between these two scenarios, a finding that could change the management of acute heart failure and improve treatment outcomes.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative Approximately one million veterans aged 50 and older will develop colorectal cancer over the remainder of their lives and nearly 433,000 will die from it. On a national basis, the relative five year survival with colorectal cancer was estimated at only approximately 40% among veterans, substantially lower than the 60% survival rate among the general population. Myeloid cell accumulation is a hallmark of human colorectal cancer and PD-L1 is a major immune suppressive ligand of MDSCs. In the preliminary studies, we determined that PD-L1 engages PD-1 of myeloid cells to inhibit type I interferon signaling to suppress CTL tumor infiltration. Therefore, it is critical to study type I interferon signaling in myeloid cells in human colorectal cancer patients. The proposed studies have the potential to determine the role of tPD-L1 and mPD-1 in colon cancer immune evasion and will provide the basis for molecular mechanism-based development of IFNA13CO01 for human colon cancer immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Malaria is a disease caused by a protozoan parasite that replicates within the vasculature of multiple organs including those with lower oxygenation (e.g., brain, bone marrow) and those with higher oxygenation (e.g., lung, liver). While laboratory-based studies suggest that malaria parasites grow fastest in environments with low oxygen, much less is known about their growth in highly oxygenated environments. This research will help us understand how tissue oxygenation may affect the malaria parasite’s replication rate and susceptibility to antimalarial drug treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) have recently emerged as important regulators of a plethora of biological processes, ranging from development to immunity. Using a discovery pipeline that integrates information from genome-wide association studies, evolutionary conservation and differential gene expression, we have identified a novel lncRNA that exhibits a pattern of selective expression in regulatory T cells (Tregs) and is genetically implicated in two intestinal auto-immune diseases, Crohn’s disease and ulcerative colitis. Here, we propose to explore the role of this lncRNA in Treg biology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Relevance to Public Health Fine particulate matter <2.5 µm (PM2.5) air pollution is a major environment-related health threat that leads to both acute and chronic diseases and a risk factor for cardiovascular disease. Very little is known on the effects of PM2.5 cessation or how to alleviate the detrimental effects of the air pollution through therapeutic or dietary interventions. This proposal will investigate a relationship between PM2.5 and resolution of inflammation caused by PM2.5 through a variety of approaches, including diet switch and a novel pharmacological mimic of exposure cessation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Malaria control and eradication efforts are hindered by persistent and emerging resistance to frontline anti-malarial drugs, highlighting the urgent need for understanding parasite biology to develop new therapeutic options. We have recently discovered that the parasite vacuolar protein UIS2 is required for protein export into the host cell and hypothesize that UIS2 establishes critical nutrient transport and protein export machinery in the vacuole membrane. This project will determine the role of UIS2 in these transport processes which represent new therapeutic targets that are essential for parasite survival and disease pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The proposed CDA-2 will provide Dr. Stout with the training, expertise and research support to examine the relatively unexplored neural circuit relationship between working memory and fear extinction, and how these mechanisms jointly contribute to posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD). This project will be one of the first to leverage innovative multivariate neuroimaging analysis to better elucidate the symptoms of PTSD. The planned CDA-2 aims to create more robust neural circuit biomarkers that can be used to delineate the individual neurobiology of Veterans with PTSD. These aims support the VA mission of developing precision medicine tools for Veteran care and the identification of viable targets of treatment for PTSD and other trauma- related disorders.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: This investigation has the potential to benefit Veterans and the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) in several ways. Veterans will benefit from the Safety Aid Reduction Treatment Protocol for PTSD (START-PTSD) by engaging in an empirically based treatment designed to identify and eliminate safety aids. This will: a) lead to reductions in posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) symptom severity; and b) potentially prepare Veterans for more intensive trauma-focused treatments. In turn, this could yield long-term benefits for the VA by increasing evidence-based psychotherapy (EBP; i.e., prolonged exposure [PE] therapy and/or cognitive processing therapy [CPT]) initiation and enrollment.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: MICHAEL E DEBAKEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Antibiotic-resistant bacteria are a major public health concern. These bacteria cause infections that are often difficult to treat and lead to serious infections. Carbapenem-resistant Enterobacteriaceae (CRE) is a severe type of antibiotic-resistant bacteria because it is resistant to almost all antibiotics and can be very deadly. It is very important to identify which patients are at risk for CRE and to identify the best treatment for CRE. We propose to develop and test a tool that predicts whether a person carries CRE, and to identify the best treatment options for CRE infections. We will use large databases to find patients at risk for CRE and patient who have CRE infections. We will use computer programming and biostatistics to identify which patients are at risk and which treatments work best. At the end of the proposed work, we will have identified new avenues to prevent person-to-person transmission of CRE and improve therapy of CRE infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metabolites from the microbiota, probiotics and diet can inhibit the virulence of bacterial pathogens, but their mechanisms of actions have been not fully elucidated. Using innovative chemical biology, proteomic and gene editing methods, we will determine the protein targets of prominent bacterial and dietary metabolites and evaluate how they attenuate the virulence mechanisms of bacterial pathogens. Understanding how key metabolites affects bacterial pathogenesis may afford new therapeutic targets and anti-infective agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to dissect molecular pathways responsible for the development and progression of chronic inflammation, in contrast with those involved in the inhibition or resolution of it, a central component in the cardiovascular and metabolic toxicity induced by air pollution. Air pollution contains both gaseous and particulate components (particulate matter) and it appears that the latter ones are mostly responsible for its toxicity by promoting systemic oxidative stress and proinflammatory effects that result in triglyceride accumulation in the liver, lipid infiltration of the vasculature and development of inflammation in both tissues. This project aims to dissect molecular pathways responsible for the development and progression of chronic inflammation, in contrast with those involved in the inhibition or resolution of it, a central component in the cardiovascular and metabolic toxicity induced by air pollution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Chronic rejection of transplanted organs is the adverse outcome when graft blood vessels thicken, due to negative immune influences on the cells of the middle layer of arteries, smooth muscle cells (SMCs), which become dysregulated. This project focuses on defining which immune cell-produced factors have the greatest potential to promote healthy regulation of those SMCs, followed by enhancing their production through interference with influential regulatory small RNAs (microRNAs), to be tested in preclinical blood vessel transplant models. This would constitute a novel therapeutic approach to the maintenance of healthy organ transplants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: There is an urgent but unmet medical need for novel treatment-shortening strategies for drug-susceptible and drug-resistant tuberculosis (TB). Using a forward genetic screen, we recently found that the cell wall-associated protein CaeA confers reduced susceptibility of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) to the primary first-line sterilizing drug, rifampin. Using a combination of targeted and unbiased approaches, the current proposal is designed to identify the mechanism of CaeA-mediated Mtb tolerance to rifampin and, in proof-of-concept studies, to evaluate the potential utility of targeting CaeA as adjunctive therapy to shorten the duration of TB treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative  Many children who receive cochlear Implants (CIs) struggle to hear in everyday environments, and recent clinical care has shifted to prioritize bilateral CIs. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions): Serious clinical conditions can arise in the peritoneal cavity, ranging from the initiation and progression of sepsis to cancer. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative – Lina Ni  Many insect vectors of diseases, such as mosquitoes, depend on their temperature-sensing molecules to detect the temperature of their warm-blooded hosts and use it to guide the blood- feeding behaviors through which they transmit human diseases. This project uses a powerful insect genetic model, fruit flies, to study a new class of warm-sensing molecules. These molecules are conserved between flies and mosquitoes so that they may serve as novel targets to control the blood-feeding behaviors of disease vectors.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tissue-resident memory Th2 cells are critical in driving allergic asthma, the most common asthma subtype. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Systemic lupus erythematosus afflicts more than a million Americans, primarily women, and presents with symptoms resulting from the involvement of practically every organ. The origin of the disease involves diverse factors which probably contribute variably to the expression of the disease in each patient. Understanding of the molecular underpinnings that lead to an aberrant immune response through this line of research will help us identify novel treatment targets and biomarkers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE) Globally, complications of preterm birth are the single largest direct cause of neonatal deaths, accounting for 35% of over 3 million annual deaths. While the specific causes are poorly understood, many have identified disparities in preterm birth by maternal socio-demographic characteristics such as race, age, and educational attainment, and the independent and joint effects of social and environmental factors over the maternal life course, as contributing to the risk of adverse birth outcomes. A better understanding of the interaction between wildfire smoke exposure and social risk factors as they relate to birth outcomes and can support interventions to promote healthy fetal development in an era of increasing wildfires.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative The research in this proposal will provide proof of concept for a novel approach for the treatment of Alzheimer’s disease using monoclonal antibodies. Specifically, we propose to develop conformation-specific monoclonal antibodies, which bind the a secretase ADAM10, activate amyloid precursor protein cleavage, and promote the non-amyloidogenic pathway in cell- and neuron-based assays. The studies will also provide the first high-resolution structural view of how ADAM10 interacts with and cleaves the amyloid precursor protein.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Low responses rate to immune checkpoint blockade cancer therapy prompted us to find new strategy to efficiently target therapeutic molecules on cancer cells and immune cells. We recently discovered a new antibody H1A to PD-L1 that is expressed by both cancer cells and immune cells. We found H1A antibody induced PD-L1 depletion in cancer cells to make cancer cells more sensitive to chemotherapy, and in immune cells to generate strong antitumor immune responses. Our proposed studies will address the synergistic effects of H1A with chemotherapy to overcome cancer resistance to chemotherapy and immunotherapy. The new knowledge and tools produced by our proposed studies will help physicians to treat cancer patients with appropriate combination that would not benefit patients’ clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Herpes simplex virus, the cause of common cold sores, also causes serious human diseases including blindness, infection of the brain, and organ damage in newborns. Once a primary infection takes hold, the virus shelters from the immune system in cells of the nervous system for the lifetime of the host, quiescent until reawakened by a stressor. We will examine the control over this quiescent state by a recently described weapon of the immune system that destroys viral components inside infected cells when they are recognized by antibodies that gain access to the cell interior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The CDC estimates that Chlamydia is one of the most prevalent bacterial infections in the US and causes upper reproductive tract pathology in a growing number of otherwise health young women. Unfortunately, women with untreated Chlamydia infection can develop serious pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), infertility, chronic pelvic pain, or suffer from ectopic pregnancy. Given the high incidence of infection and the potential for serious pathology, the current consensus among scientists and clinicians is that an effective Chlamydia vaccine is needed. In order for a vaccine to be generated, we require a greater understanding of host immunity to Chlamydia infection in the upper reproductive tract. This application will utilize new antigen-specific reagents to study the mouse model of genital Chlamydia infection. We will use these reagents to examine the mechanism of circulating memory to Chlamydia in the female reproductive tract.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative The AMPK and mTOR complex 1 (mTORC1) protein kinases enable cells and tissues to respond to fluctuations in a variety of systemic cues. This proposal will define an unexpected role for the energy sensing kinase AMPK in cellular adaptation to nutrient stress caused by amino acid starvation through cooperation with mTORC1 to maintain metabolic function. This research using cultured cells and mouse models will advance our understanding of mTOR and AMPK in health and disease and may identify new therapeutic strategies for treatment of linked disorders, such as cancer and metabolic diseases.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: WM S. MIDDLETON MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSP
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE:         Following deployment to the Persian Gulf, nearly 250,000 Gulf War Veterans (GVs) now report an array of symptoms including fatigue, pain, and problems with cognitive function. Nearly 50% of GVs seek VA clinical care, and nearly 40% receive disability compensation. To date, the causes of these symptoms are not known, and as a result, no efficacious treatments are available. The proposed research addresses this problem by testing multiple physiological systems at rest and in response to exercise in GVs with Gulf War Illness (GWI). These studies will determine whether interactions among central nervous, autonomic, and immune systems explain symptoms at baseline and the worsening of symptoms that occur following exercise challenge (i.e., post-exertion malaise). Results from this research are intended to improve our understanding of the causes of GWI and to begin a path towards individualized treatment of this debilitating condition. These goals are directly in-line with the mission of the Department of Veterans Affairs to care for those who have served this country.

ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative The opportunistic fungal pathogen Aspergillus fumigatus remains a health concern for critically ill patients and continues to have a high mortality rate despite improvements in anti-fungal therapies. This proposal seeks to investigate the role of heterogeneous conventional dendritic cells (cDCs) in generating adaptive immune responses to A. fumigatus. Understanding the mechanisms by which cDCs induce protective immunity may identify novel strategies for development of therapies and vaccines to mitigate the burden of A. fumigatus and other fungal pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Visceral leishmaniasis is a devastating parasitic disease that causes death if left untreated and despite decades of research, efforts to develop a durable, effective vaccine have been unsuccessful. Rather than remaining “hidden” from the adaptive immune system, we have found that T cells undergo a state of dysfunction often described as “exhaustion” during visceral leishmaniasis, similar to what occurs during chronic viral infections and cancer. Thus, the goal of this study is to begin to understand why protective immunity against visceral leishmaniasis fails to develop and if T cell exhaustion can be reversed using therapeutic immunization and/or immunotherapy, which will contribute to our long-term goal of understanding how to improve vaccine design against and develop treatments for Leishmania infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Many individuals develop cancers. The brain is one of the common organs for cancer recurrence. Unfortunately, cancer brain metastasis is increasingly becoming a significant clinical problem due to its rising incidence and limited efficacy of existing systemic therapies. Metastasis is the consequence of favorable interactions between the invaded cancer cells and the microenvironment in the distal organ. To cancer cells, the brain has the most unique microenvironment since almost all the cells in the brain do not exist in any other organs. Thus, this proposal is designed to study crosstalks between cancer cells and brain stromal cells. If we can identify key changes in this process, we can better target brain metastatic cancer cells, in order to eradicate them and provide more effective therapies for cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative  Children exposed to opioids in utero, either through the mother’s opioid use/abuse or via medication- assisted treatment for opioid addiction (MAT, methadone or buprenorphine), are at an increased risk for cognitive deficits, particularly those related to attention and impulse control. No study has addressed this in an animal model so the goal of this proposal is to test how maternal opioid use, including MAT, affects offspring brain development and behavior in a mouse model. These studies will establish a foundation for future investigations into potential interventions to improve outcomes in opioid-exposed children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The broad, long-term goal of this project is to develop a comprehensive understanding of the developmental events that dictate cell fate decisions in formation of the synovial joint. Within this broad area, this proposal focuses on the differentiation of articular cartilage, which plays a central role in maintaining the low-friction environment of the joint space. Successful completion of this proposal will provide fundamental new insight into the events that regulate the development of articular cartilage, with additional implications for regeneration of articular cartilage in degenerative joint diseases including osteoarthritis (OA) or rheumatoid arthritis (RA).

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: This application requests funds to purchase a Zeiss Confocal Laser Scanning Microscope (LSM) 980 The LSM allows for high resolution and super-resolution imaging of biological specimens and will further enhance collaborations within VA-NWI and with collaborators. The system will bring new research capabilities to VA- NWI, and is a flexible system capable of meeting the diverse experimental requirements of all participating Investigators. The device will be used by 9 currently VA-funded Major Users and 1 Minor User under the supervision of an Oversight Committee. The device will significantly enhance the physical research infrastructure at VA-NWI. In doing so, the Zeiss LSM 980 will allow our researchers to perform detailed and quantitative imaging studies in a variety of samples at high resolution, greatly expanding our capabilities. This will, in turn, accelerate and augment preclinical research in areas of critical importance to Veterans health, including metabolic disease, pulmonary disorders, liver disease, and reproductive health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE This K24 proposal addresses a critical public health need to improve treatment and prevention of pediatric venous thromboembolism (VTE), a condition that affects 1 in 200 hospitalized children. The six mentored projects will generate foundational evidence toward achieving this goal, by developing new pediatric subpopulation-specific risk assessment models and elucidating novel prognostic factors in pediatric VTE, leveraging (and collecting new patient-derived data within) recently-completed or ongoing multicenter studies in which the mentor plays a leadership role. This K24 proposal will also expand the skillsets of the mentor via the Master Mentor Program of the Johns Hopkins Institute for Clinical and Translational Research, as well as through distance learning-enabled coursework in both Bayesian methods and proteomics through Johns Hopkins University and other expert institutions/organizations, enhanced by direct interactions with internationally- recognized experts in these fields who also serve as co-investigators in the mentored projects.

ORG_NAME: VA NEW JERSEY HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This ShEEP proposal requests a single cell analysis system comprising Namocell Pala Single Cell Dispenser and 10x Genomics Chromium Connect to serve as a shared common resource for VA-Merit and VA investigators at Veterans Administration New Jersey Healthcare System (VANJHCS). This single-cell analysis system will allow VANJHCS researchers to obtain high-resolution transcriptomic analyses of the cell populations in various diseases. Multiple VA Merit-funded research projects on melanoma, traumatic brain injury, neuroprotection, Parkinson’s disease, neuroimmunomodulation, fatty liver, hepatocellular carcinoma, and leukemia will benefit from this needed investigational platform for the careful precise study of the cell’s transcriptomic state in health and disease. This proposed system single cell analysis system will augment VANJHCS’s mission to advance Veteran healthcare by incorporating a cutting-edge, but rapidly becoming a standard investigational tool and substantially contribute to the long-term research goals of VANJHCS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to investigate cognitive and neurobiological mechanisms as predictors of a risky pattern of poly-substance use, cannabis and alcohol co-use, at different stages of adolescence using two large population studies (COGA, ABCD) and through collecting pilot data on use and co-use in a multigeneration family study (MFS). Using behavioral and neuroimaging measures, I will investigate self-regulation prior to substance initiation to understand executive functioning and impulsivity mechanisms related to future cannabis and alcohol co-use and cannabis/alcohol use disorders during adolescence. Having a broader understanding of self- regulation mechanisms will contribute to identifying at-risk children and adolescents before substance initiation, which can have immense clinical, prevention, and public health implications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Opportunistic pathogen Group B Streptococcus (GBS) remains a leading cause of invasive disease in neonates and certain adult populations, including pregnant women. During pregnancy, asymptomatically colonizing GBS in the female genital tract can be transmitted to the fetus or newborn and can result in progression of neonatal meningitis upon GBS disruption of the blood-brain barrier (BBB); yet, the specific mechanisms by which Group B streptococcal effectors mediate toxicity and drive inflammatory responses during colonization and development of meningitis are still being elucidated. This proposal seeks to investigate how secreted bacterial proteins and/or toxins contribute to GBS pathogenesis and colonization and thwart the anti-GBS immune response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: OVERALL - NARRATIVE Alcohol-associated liver and pancreatic diseases (ALPD) and cirrhosis are the major medical consequences of excessive alcohol drinking with high mortality around the world. The Southern California Research Center for ALPD and Cirrhosis is a regional, multi-institutional and multi-disciplinary center which continues to strive for integrated and comprehensive efforts to advance research, education, training and dissemination on the diseases. In support of its mission, Administrative Core provides administrative and logistic support; Animal Core produces innovative animal models of ALPD and cirrhosis; and Pilot Project Core provides seed funds to early-career investigators who are aspired to pursue independent ALPD research. The Center also supports four leading-edge research projects to help understand: how gut viruses contribute to alcohol- associated liver disease (AALD); how liver cancer is promoted by metabolic reprogramming in AALD; what cellular and molecular events drive excessive liver scarring in AALD; and how alcohol causes pancreas damage and inflammation via cholesterol dysregulation. High-impact outcomes from these activities are improving our understanding of the diseases and facilitating developments of new preventive and therapeutic approaches while serving as a unique national resource of technical, intellectual and collaborative services to investigators across the nation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Calcium channel splice variation plays a vital role in normal human physiology, individual responses to drugs, and human disease. However, the tools for studying the functional effects of altered splicing are limited. Creation of a new tool for targeted splice manipulation will enable new understanding of the limitations of currently available drugs and will serve as a promising new treatment strategy for devastating genetic diseases such as Timothy Syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Control of serotonergic gene expression is of general interest as serotonin has wide-ranging modulatory effects on central neural circuitry and altered serotonergic gene expression, brought about by either genetic or early life environmental stressors, has been implicated in several neuropsychiatric diseases including depression, stress-related anxiety disorders, autism, OCD, and schizophrenia. The objective of the proposed research is to introduce assays of chromatin architecture to the study of serotonin neuron development and determine whether continuously expressed developmental neuronal transcription factors control gene expression through the regulation of open chromatin states. We will investigate previously unaddressed fundamental questions about how continuously expressed neuronal transcription factors control gene expression as postmitotic neurons progress through life, which may provide fundamental knowledge about underlying mechanisms of neurodevelopmental disorders in which gene expression trajectories are thought to be altered.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ischemic diseases - such as heart attacks – occur when blood flow decreases or stops, causing damage to organs and tissues. These diseases afflict millions of people in the United States and current treatments are inadequate to restore the small blood vessels in the affected tissues. Here, we propose studies to develop a new strategy to make the transplantation of endothelial cells (the cells that line all the blood vessels in the body) more effective for the treatment of ischemic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The over-arching goal of the proposed research is to translate a new MRI technology, hyperpolarized (HP) MR, to the clinic in the setting of large-field-of-view (FOV) MRI, which utilizes both the agents HP [1-13C] pyruvate and [2-13C] pyruvate in metastatic prostate cancer patients. Prostate cancer demonstrates tremendous biologic diversity, and there is an urgent need to develop more sensitive and specific imaging biomarkers to characterize the disease. We aim to develop a large-body transmit/receive system and pulse sequences for large FOV and apply them to a cohort of prostate cancer patients: this work will aid in future patient-specific treatment planning, facilitate earlier assessment of response to therapy, and facilitate the development of novel experimental strategies for cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because many genetic, infectious and neoplastic diseases are driven by changes in PI(4,5)P2 levels. We seek to identify the basic mechanisms whereby healthy cells control PI(4,5)P2 levels and couple them to multiple, parallel PI(4,5)P2-dependent membrane functions, revealing basic cellular mechanisms underpinning these diseases. Therefore, the research is relevant to NIH's and NIGMS's central mission of seeking fundamental knowledge about living systems and life processes that lay foundations for advances in disease treatment and prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Food insecurity is a major public health problem that affects 1 in 7 Americans, disproportionately impacts low- income and minority households, and is associated with poor cardiovascular health. The proposed Mentored Career Development Award will provide further understanding of the relationship between food insecurity and cardiovascular disease allowing us to tailor an innovative tool for primary care practices to address food insecurity and improve cardiovascular health. This research program could improve the care of low-income and vulnerable patients by reducing the negative impact of food insecurity on cardiovascular health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project will be the first to investigate the impact of predictability of the word learning environment on fast-mapping, retention, and generalization of newly learned words in young children with ASD compared to cognitively matched NT peers. This project will employ two brief eyegaze experiments which will evaluate performance on a word-learning task in which words will be taught in both predictable and unpredictable sequences and tested as they appeared in training immediately (fast-mapping) and after a 5-minute delay (retention) as well as for generalization to shape-matched objects. Finally, individual differences (e.g., extant language and cognitive abilities) associated with greater disruption of learning from unpredictable stimuli will be investigated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE We showed that activation of -catenin in osteoblasts leads to MDS and occurs in 38% of MDS patients. ATRA is reported to inhibit -catenin signaling. Our preliminary data show that inhibition of -catenin signaling in 14 such patients by ATRA improves hematologic phenotype and treats MDS in mice. We aim to dissect molecularly and genetically in mouse and xenograft models the specificity of the inhibitory action of ATRA in this type of osteoblast-induced MDS to explore its potential use in these patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Sepsis remains the leading cause of death in critically ill patients. The proposed research is relevant to public health because the elucidation of Lipocalin 10 (Lcn10) in sepsis-induced vascular leak is ultimately expected to open new avenues and develop novel therapeutic tools for increasing the expression levels of Lcn10 in septic endothelial cells, thereby resulting in a decreased vascular leakage and an improved survival. Thus, the proposed project is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to advancing fundamental knowledge and translational study that will help to reduce the burdens of human disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE SARS-CoV-2 uses angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) as the receptor for cell entry. We propose to study the host factors that regulate the transcription of ACE2, and to analyze the function of virus variants that adapt to replication in cells expressed low levels of ACE2. Upon conclusion, this research will extend our knowledge of host factors essential for SARS-CoV-2 infection and provide new targets for the treatment of SARS-CoV-2 infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with early-stage bladder cancer have seen few meaningful treatment advances in the last 20 years. Focusing on two groups with particularly acute need for new treatment options, we aim to discover and validate genomic contributors to disease progression and chemotherapy resistance, and to preclinically examine HER2-directed antibody-drug conjugate therapy as an alternative to platinum-based cytotoxic chemotherapy. Our long-term translational goal is to use integrated clinical and laboratory studies to develop more effective and less toxic treatments for patients with localized bladder cancer, a frequently fatal yet understudied disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Whereas the impact of risk variants and environmental stress associated with brain disease occurs in aggregate, the interactions between the myriad variants and stressors are undetermined, thereby limiting the translation of highly complex genetic insights into medically actionable information. We propose to combine functional genomics, genetic screening, and genome engineering approaches to explore the complex genetics of psychiatric and neurodegenerative disease risk. By better understanding the interactions between genetic variants and stress, we hope to improve diagnostics, predict clinical trajectories, and develop novel therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This proposal focuses on the fungus Cryptococcus neoformans, responsible for hundreds of thousands of deaths yearly, and towards which there is no adequate treatment. We aim to characterize a gene that, in its absence, renders the fungus sensitive to a variety of antifungals and also alters the fungal-host interactions, which are important for the progression of the disease. Elucidation of the function of this gene will result in a better understanding of antifungal resistance and fungal pathogenesis, opening new areas of research that could potentially result in improved therapeutics. Therefore, given the high medical burden of this yeast, and the limited and suboptimal treatments, this research is relevant to NIH’s public health mission and a specific priority for various institutes such as NIAID and NHLBI. Lastly, because this gene resembles an ABC transporter, which play a significant role in resistance to antimicrobials and anticancer treatments, this work will also contribute to basic cellular knowledge, impacting the research of ABC transporters and antimicrobial resistance in general.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Animal models of SARS-CoV-2 infections are critical for the discovery of therapeutics, as well as understanding SARS-CoV-2-induced acute respiratory distress syndrome and extra-pulmonary complications. Unfortunately, current mouse models for COVID-19 do not allow to study the mechanism of organ-specific pathology. The proposed research is critical to public health because it will generate novel preclinical mouse models to study tissue-specific SARS-CoV-2-induced disease and provide a deeper understanding of the fundamental mechanisms controlling lung and gut pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Malaria, caused by Plasmodium species, is an unresolved global health burden without an effective vaccine. Development of potent and translatable vaccines against malaria has been hampered by our incomplete understanding of the mechanisms by which the immune system can be trained to control Plasmodium infections. The goal of this research is to dissect mechanisms of CD8 T cell-mediated protection against liver-stage malaria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative We recently found novel CRL4 ubiquitin ligase complexes that regulate the protein levels of SRY-box2 protein, SOX2, a dose-dependent master transcriptional factor that plays a central role in regulating the self-renewal and pluripotency or multipotency of embryonic stem cells, and many fetal and adult stem cells. Haploinsufficiency of human Sox2 is sufficient to cause the familial anophthalmia/microphthalmia syndrome associated with seizures, brain abnormalities, and slow growth, whereas gene amplification and over- expression of SOX2 are frequently associated with a large spectrum of cancers. We propose to investigate this CRL4-based novel and important lysine-methylation dependent regulation on SOX2 that controls the self- renewal and pluripotency of embryonic stem cells and many fetal and adult stem cells during embryonic development and tissue homeostasis using both pluripotent stem cells and animal models.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Southeastern U.S. has the highest rates of unintended pregnancy as well as STI/HIV infection and current efforts are met with improper use of contraception and low adherence to antiretorviral pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP). This project is proposing to investigate behavioral and socio-cultural factors involved in contraception decisions and attitudes towards multipurpose prevention technologies by translating current knowledge from data collected in Sub-Saharan Africa to other high-risk vulnerable populations. These data will expand our understanding of women’s perceptions giving context for implementation of multipurpose prevention technologies and providing improved reproductive and sexual health options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative In response to large numbers of senior center clients who suffer untreated depression and the dearth of geriatric mental health providers, we have simplified Behavioral Activation to be delivered by lay volunteers (“Do More, Feel Better”; DMFB). The focus of Behavioral Activation is to guide clients to reengage in daily pleasant and rewarding activities, and reduce depressive symptoms. If we can show that the lay delivery model has positive impact in comparison to MSW-delivered Behavioral Activation, we will have identified an effective intervention that can be used by a large untapped workforce of older adult volunteers across the nation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: We will perform first systematic test of associations between maternal diagnoses around pregnancy and the risk of ASD in offspring. In order to understand whether the observed associations between maternal diagnoses and ASD arise due to genetic or non-genetic mechanisms, we will then analyze family and molecular genetic data available for this large cohort. Our goal is to identify potential novel risk factors for ASD, close important gaps in the knowledge about the etiology of ASD, and elucidate possible pathways to prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Respiratory viral infections are an important cause of hospitalization and death in adults, and we are concerned that exposure to outdoor air pollution may reduce the body's ability to fight infection. This epidemiology study will examine the association between short-term exposure to outdoor air pollution concentrations and the immune system response to respiratory viral infection, in a population of adult patients hospitalized with severe respiratory viral infections. By studying this link between air pollution and respiratory viral infection, we can learn how to better counsel our patients to avoid specific pollutants in the short term, so as to protect them against severe respiratory infection, while we contribute to decisions on air quality regulations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: There are few effective therapeutic options for KRAS-mutant lung cancer (KMLC), and there is an urgent need to develop a better understanding of the biological basis of KMLC growth and metastasis. On the basis of the preliminary results presented here, we postulate that KMLC growth and metastasis is driven by a chromosome 1q amplicon containing an actionable Golgi-dedicated kinase (PI4KIIIβ) that promotes secretion of pro- tumorigenic effector proteins. If proven true, these findings would advance our understanding of the mechanisms of KMLC progression and would provide a rationale to advance PI4KIIIβ antagonists into clinical trials for the treatment of KMLC and other chromosome 1q-amplified tumor types.

PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed exploratory studies are an important area of plague research as they have potential to uncover fundamental knowledge about flea processes that can be manipulated by Yersinia pestis to allow it to be transmitted by flea vectors. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Autonomic failure patients (due to Parkinson disease, pure autonomic failure and multiple system atrophy) have nocturnal supine hypertension which is difficult to treat without worsening their orthostatic hypotension. We propose a novel therapeutic approach of using continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) to control nocturnal hypertension, reduce unary volume loss and improve daytime orthostatic hypotension. We believe our results will provide the mechanistic insight to develop a simple but elegant and highly innovative approach to treat nocturnal hypertension in these patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Septins undergo dynamic high-order assembly and remodeling to execute a scaffolding and/or diffusion-barrier role in diverse functions including cytokinesis, cell morphogenesis, and cell migration. Mutations or overexpression of septins are associated with cancer, neurodegenerative diseases, and infertility. Thus, our proposed study on the mechanisms of septin high-order assembly and architectural remodeling is fundamentally important not only for basic research but also for public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The mechanisms by which global regulatory proteins operate on their RNA targets are complex and are still largely not understood; understanding these mechanisms is crucial for preventing or alleviating bacterial infections and antibiotic resistance. The overarching goal of the proposed work is to characterize in vivo the molecular features that underlie novel CsrA-target interactions that we have recently uncovered as well as to decipher the biological relevance of these interactions; the CsrA protein is part of the Csr (carbon storage regulator) system, a global regulatory network known to impact virulence factors, secretion systems, and other important genes for rapid host adaptation in a number of pathogens. We expect these studies to further expand our knowledge of the diversity of post-transcriptional regulation approaches that global regulators can exert in bacteria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A large proportion of cancers in India are detected at a late stage, which results in high mortality. The goal of this study is to develop a low-cost mobile health platform that will educate individuals and providers via apps using their own mobile devices and connect them with screening support staff at tertiary medical colleges who will provide coordination and navigation support. This approach will address current patient, provider, and health system gaps and offer an interconnected infrastructure to deliver organized population-based screening to reduce the burden from cancer in India and other resource-constrained settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research focuses on understanding how the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa evolves during growth in building premise plumbing biofilms, and how this evolution impacts downstream infection pathogenesis. This project will provide fundamental knowledge about microbial persistence in premise plumbing and in the host that is relevant to public health because potable water is a major source of bacteria that cause opportunistic infections. This work is relevant to the mission of the NIH because it is expected to inform development of therapeutic, public health, or engineering-based interventions to prevent infections seeded by premise plumbing biofilms, thereby reducing the disease burden from waterborne opportunistic pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Commensal gut protists shape the bacterial composition of the human gut microbiome and protect against inflammatory bowel diseases. However, how protists interact with other microbes and contribute to the gut metabolic environment to cause these outcomes are unclear. This work will use genomics and defined culture- based approaches to determine mechanisms of protist-bacteria and protist-host interactions, with the potential to support the use of commensal protists and their metabolites in therapies.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Patients with social risk factors, including poverty, being a minority, lack of an education, and living in rural areas are all associated with having worse health outcomes and having more difficulties recovering after surgical procedures. We will study the effect of social risk factors and rurality on health outcomes after surgery to identify patients that would benefit from care pathways that help poor people. One problem is that medical records usually do not contain information about social risk factors. We will use multiple data sources to try to determine which social risk factors have the most effect on surgical outcomes. These studies will help us understand outcomes in patients receiving care within and outside of the VA and how to use that data to improve our ability to identify patients that need extra help. In addition, a better understanding of which social risk factors lead to poor outcomes will help us to design care pathways that provide services and treatments that will improve outcomes after surgery.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: EDITH NOURSE  ROGERS MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSPITAL
PHR: VA seeks to promote patient-centered care in which Veterans' personal values, goals, and preferences drive health care plans. Cancer screening often involves a complex process whereby patients who do not exhibit any symptoms participate in repeated testing over sometimes inconsistent intervals over many years. Clinical recommendations do not account for variation in these perceptions over the course of cancer screening, and little is known about how they change over time and between screening intervals. Using lung and breast cancer screening initiatives as cases, this work will generate greater understanding of how perceptions of risk change throughout the screening process. We will develop guidance and materials for patients and providers to facilitate patient-centered shared decision-making in repeat cancer screening.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA SALT LAKE CITY HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Poverty has a devastating effect on Veterans’ health and well-being. Through the Shallow Subsidy program, Veterans and their families living in 15 high-cost communities throughout the country who are experiencing housing instability can receive long-term rental assistance and job training with the long-term financial self- sufficiency. The impact of the Shallow Subsidy program on Veteran housing, healthcare cost, health, income, and employment outcomes as well as Veteran experience with this new program is not known. Through this project, we will generate important information about the Shallow Subsidy program. We will use nationwide data to describe the geographic variation in Shallow Subsidy services and expenditures throughout the different, eligible communities. We will measure the impact of Shallow Subsidy on Veteran outcomes as well as the cost-effectiveness of the program relative to usual care. Finally, we will interview Shallow Subsidy participants to better understand barriers and facilitators of the program.
