IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: There is increased attention on social determinants of health (SDOH) as a result of empirical evidence showing that the patient’s social background is associated with their health behaviors and clinical outcomes. Now more than ever, health care systems (HCS) are being held accountable for addressing social factors. Improving the quality of health care among racial and ethnic minorities is a VA priority. A systematic approach is needed for Health information technology (HIT) to be effective at addressing minority health and health disparities. Our project will use HIT to address the SDOHs that contribute to health disparities in minority populations and other medically underserved groups as a multi-step process that involves identifying patients who have social risk factors and implementing an assessment system with the goal of improving the outcomes of Veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Among Veterans over 50 years old, 17% actively smoke cigarettes. Teachable Moment to Opt- Out of Tobacco (TeaM OUT) is a smoking cessation intervention designed to make use of interactive voice response (IVR) technology in order to engage with patients during a possible teachable moment: the discovery of a pulmonary nodule. This project will evaluate whether a pragmatic, proactive, low-cost solution, that takes advantage of a naturally occurring teachable moment, can increase smoking abstinence in this group as well as provide generalizable results for patients in multiple settings and situations.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) is common among Veterans and results in poor psychological functioning, quality of life, and physical health. This includes having disproportionately high rates of obesity, in part due to PTSD symptoms interfering with physical activity and healthy diet. Unfortunately, Veterans with PTSD have poorer weight loss outcomes than those without PTSD in VA’s existing weight management program, MOVE!. Based on pilot work, it appears that a weight management program that augments standard PTSD care and targets PTSD-related barriers to weight loss improves weight and PTSD symptoms. Whether it improves these issues more than standard VA care is in need of study, which is the focus of the proposed research. The proposed study also seeks to understand factors that would interfere with and facilitate implementing the program in VA if it is effective. This Veteran-centered, tailored weight loss program may efficiently benefit both physical and mental health of Veterans with PTSD, addressing standard care limitations.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: There is increasing recognition that social determinants of health (SDHs)–personal circumstances and environmental factors that shape an individual’s daily life–contribute to meaningful variation in clinical and economic outcomes. Systematic procedures for assessing and addressing SDHs in health care settings could improve prevention and treatment efforts. In order for the Veterans Affairs (VA) system to achieve this goal, there is a need to evaluate the impact of SDHs in Veterans to determine the best candidates for integration into the electronic health record. The proposed study will leverage national surveys of the general VA population and Veterans at high-risk for hospitalization to identify SDH factors associated with health care utilization, cost, community bed days, and patient experience outcomes. We will partner with VA leadership, clinicians, patients, and caregivers, to prioritize SDHs that are actionable (i.e., addressable through VA or community services) and develop recommendations for SDH measure screening procedures and electronic health record integration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have developed a highly novel gene therapy approach to achieve a functional cure for HIV, based on engineering B cells ex vivo to express HIV broadly neutralizing antibodies (bnABs). The approach is well suited for in vivo delivery because B cells are abundant and accessible in the body, and because modifying relatively few B cells is sufficient to generate the desired therapeutic effect. Here, we further develop in vivo delivery vectors in order to generate multi-specific bnAb responses for long-term HIV control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our long-term goal is to understand the cellular events that underlie the formation and growth of unstable atherosclerotic plaques in the arterial wall, which can cause heart attacks and strokes and represent the leading cause of death worldwide and are highly-relevant to the mission of the NIH. These vulnerable plaques are largely composed of macrophages and lipids deposited in the sub-endothelial layer of arteries resulting from chronic inflammation and endothelial cell injury or dysfunction. Because the liver is the primary site of lipid synthesis, we are unraveling the molecular mechanisms responsible for the activation of deleterious cell signaling pathways in the liver in an effort to identify new therapeutic targets to treat atherosclerosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: The STEM workforce, including the field of neuroscience, continues to lack racial and ethnic diversity. To reduce the disparity in the representation of Black and Latin-X neuroscience trainees, this proposal establishes a unique neuroscience fellowship opportunity at a Historically Black College and University (HBCU). This fellowship will diversify our neuroscience curriculum, expand the network of neuroscience peer and traditional mentors for trainees, and will allow fellows to establish themselves as leaders through undergraduate course development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative One million patients are hospitalized each year for the management of heart failure, and 25% of Medicare beneficiaries who are hospitalized for heart failure are readmitted within 30 days. Previous interventions designed to prevent readmissions in this population have had mixed results, possibly because they have not involved home health aides, who are often with patients post-discharge for prolonged periods of time. The goal of the proposed project is to develop and pilot test a novel intervention for home health aides caring for patients with heart failure, in order to avert avoidable readmissions and improve patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Acute allograft rejection is a T cell mediated immune response that continues to undermine treatment of end- stage organ disease through transplantation. The infiltration of endogenous memory T cells into allografts occurs early after reperfusion and the experiments proposed in this study will test the mechanisms of memory CD8 T cell activation to directly mediate increased graft tissue injury and rejection of cardiac allografts subjected to prolonged cold ischemic storage. The results should unveil new therapeutic targets for development of strategies to decrease this inflammation and inhibit acute graft injury and failure in recipients harboring high numbers of pre-existing memory CD8 T cells reactive to graft alloantigens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Obesity and other weight-related problems, including poor dietary intake, inadequate physical activity, body dissatisfaction, and disordered eating behaviors, are of major public health concern, given their high prevalence and serious health consequences. Of particular concern is the high prevalence of these weight- related problems in adolescents and young adults from low-income and ethnic/racial minority groups in the United States. This longitudinal program of research will identify short- and long-term multi-level (individual, family, friend, school, worksite, and neighborhood) predictors of weight-related problems in young people and will guide the development of highly innovative and effective interventions to reduce the burden of these problems on marginalized populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lymphoma is a cancer derived from lymphocytes, a type of white blood cell, with an annual mortality of over 20,000 patients in the United States. This research aims to uncover the key oncogenic signaling pathways that cancer cells gain addiction to in support of their survival and growth and to design corresponding treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE Improving human health will require improved understanding of human DNA, which has about 3 billion units that code for more than 20,000 different proteins (with many of these proteins existing in multiple forms) and for an undetermined number of regulatory molecules. Dealing with all of these entities and their interactions requires extensive use of computer algorithms. Exchanging information about the development and optimal use of these computational biology and bioinformatics algorithms is the focus of the Pacific Symposium on Biocomputing (PSB), which is one of the more significant scientific meetings on this topic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE RNA editing by adenosine deaminase that acts on RNA (ADAR1) helps control the cells inflammatory response by editing a unique RNA conformation, but at the cost of promoting viral infection and growth. The proposed research will gain a better understanding of how this unique conformation is recognized by ADAR1 at the molecular level. Using this knowledge, new treatment strategies can be designed in order to help fight viral infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Enterococcus faecalis causes infections with high mortality. This research project will assess whether and how inhibitors of the enzyme carbonic anhydrase can work together with currently used antibiotics to inhibit the growth of E. faecalis. The results from the study will inform efforts to develop new therapies for E. faecalis infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Functional connectivity and functional networks of the brain’s cortical gray matter have allowed us to better understand how different regions of the human brain are connected. In this project we will investigate functional networks of the brain’s white matter, a critical region of the brain that is often overlooked in functional magnetic resonance imaging studies. Findings from this study will help to understand the brain as an integrated system of both white matter and gray matter and help to better diagnose and treat neuropsychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Narrative Diabetes mellitus is a metabolic disorder affecting about 8.8% of the world’s adult population, and these patients frequently suffer with skin and soft tissue infections, usually caused by Staphylococcus aureus. We find that S. aureus are more difficult to kill with antibiotics in diabetic mice and resistance evolves more rapidly. Here we will determine how diabetes contributes to antibiotic tolerance and resistance in S. aureus during infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: The correct cellular concentration of the bioactive vitamin A derivative, all-trans-retinoic acid (RA) is critical for optimal performance of adult organs and tissues. The enzymes called retinol dehydrogenases are important because they determine the rate of RA biosynthesis, but not all retinol dehydrogenases have yet been identified. The proposed studies will show whether the candidate enzymes, retinol dehydrogenase 2 and retinol dehydrogenase-similar, contribute to RA biosynthesis and homeostasis in mammals in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: The T helper lymphocyte type 2 (Th2) is a type of white blood cell that is capable of producing Th2 cytokines and that supports accumulation of another type of white blood cell, eosinophils. Eosinophilic esophagitis is a type of food allergy in which eosinophils build up in the tissue of the esophagus and cause inflammation and gastrointestinal symptoms. We found that certain human gastrointestinal bacteria metabolites (short-chain fatty acids) could enhance the Th2 cytokine production by Th2 lymphocytes, potentially causing EoE, and our proposed studies are expected to provide a detailed understanding of the regulatory role of short-chain fatty acids to Th2 cytokine production by Th2 lymphocytes in the Th2-inflamed tissue.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative: Pyrazinamide is an antibiotic used to treat tuberculosis, an infectious disease caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis, that kills more than 1 million persons every year worldwide. The bactericidal activity of pyrazinamide in vitro is poor which prevents the full understanding of its mode of action and diminishes our capacity to fight against pyrazinamide-resistant tuberculosis. Here, we show that pyrazinamide is highly active against M. tuberculosis when grown in a condition that recapitulates the infection settings and we will use this in vitro model to elucidate the mode of action of pyrazinamide to help the fight against pyrazinamide-resistant tuberculosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The heart constantly requires energy to work. Mitochondria, which are renowned as being “the powerhouse of the cell”, supply continuous energy to the cardiac cells. Mitochondria malfunction is closely linked to development defects and dysfunction in the heart. This application seeks to advance our understanding of metabolic reprogramming of the heart through mitochondrial signaling pathways during postnatal development and pathological development. Specifically, this proposal will utilize a genetic model and state-of-the-art multisystems approach to determine the role of the novel muscle-specific mitochondrial regulator Perm1 in mitochondrial biogenesis and energetics in the healthy and diseased hearts.

PHR: Lipoproteins in the circulation are important for the body’s ability to utilize fat. When these lipoproteins are thrown out of balance, they can contribute to cardiovascular disease and other inflammatory disorders. This work is aimed at understanding how a protein called apolipoprotein A-II works to maintain lipoprotein balance, a question that has plagued scientists for nearly 5 decades.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Clostridioides difficile has a complex metabolism that supports gut colonization as well as capacity to rapidly expand after antibiotic ablation of the commensal microbiota promotes host-based release of nutrient sources via toxin-mediated damage to mucosal surfaces. Using novel methods in nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) we will clearly define the real-time metabolism of living C. difficile cells, under anaerobic and reducing conditions, to inform metabolic targets in carbon and nitrogen metabolism. Findings will inform functional studies to identify therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed research is relevant to public health because our ability to diagnose and treat brain disorders is currently limited by our understanding of the fundamental neurobiological mechanisms underlying complex behaviors, and associated brain states such as motivation and arousal. Because of the evolutionary conservation of mammalian brain structures, an understanding of the neural circuitry controlling these processes in the laboratory mouse should yield fundamental concepts and details that are relevant to understanding the human brain. The research described in this proposal will develop innovative new tools that will aid in the functional dissection of neural circuit mechanisms, and is therefore relevant to NIMH's mission of achieving a deeper understanding of fundamental neurobiology and its dysfunction in brain disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Cryptosporidium species are important causes of diarrhea in AIDS patients and children for which improved treatments are needed and under development. However, drug resistance developed in a dairy calf drug efficacy study for one drug lead in under a week, stressing the need for a basic understanding of Cryptosporidium drug resistance. This project will use a suite of novel methods and three lead compounds to develop and validate methods to study the evolution of Cryptosporidium drug resistance and approaches to prevent its occurrence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Major mood disorders are characterized by an inability to regulate one’s emotions; an impairment that can be mapped onto abnormalities in brain circuits that underlie the salience of affectively-laden material and higher- order cognitive control. These deficits contribute to maintenance of the illness as well as functional disability, and they may worsen with age; a pattern which is in contrast to the improvement in emotion regulation noted in healthy older adults. A better understanding of these complex age-related brain changes could point toward novel targets for intervention to promote improved well-being in patients suffering from disabling mood dysregulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Behavioral disorders that have a strong social component, such as autism spectrum disorders, are often more common and severe in males than in females. Sexual differentiation of the brain likely contributes to these differences. This research explores the behavioral consequences of sex differences in neural systems implicated in social behavior.

PHR: Project narrative Tuberculosis remains a leading cause of mortality and morbidity. The goal of this proposal is to subvert Mycobacterium tuberculosis adaptation to a fatty acid rich diet. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Current vaccines against IAV are designed to largely induce IAV-specific antibodies, and by their design, do not induce the lung resident memory T and B cells that occurs during natural IAV infections and has been shown to be critical for protection against heterologous IAV infections. The H5N1 avian IAV viruses, which have poor immunogenicity, are listed by the CDC as viruses of special concern due their high mortality rate in humans. This project tests our promising biocompatible nanoparticle based IAV vaccine (IAV-nanovax) which induces immunity in the upper and lower airways as well as systemically to determine if it can provide superior, long-term broadly protective immunity and protection against homologous and heterologous IAV strains.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The gut microbiota protects against infection by invading pathogens (colonization resistance), such as Salmonella enterica. The proposed research will investigate if propionate, a short-chain fatty acid predicted to mediate colonization resistance, is metabolized by Salmonella in the inflamed gut to regulate invasion and fuel intestinal growth. This work will describe a novel mechanism by which Salmonella overcomes the inhibitory effects of propionate and provide a deeper understanding of how Salmonella thrives in the gut.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative: A Miltenyi MACSima instrument is requested to enable Oklahoma City VA investigators to perform single-cell, high content imaging of tissue and cells. The ability to quantify large numbers of proteins at the single cell level in tissue sections allows researchers to more deeply interrogate their scientific questions than conventional immunohistochemistry. This instrument will be used for neuroscience, aging, and cancer research studies at this station. Automated iterative fluorescent imaging and associated software produces data at a higher resolution and with tissue context than cytometry methods. This instrumentation will extend the scientific impact of ongoing VA funded studies and increase the speed and rigor of analyses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Killer T cells are mainly thought to target virus-infected cells by recognizing foreign peptides associated with major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class Ia proteins, but recent data show that killer T cells can fight influenza virus infection in mice by recognizing a viral peptide called M-SL9 bound to Qa-1, a protein not usually associated with adaptive immunity. The experiments in this proposal will explore the molecular mechanism of M-SL9 presentation on Qa-1 and will search for additional Qa-1-binding peptides from influenza virus and from a model coronavirus, mouse hepatitis virus. These studies will enhance our understanding of the generation of killer T cell responses and may guide future T cell-based therapies and vaccines against infections and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This R61/R33 study examines the impact of structural racism (SR) on substance use risk via brain structure, function and reward-related decision making in Puerto Rican adolescents living in the mainland US, mostly in New York and in Puerto Rico. During the R61 phase (n=36 in NY; n=36 in PR), we will establish a relationship between SR, between the brain structure, function and reward-related decision making; during the R33 phase, (n=80 in NY; n=80 in PR), we will determine if SR increases substance use risk via the changes brain and behavior, as well as examine neighborhood- and family-level protective factors. Findings will suggest novel structural, family and individual points of intervention by shedding light on neurocognitive mechanisms by which SR can increase substance use risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE OVERALL COMPONENT The Developmental Exposure Alcohol Research Center (DEARC) utilizes rodent models of early life ethanol exposure to examine how early developmental exposure to alcohol makes individuals susceptible to alcohol misuse, compromises neurobehavioral function, and adversely impacts the trajectory of healthy aging. The DEARC will focus on two primary neurodevelopmental periods when ethanol exposure is most prevalent: during gestation through maternal consumption of alcohol; and during adolescent exposure, a key age for initiation of alcohol use characterized by binge and high-intensity drinking that are less common for adults. The work of the Center will contribute significantly to our understanding of the biological basis of Alcohol Use Disorders and its long-term consequences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Oxycodone is the 3rd highest contributor to opioid overdose deaths behind heroin and fentanyl in the United States and remains widely prescribed. Avoiding oxycodone withdrawal has been citied as a reason for misuse and relapse amongst opioid-dependent individuals. In the present proposal the central amygdala will be evaluated for its contributions to oxycodone withdrawal with goal of generating a more targeted approach to treat opioid use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Learning for Early Careers in Addiction and Diversity (LEAD) Program at the University of California, San Francisco continues its mission to address the racial gap in NIH funding. The Program provides training to early- stage researchers from historically underrepresented groups (URG) to increase the number who conduct behavioral or pharmacological substance use and substance use disorders research. The ultimate goal is to improve diversity in addiction research leadership and strengthen the research and training network of NIH and the scientific community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Systemic inflammation is necessary for effective disease response mechanisms but has significant harmful effects to human health in chronic or dysregulated settings, such as clonal hematopoiesis, the overrepresentation of mutant hematopoietic clones. Hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells govern the response to these diseases and are responsive to cues associated with inflammation, therefore it is necessary to identify new inflammatory signals that influence these cells’ behavior. Here, we found that acetate, a diet-associated metabolite which rises during systemic inflammation, may regulate the inflammatory response in these stem cells which we will test using a combination of functional, gene expression, and phenotypic studies of HSPCs in response to acetate during inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The cortex is made up of two main classes of cells, excitatory pyramidal cells and inhibitory interneurons, however, there exists a cell type that is dissimilar from both. The long-range inhibitory neuron is remarkable in its unique morphology and gene expression profile, and this cell type likely plays a similarly unique role in cortical circuit function. Here, I set out to characterize this cell type and test the hypothesis that it regulates the generation of low-frequency oscillations in the cortex.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer death among American Indians and Alaska Natives (AI/AN), who experience disparities in lung cancer incidence, stage at diagnosis, survival, and mortality. The advent of lung cancer screening (LCS) is an evidence-based intervention to reduce mortality from lung cancer, but the implementation of LCS has not adequately performed or evaluated in healthcare settings serving AI/AN patients. The TEALS tribal-academic collaboration will implement an effective community-centered LCS delivery system for AI/AN, and lay the foundation for future patient-level research on LCS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Anxiety disorders are characterized by problems learning about potentially dangerous situations, particularly when possible outcomes in a situation are uncertain. The present application proposes to use neural and computational approaches to understand why people high in anxiety have difficulties learning about uncertainty and why uncertain situations are avoided in and outside of the laboratory. The goal of this application is to determine what learning difficulties are present in anxiety in order to develop more effective treatments that target these learning difficulties.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The strength of an immune response against a transplanted organ depends on the extent of genetic disparities between the donor and the host. We have shown that the microbiota, the community of microbes that colonize the body, is an additional novel factor that can modulate this response. We will investigate both how microbial location in the body differentially impacts transplant outcome, as well as delineate the mechanism by which select taxa either promote or delay transplant rejection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Accurate chromosome segregation critically depends on the effective attachment between kinetochores of the chromosomes and microtubules of the mitotic spindle. Defective kinetochore-microtubule attachments lead to chromosome mis-segregation and aneuploidy. Our work will examine new mechanisms that control kinetochore- microtubule attachments to prevent chromosome mis-segregation. Our long-term goal is to understand how defects in these mechanisms lead to the biogenesis and progression of cancer generated by aneupoidy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Colony stimulating factor 3 receptor (CSF3R) is the primary regulator of neutrophil production. Mutations in CSF3R are associated with poor-prognosis myeloproliferative neoplasms. This proposal investigates a novel mechanism of CSF3R-driven MAPK pathway activation and its role in the biogenesis of myeloproliferative neoplasms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project seeks to adapt and pilot test an intervention to build resilience among young Black gay, bisexual and other men who have sex with men (YB-GBMSM) who are living with HIV. This intervention is designed to improve young men’s perceptions of their own identities, while also enhancing social connections and ultimately improving engagement in care. This project is relevant to public health because YB-GBMSM are disproportionately impacted by HIV, but face many barriers to care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE. For a cell to become cancerous, it must reprogram its metabolism in order to fuel unrestrained growth and progression to metastasis. Head and neck cancer is one of the most common cancers – with low survival and treatment regimens that can leave patients (sometimes quite young) disfigured and unable to swallow or speak. As experts on a human protein known as “DEK,” we have performed experiments that strongly suggest that DEK controls metabolic reprogramming in order to promote cancer development and metastatic dissemination. The proposed studies will determine whether this is the case, while also revealing and testing new metabolism-based strategies for head and neck cancer prevention and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The neural basis of learning is complex, which likely involves the activities of many brain areas whose malfunctions are associated with impaired learning ability in various neurological diseases that adversely affect communication. This project studies how learning is encoded by the dynamic activity of the nervous system at the scale of whole brain with the resolution of individual neurons. The outcome of the proposed study will contribute to our integrative understanding of how learning is regulated by the brain function across scales, inform learning studies in more complex brains, and guide potential design of therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study focuses on two genetic risk factors of autism—structural variation and ultra-rare, single-nucleotide mutation—to pinpoint likely disease-causing genes. We will test the significance of rare, gene-disruptive mutations by examining large numbers of families with autism and discover more complex variants by applying cutting-edge sequencing technologies. We will select a subset of genes and families for clinical follow-up to determine if carriers manifest more subtle features and whether the mutations are necessary and sufficient to cause disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mother-child social interactions play an important role in the mother-to-child transmission of social anxiety; however, the dynamic social processes through which children acquire social anxiety from their mothers are not fully understood. In the proposed project, we will examine the following hypotheses: 1) higher levels of negative maternal verbal communication regarding social situations will mediate the influence of maternal social anxiety on children’s laboratory-based social fear, 2) greater mother-child dyadic rigidity characterized by perseveration in the state of child attending to negative maternal input will mediate the influence of maternal social anxiety on children’s laboratory-based social fear, and 3) more negative maternal verbal communication and dyadic rigidity will mediate the positive association between maternal social anxiety and child social anxiety 6 months later. Findings from this project will provide insight into the dynamic social processes by which mothers transfer social anxiety to their children and identify potential targets for intervention efforts aimed at preventing childhood social anxiety.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stroke, the leading cause of disability in the US, has very limited treatment options; recovery after stroke can occur, and our group has demonstrated the use of optogenetics to selectively stimulate key brain regions to promote recovery. Our goal in this proposal is to investigate the role of key brain circuit dynamics during post-stroke recovery using multimodal approaches. Results from our studies will advance the understanding of how stroke affects brain circuit dynamics and how brain stimulations alter circuits to promote recovery, which is a crucial step in developing effective treatments that improve functional recovery after stroke.

This project will examine how signaling between mitochondria and the nucleus impacts colorectal cancer and its treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Genetic differences between people and populations can impact the risk of adverse effects from environmental exposures. Improved understanding of the relationship between genetic susceptibility and the environment is critical to protecting public health. Current approaches have had limited success in identifying human health relevant interactions. We propose a fundamentally different approach to functional assess commonly variant human genes for their role in specific environmental exposures which could enable more effective human risk assessment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Piperaquine is a vital drug in the fight against malaria, yet resistance has emerged in Southeast Asia. Our project will predict the risk that resistance emerges and spreads in Africa and will identify the causal genetic factors in Plasmodium falciparum parasites. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project narrative Mechano-sensory hair cells within our ear are essential for our ability to detect sound. Hair cells are not regenerated and their loss is a leading cause for deafness in humans. In our proposal, we will investigate whether re-activation of the progenitor-specific genes Lin28b and follistatin will enable supporting cells to re-activate a progenitor-like state and allow them to regenerate lost hair cells. We anticipate that insights gained from our study will provide exiting new avenues for cell-based hearing restoration efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance/Narrative Understanding the molecular basis of immune responses is important to the development of vaccines, fighting infectious diseases and designing cancer immunotherapy. Using samples from herpes zoster vaccination studies, we will perform cutting-edge high-coverage metabolomics to learn how individuals respond to vaccination differently, and how metabolic phenotypes influence the immune responses. The scientific findings in this project shall guide vaccine development, trials, and therapeutic designs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE NMDA receptors mediate excitatory neurotransmission in the central nervous system and play important roles in neuronal development and synaptic plasticity. They are also implicated in many neurological and psychiatric disorders, and subunit-selective modulation of NMDA receptors by targeting a single GluN2 subunit in specific brain regions or neuronal cell types could be therapeutically beneficial in a number of diseases. We will investigate novel subunit-selective allosteric modulators and glycine site agonists. These experiments will uncover novel structural and mechanistic features of NMDA receptor modulation and provide new avenues for basic and translational research, as well as facilitate the development of novel therapeutic agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Epilepsy resulting from brain infection, tumors or injury presents with tissue remodeling that employs protein- degrading enzymes. These enzymes may damage “perineuronal nets,” an important protective coat around inhibitory neurons. The loss of this coat slows neuronal firing, making these neurons less inhibitory and giving rise to seizures. This proposal investigates how perineuronal nets may be causally involved in epilepsy and may suggest a completely different therapeutic approach to ameliorate this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal extends successful work funded by a NIH Director's Transformative Research Award to apply a site-directed RNA editing approach to repair mutations in neurological disorders. We focus on guanosine to adenosine mutations that underlie several neurological disorders, including Rett syndrome, our model for testing basic and translational hypotheses related to the technology because of symptom reversibility in Rett mice. Our recent results show, for the first time with any editing method, widespread in vivo repair of an endogenous protein (MeCP2) in CNS neurons.

PHR: Project Narrative Membrane Associated RING CH (MARCH) family of proteins were recently found to restrict HIV-1 replication by blocking envelope incorporation in the budding virions in the producer cells. A better understanding of the antiretroviral mechanism of MARCH proteins and its effect on HIV-1 infection has the potential to be utilized for the development of new therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: DNA fragility generated by alternative DNA secondary structures is a known cause of many human diseases, occurs in normal DNA processes, and can be affected by cellular activities, environmental and chemical exposures, and nucleotide sequences. We propose to investigate the role of alternative DNA structure in the generation of topoisomerase II-mediated DNA breaks, to evaluate DNA structure-rich and break-prone regions as a biomarker for cancer susceptibility, and to use naturally occurring sequence variants to identify structure characteristics contributing to DNA fragility. This work will reveal a new aspect of the molecular mechanism for DNA structure-driven fragility, and eventually lead to development of novel diagnostic measures for cancer caused by the DNA fragility-directed mutations.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multiple sclerosis (MS) and its animal model, experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), are known to be T cell-mediated autoimmune diseases. In this proposal, we will elucidate crosstalk between the innate immune system and the central nervous system through the dectin-1 receptor to identify novel therapeutic targets for neuroprotection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Genomic technologies are revolutionizing biomedical research and increasingly permeating all aspects of biosciences research and medicine. This development has triggered a huge need for genomic data analysis expertise among researchers and professionals. There is a particular need for this expertise among researchers in the neuroscience community and this proposal aims to provide training in genomic analysis to undergraduate students who are interested in careers in neuroscience.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This work aims to develop innovative statistical methods for analyzing phase III and IV biomarker studies to accelerate biomarker development for cancer early detection. The proposed research is essential for analyzing two high-impact collaborative studies for pancreatic cancer and lung cancer early detection; it will also yield guidelines for addressing several critical issues in current practice, including: 1) primary endpoint selection and proper strategies to assess screening efﬁcacy in phase IV trials, 2) utilization of phase IV studies in phase III biomarker panel development, and 3) combination of studies with differential screening modalities and eligibility criteria when estimating design parameters for biomarker clinical utility trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Patients with Schwannomatosis (SWN) overwhelmingly present with intractable, debilitating chronic pain. There is currently no curative treatment for this disease, treatment for SWN is limited to invasive surgery, which carries significant risk of further nerve damage. Our project will i) provide pivotal cellular and molecular mechanistic insights into the role of tumor (HMGB1)–neuron (CCL2)–macrophage (IL-6) crosstalk in causing pain in SWN, and ii) employ FDA-approved IL-6 and EGFR inhibitors to simultaneously alleviate pain and control tumor growth in SWN. If successful, our results will inform the design and catalyze the initiation of clinical trials in SWN to improve treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Most colorectal cancers are microsatellite stable (MSS) and do not respond to checkpoint inhibitor therapy; they have poor prognosis when they have spread locally or have metastasized. By contrast the minority of colorectal tumors with high microsatellite instability (MSI-high), which have defects in DNA mismatch repair, respond to checkpoint inhibitor therapy and have good prognosis. Here we will investigate a tumor-targeted gene knockdown strategy to convert immunologically cold MSS tumors to immunologically responsive MSI-high tumors, which we hypothesize will dramatically improve clinical outcome when used on its own or when combined with chemotherapy or checkpoint inhibitors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Several New World mammarenaviruses (NWMs) cause a severe life-threatening hemorrhagic fever syndrome and pose a significant public health risk and threat to national security. In the absence of FDA-approved vaccines or therapeutics, there is an urgent need to develop antiviral therapies that are broadly applicable to the treatment of NWM hemorrhagic fever. The goal of this project is to advance the development of a novel antibody-based therapeutic approach for the treatment of severe NWM infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Public Health Relevance: Heart disease is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in the developed world. Because cardiomyocytes in the heart have limited regenerative potential in response to injury, loss of cardiomyocytes results in impaired pump function and heart failure. Our strategy to reprogram endogenous cardiac fibroblasts into contractile cardiomyocyte-like cells holds promise as a novel therapy for the treatment of this prevalent and morbid disease.

PHR: This application will test the hypotheses that: 1) during homeostasis marrow-resident cells are the principal source of osteoclast precursors (OCP), while during states of inflammation or fracture repair, circulating cells are a significant OCP source and 2) there are different mechanisms regulating OCP homing, engraftment and differentiation between healthy and disease states. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project narrative This project focuses on understanding how the hippocampus encodes a cognitive map and how it communicates this information to orbitofrontal cortex in order to improve learning. Dysfunction of both these brain areas has been implicated in a wide variety of neuropsychiatric disorders, including schizophrenia, depression, anxiety, and post-traumatic stress disorder. Understanding the contribution of this pathway could lead to an important target for future therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The current project will identify the role of toxins generated by intestinal bacteria in the pathogenesis of brain microbleeds. This research proposal is relevant to public health because there are over 20 million Americans who have chronic kidney disease and these persons are at increased risk for microbleeds (tiny spots of bleeding in the brain) which lead to stroke and dementia. We hope that our work will provoke investigations into gut-directed therapies that will decrease brain microbleeds and preserve quality of life for people living with chronic kidney disease.

PHR: Project Narrative: Our long-term goal is to better understand a broad array of physiological and pathological brain processes and ultimately uncover treatments for neurological disorders such as stroke and vascular dementia. Findings from the proposed project will reveal insights into the integration of different signaling pathways required to regulate blood flow distribution matching with metabolic demands. This will map out the landscape and build an important foundation for understanding brain blood flow in health and disease and ultimately provide the basis for correctly interpreting fMRI data, a technique that has been used extensively in medical diagnostics as well as unearth potential treatments.

PHR: Project Narrative T-cell lymphomas (TCL), comprising ≈15% of non-Hodgkin lymphomas (NHL) in North America, are molecularly heterogeneous, poorly understood, and are associated with poor clinical outcomes, as most patients will develop recurrent or refractory disease that is resistant to currently available therapies, particularly if their TCL expresses the transcription factor GATA-3. We will investigate the role of Notch and GATA-3, a Notch target gene, in T-cell lymphoma pathogenesis and will develop novel therapeutic strategies targeting these transcriptional regulators.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurons can communicate with each other via electrical and chemical signals, as well as membrane-bound packets called extracellular vesicles. These vesicles carry cargo that can contribute to normal brain function, but in neurological disorders including Parkinson’s and Alzheimer’s Diseases, they can also spread toxic proteins throughout the brain. Our research will help us understand how extracellular vesicles are packaged, released and spread in the nervous system, and may identify new strategies to treat a wide variety of neurological diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE An elevated level of lipoprotein(a) [Lp(a)] is an independent causal risk factor for cardiovascular disease. This proposal evaluates the effects of dietary changes consistent with evidence-based guidelines on Lp(a) properties using three randomized controlled feeding trials—the largest and most diverse platform. The findings will improve our understanding of Lp(a) atherogenic properties and their modulators during a common, everyday condition affecting a large segment of the population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Many human diseases exhibit circadian rhythmicity in their symptoms and pathology, including asthma, rheumatoid arthritis and other disorders of the immune system. The results of this study offer the potential to develop new therapeutics for infectious and autoimmune diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The present proposal will test the efficacy of two fumarate-based drugs, dimethyl fumarate (DMF) and its derivative IMF, to prevent or delay the development of lethal cardiomyopathy in Friedreich's ataxia (FA). Currently, there are no drug therapies that ameliorate FA cardiomyopathy and most with FA die of the cardiomyopathy in their 30s. We will identify the optimal dosing and determine underlying cardioprotective mechanisms of these drugs in validated mouse models of FA which can generate important pre-clinical data because it would address the primary cause of mortality in Friedreich's patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We will examine how the brain adapts to newly synthesized motion signals, through regeneration, to control the critical function of gaze stabilization. With vestibular loss, gaze stability is severely compromised throughout life, but newly developing technologies offer to replace lost receptor signals through regenerative or gene therapies. We believe these studies are significant, timely, and necessary in order to provide key insights into a paradigm shift in vestibular pathology treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exercise is well known to stimulate thin fiber sensory nerves in contracting muscles. Stimulation of these nerves reflexively activates the sympathetic nervous system, an effect which causes vasoconstriction in the heart, kidneys and the skeletal muscles. In hearts whose coronary arteries are narrowed by disease, this vasoconstriction can cause chest pain and fatal arrhythmias. Likewise, in muscles, whose arteries are narrowed by disease, this vasoconstriction can cause muscle ischemia and result in pain that is only relieved by the cessation of exercise (i.e., intermittent claudication). Over time, the exaggerated pressor responses to exercise in patients whose arteries perfusing the vascular of the legs can result in thickening of the walls of the heart, which is maladaptive, and irregular heart rhythms, some of which are not compatible with life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH STATEMENT The proposed research contributes to human health by increasing our understanding of the interplay between the immune system and cancer. Here we focus on the role of neutrophils, white blood cells that fight infection but also contribute to chronic inflammation, in the initiation and progression of cancer. We are interested in tumor genes and neutrophil genes that regulate cancer progression and how these pathways can be targeted to facilitate the development of new treatments for cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Through UCSF Summer Research Experiences in Neuroscience, high school students from backgrounds underrepresented in the sciences will further their educational and scientific careers, while deepening their knowledge and understanding of cutting-edge neuroscience research. This project will also help research scientists learn how to mentor students from backgrounds different from their own; thereby equipping these researchers to be more effective mentors throughout their careers. Ultimately, these efforts will help diversify the health science field, which has been repeatedly cited as a mechanism for addressing disparities in health and healthcare.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance This trial will evaluate a web-based, system-level intervention that addresses persistent gaps in PMTCT care by facilitating guideline-adherent services to optimize HIV prevention and maternal health. The HIV Infant Tracking System (HITSystem) 2.1 will prospectively follow HIV-positive pregnant women through 6 months postpartum, employing accessible technologies to ensure complete and timely engagement in clinical care, and robust management of maternal viral loads during critical windows for preventing new HIV infections. Such improvements are essential before low resource countries can close the remaining gaps and eliminate mother- to-child transmission of HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Nearly half of the human genome is comprised of mobile DNA elements that are commonly recognized as sources of genetic mutations to drive cancer development. We recently discovered that the epigenetic silencing of L1 retrotransposons, the autonomously mobile DNA, is required for the propagation of AML- initiating cells, thus establishing an unexpected ‘tumor-suppressive’ function for retrotransposon activity in myeloid leukemia. Elucidating the functional and mechanistic roles of L1 retrotransposons in leukemia pathogenesis and in response to anti-leukemia agents will establish a previously unrecognized regulatory pathway in cancer pathobiology, whose intervention may lead to improved anti-leukemia therapies.

PHR: Distinguishing recurrent tumor from treatment effect following therapy remains a major clinical challenge in neuro-oncology. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to determine the role of sensory-evoked activity in immature adult-born olfactory sensory neurons in their survival and integration in both the healthy and the regenerating adult olfactory system. This will advance our fundamental understanding of the contribution of newborn neurons to olfactory processing and regeneration. Furthermore, our findings may suggest strategies to promote the survival and integration of transplanted stem cell-derived neurons to repair damaged brain areas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our knowledge of heart regeneration is increasing, yet our understanding of which genes are key drivers and how regeneration signals control these genes are incompletely defined. We propose to characterize how cardiac injury induces the expression of paracrine factors that facilitate heart regeneration. Our results will have profound implications for understanding the heart regenerative process and developing innovative strategies to promote heart regeneration in mammals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Metastatic disease remains the primary cause of morbidity and mortality in cancer with little improvement in outcomes seen over the past decade. In this proposal, we investigate (i) mechanisms regulating the formation, (ii) the reversibility, and (iii) therapeutic implications of a niche environment in the liver that is supportive of cancer metastasis and growth. The proposed studies will incorporate clinically-relevant mouse models of cancer to inform development of novel strategies to prevent and treat cancer metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative  Low-cost air-pollution networks, while becoming increasingly prevalent to ﬁll the knowledge-gaps left by sparse regulatory monitoring, introduce a series of novel features like need for co-location calibration to elim- inate noise, spatio-temporally correlated massive datasets, and repeated measures on exposures. Statistical methodology for more traditional air-pollution data collection schemes are not optimized to properly exploit the noisy, high-throughput, and spatio-temporally dependent low-cost data in scientiﬁc studies. We propose new statistical methods that will allow use of the low-cost data to answer new and interesting scientiﬁc questions like studying intra-urban variation in exposure using more detailed maps, improving personal exposure assessment, and using distributions (repeated measures) of exposures in health association studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project narrative Injection is an increasingly common route of administration for opioids and other drugs in the U.S. and increases risk for infectious diseases such as HIV and hepatitis C virus. However, there are no state-level estimates of how many people inject drugs or their characteristics, making infectious disease prevention programs difficult to plan, implement, and monitor. In this project, we will use big data to create estimates of the size of the population injecting drugs in New York, and these estimates will serve as a model for other states aiming to address the infectious disease consequences of the opioid crisis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE Aging-induced changes in the structure and function of lymph nodes result in lymph node atrophy, which is important because lymph nodes play a key role in orchestrating immune responses. The molecular mechanisms driving these changes in aging lymph nodes are poorly understood, but reduced activation of NFκB signaling in lymph node lymphatic endothelial cells may provide a rationale. Therefore, the information gained from the proposed study may help uncover therapeutic strategies that may improve immune function in the elderly and reduce their risk for autoimmune disorders, life-threatening infections, and impaired response to vaccines and tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Suicide results in >800,000 world deaths annually, and suicide rates in India, rising over the past five decades, now reflect the highest rates in the world. This proposal describes a cost-effective, large-scale collection of blood, brain, phenotypic, and psychological autopsy data in India from postmortem suicide cases and controls to increase the generalizability and impact of global genetic and epidemiological studies of suicide death. This unique data resource will stem from a close collaboration between academic suicide research laboratories in the United States and Delhi, India.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Severe alcoholic hepatitis (SAH), an acute presentation of alcoholic liver disease (ALD), carries an extremely high mortality rate and early liver transplantation (ELT) is the only life-saving option available for patients who are refractory to medical management. We have established the largest cohort of ELT recipients in the world and preliminary investigations have shown promising short-term outcomes for individuals who undergo ELT and given us considerable insight into the pathophysiology of ALD. The insight provided by the studies described in the projects that comprise our ALD research initiative will be integral for guiding the expansion of ELT and the ethical framework developed will help influence the creation of a national policy governing the practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Severe alcoholic hepatitis (SAH), an acute type of alcoholic liver disease, carries an extremely high mortality rate and early liver transplantation (ELT) is the only life-saving option available for patients who are refractory to medical management. Despite an increase in the number of centers performing ELT, access to this resource remains limited due to inhibitory social determinants of health (SDoH) that affect how patients progress through the referral, evaluation and transplant process. Understanding how (SDoH) affect ELT access and outcomes as well as assessment of public perception about ELT for SAH is vital for support and future treatment of these patients; therefore, the goals of this study are to establish how social determinants of health impact ELT as well as the continued development of an evidence-based ethical framework regarding ELT for SAH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Post-transplant addiction care for liver recipients who had severe alcohol-associated liver disease is necessary to prevent harmful returns to alcohol use. However, effective, easy-to-implement, and sustainable intervention strategies remain a critical knowledge gap. The proposed project—combining observational studies and an intervention trial—will systematically investigate early and long-term approaches to enhance liver transplant recipients’ engagement in alcohol treatment services and improve post-transplant outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - OVERALL Alcohol consumption during pregnancy increases the risk of causing functional brain damage in the fetus that can lead to life-long adverse neurobehavioral consequences. Except in more severe cases, many children affected by prenatal alcohol exposure are difficult to identify, particularly early in life when interventional approaches may have the greatest positive impact. The New Mexico Alcohol Research Center’s objectives are to advance our understanding of how prenatal alcohol exposure causes functional brain damage and use this information to develop better procedures for the diagnosis and treatment of prenatal alcohol effects earlier in life.

PHR: Narrative This project will use state-of-the-art neuroimaging tools combined with a computational model to examine the underlying mechanisms associated with cognitive and behavioral effects of prenatal alcohol exposure gaining insight from the other center projects. The long-term goal is to understand the neurophysiological underpinnings of cognitive deficits to guide treatment development for individuals affected by prenatal alcohol exposure. This study addresses the needs of individuals with fetal alcohol spectrum disorder and their families and advances the NIAAA Strategic Plan focused on understanding the underlying mechanisms associated with deficits from prenatal alcohol exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Emerging evidence from both preclinical and clinical studies support that the biological vulnerability to chronic central nervous system (CNS) dysfunction in FASD populations is driven by aberrant CNS-immune interactions rendering them particularly susceptible to developing cognitive disabilities during the period of adolescence, often manifesting after secondary challenges such as stress or immune challenges. While the underlying mechanism of adolescent cognitive deficits from prenatal alcohol exposure (PAE) is unknown, the proposed research will identify whether non-coding circular RNAs underlie sensitized CNS-inflammatory immune signaling pathways, potentially inclusive of TLR4-associated factors, from PAE that leads to cognitive deficits. Exploring these novel molecular targets in preclinical models along with leveraging clinical data from adolescent children with FASD, will provide a foundation to develop future therapeutic targets to treat adolescent cognitive deficits as well as identify biomarkers of adolescent cognitive dysfunction for early intervention to mitigate the impact PAE exerts on cognitive function.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prenatal alcohol exposure (PAE) is the most common environmental cause of neurodevelopmental brain injury resulting in the development of fetal alcohol spectrum disorders (FASDs). Children with FASD exhibit persistent learning and behavioral disabilities, which may be due to white matter injury in the brain. The goal of our study is to investigate how alcohol impacts the gene expression and function of oligodendrocytes, the major glial cell type that is responsible for myelinating white matter tracts in a mouse model of FASD.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Armed combat predisposes to burn injury that can cause disfiguring scars and contractures in our Nation’s Veterans. We developed an immune-modulating biomaterial scaffold that allows mouse skin wounds to heal by regenerating new hair follicles and other skin structures. Here, we propose a series of experiments to test the hypothesis that immune-modulating biomaterials can regenerate tissue following burn injury, wounds that heal by scarring, tilting the balance toward a desirable regenerative response. These studies may unravel a new paradigm in burn wound management: providing a biomaterial scaffold to stimulate regenerative immune responses for optimal burn wound healing and skin regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) can measure the concentration of naturally occurring chemicals within the brain, often applying ‘edited’ methods which focus on one particular chemical and location. This project will develop new experimental methods that allow the simultaneous measurement of several chemicals simultaneously in multiple regions of the brain. The methods developed in this study will be disseminated to the neuroimaging community, and are expected to have a wide range of clinical and neuroscience applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative In response to large numbers of senior center clients who suffer untreated depression and the dearth of geriatric mental health providers, we have simplified Behavioral Activation to be delivered by lay volunteers (“Do More, Feel Better”; DMFB). The focus of Behavioral Activation is to guide clients to reengage in daily pleasant and rewarding activities, and reduce depressive symptoms. If we can show that the lay delivery model has positive impact in comparison to MSW-delivered Behavioral Activation, we will have identified an effective intervention that can be used by a large untapped workforce of older adult volunteers across the nation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / RELVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH After a heart attack, dead heart muscle is replaced by scar tissue. Scar tissue induces cardiac remodeling that leads to dilatation of heart chambers and development of heart failure. In this application, we identify and target a novel gene GPNMB for attenuating cardiac remodeling.
